After a long bidding battle, the consortium has obtained 57% of the company in a deal expected to be finalized at end of March.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited 25% stake in Dutch brewer Heineken 7 years ago from her late father, Freddy Heineken. Company is one of the world's great brewers, with more than 170 premium brands in more than 65 countries. Mother of 5 enjoys photography, music and architecture. She is also a member of St. Moritz's elite Corviglia Ski Club. Her husband, investment banker Michel de Carvalho, sits on Heineken's supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 17% stake in auto maker BMW, which his late father, Herbert Quandt, rescued from bankruptcy almost five decades ago.  Sits on supervisory board of the car maker along with sister Susanne Klatten. Owns and manages Delton AG, a $3.7 billion (sales) holding company whose subsidiaries include a maker of homeopathic drugs and a supplier of electricity. Also holds stakes in  logistics company and smart card maker Data Card Corp. Trained engineer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Perry Bass passed reins of family's oil fortune to son Sid 1968; Robert struck out on his own that same year. His Oak Hill investment group manages $26 billion; raised $900 million to buy distressed debt this year. With Pritzker family, bought 8 TV stations from News Corp. for $1.1 billion last July, adding to 9 already owned. Bulking up on aerospace: bought engine parts maker Firth Rixson for $2 billion in 2007; owns stakes in partsmaker Primus, freight carrier Cargo 360 and Aerion, which reportedly has a $3 billion backlog in orders for supersonic business jets. In 2007 forced New York Times to print correction after article alleged one of his TV stations purposefully blacked out a 60 Minutes segment critical of Karl Rove.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood's richest man is $1.5 billion poorer despite ditching the stock market in 2006 and selling off a third of his massive art collection. Saw financial doom on the horizon years ago: "There were billionaires who could not qualify for The Forbes 400. That was one of many warning signs for me to get out." Sold classic drip painting by Jackson Pollock for $140 million in 2006, believed to be the largest sum ever paid for single piece. Also unloaded a Jasper Johns, Willem de Kooning. U. of Texas dropout sorted mail at famed William Morris Agency. Founded Asylum Records 1970, then Geffen Records. Launched DreamWorks with partners Jeffrey Katzenberg, Steven Spielberg in 1995. Democrat famously ditched the Clintons for Obama.

name: Billionaires
bio: Master of the leveraged buyout, once drove a tow truck and is now the richest person in Australia and New Zealand. Despite a reputed affinity for leverage, still managed to have cash last year for dealmaking: in May his Rank Group bought troubled U.S. forestry company Weyerhaeuser's Australian timber assets for $250 million. Deal helped cement Rank's role as packaging powerhouse; now has 5 companies in the industry, all bought within past 3 years, including Australasian forest products group Carter Holt Harvey, Swiss packager SIG, Alcoa's former packaging unit and a North Carolina paper mill. Drew up idea for Rank Group as an M.B.A. student at University of Otago. Boating enthusiast, owns 190-foot yacht Ulysses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of James M. Cox (d. 1957) has lost $2 billion since September as declining ad market punishes media revenues James Cox worked as a newspaper reporter before buying Dayton Evening News for $26,000 in 1898. Merged into politics; 3-term Ohio governor, 1920 presidential candidate alongside veep FDR. Cox Enterprises media empire now includes 17 daily newspapers, 15 TV stations, 86 radio stations; company also dips into auto industry with used car retailer Manheim, Cox Auto Trader. Kennedy now Cox Enterprises chief executive. Inherited 25% stake in company after mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, died in 2007.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of James M. Cox (d. 1957) has lost $2 billion since September as declining ad market punishes media revenues. James Cox worked as a newspaper reporter before buying Dayton Evening News for $26,000 in 1898. Merged into politics; 3-term Ohio governor, 1920 presidential candidate alongside veep FDR. Cox Enterprises media empire now includes 17 daily newspapers, 15 TV stations, 86 radio stations; company also dips into auto industry with used car retailer Manheim, Cox Auto Trader. Blair inherited 25% stake in company after mother, Barbara Anthony Cox, died in 2007. Uninvolved in company affairs; lives in Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: With son Ross Jr., sold natural gas interests under land owned by their Hillwood real estate outfit on Texas' Barnett Shale to Quicksilver Resources in August. Cotton broker's son spent time in Navy, IBM sales department before founding Electronic Data Systems 1962. Sold to General Motors for $2.5 billion 22 years later. Formed data processing company Perot Systems 1988; stock down 40% since September. Two failed self-financed presidential bids in 1992 and 1996; tackled Nafta, budget deficits. His foundation sold a copy of the Magna Carta for $21.3 million 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues in 1972. Retired in May 2003 after 30 years as Its chief executive. Sports enthusiast, sails his Morning Glory yacht competitively; skis, snowboards, plays golf and tennis. Owns luxury golf course and hotel, Fancourt Estate, in South Africa's Western Cape province. His Hasso Plattner Ventures based in Potsdam incubates promising IT technology companie

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned playing card company Nintendo into world's most successful videogame console maker. Sales of the Nintendo Wii machine jumped 47% to 25 million units last year, outstripping sales of similar devices from Sony and Microsoft. Retired in 2005 after running the company for 55 years but remains big shareholder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elected chairman of steel giant Evraz in December replacing fellow billionaire Alexander Frolov with whom he cofounded the group; Frolov remains chief executive. Stock has almost 90%  in past year. He and Frolov bought a stake in Highlands Gold Mining in January from billionaire Roman Abramovich,  large Evraz shareholder. Named presidential aide in Spring 2008. Got start as head of a research lab before Soviet Union collapsed. In 1992 established a precursor to Evraz Holding; made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia. After 1998 Russian financial crisis, bought up steel companies and coal mines on the cheap. In 2006 Russia's richest man, billionaire Roman Abramovich, became Abramov's partner in Evraz. In 2007, made a number of acquisitions, including U.S. firms Claymont Steel Holdings of Delaware and Oregon Steel Mills.

name: Billionaires
bio: Net worth up $400 million in 6 months as sales of privately-held Alticor rose 15% to $8.2 billion in 2008. Met lifelong pal Jay Van Andel (d. 2004) in high school; duo opened drive-in diner after serving in Army together. Started selling all-purpose cleaner door-to-door 1959; eventually gave pyramid selling schemes a good name by turning an army of part-time entrepreneurs into door-to-door peddlers of cosmetics and nutritional supplements. Amway reorganized as Alticor 2000. Retired 1993; son Doug president. Owns pro basketball's Orlando Magic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Google's grown-up and technology advisor to President Obama. Previously touted as front-runner for new U.S. Chief Technology Officer post, says he's happy to remain in private sector. Earned electrical engineering degree from Princeton and Ph.D. from UC, Berkeley. Joined Bell Labs, then Xerox PARC. Developed Java technology at Sun Microsystems 1980s, rose to chief technology officer. Recruited to chief executive post by Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin in 2001. Ads remain propeller of high-profit search engine; stock down 30% in past 6 months.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Former military man turned financial whiz. In 1990s helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed out of the best Russian oil properties; now he is billionaire's Lukoil Chief Vagit Alekperov's right-hand man. As vice president, responsible for strategic development and external relations. "My wealth is a virtual thing," Fedun has said, referring to the fact that most of it is tied up in public stocks. Along with Alekperov, upped his shares in Lukoil last year to 9.2% from 8.3%. The funds for the purchase came from successful deals by the financial holding IFD Capital, which he also manages. An avid soccer fan: owns Spartak of Moscow.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive and controlling shareholder of steelmaker Severstal, which has seen its stock plummet 84% since last February. Though completed three major acquisitions in the U.S. market last year, analysts say the company doesn't have short-term debt problems. Pushing ahead with Liberian iron ore project. In consortium with fellow billionaires Oleg Deripaska and Viktor Vekselberg to bid on world's largest coking coal deposits, Tavan Tolgoy in southeast Mongolia; Mongolian government plans to sell a 49% stake in the project to a foreign investor for $2 billion. In February announced sale of his Sheksna Insurance Group; still has stakes in banks, telecom. Son of mill worker parents became finance director of a steel mill. When the plant's elderly general director instructed him to buy up company shares so it would not fall into the hands of an outsider, Mordashov bought most of them himself. He became general director and built it into a conglomerate, acquiring firms in several sectors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Traces lineage to great-grandfather Ghanshyam Das Birla , who built commodities empire and was a close associate of Mahatma Gandhi. At age 28 inherited Aditya Birla Group, commodities conglomerate named after father, who died at the age of 52 in 1995. Today group has revenues of $28 billion and operations in 25 countries. His Hindalco, which bought aluminium company Novelis for $6 billion in 2007, is world’s largest producer of rolled aluminium. Last October a rights issue by Hindalco did poorly as its stock price plunged to record low. His telecom outfit Idea bought 50% in Indian mobile operator Spice Communications last June. Also has interests in financial services, retailing. Mother Rajashree oversees charitable arm that works in 3,700 villages.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of family of Iraqi Jews who made early fortune in Shanghai more than a century ago and later settled in Hong Kong. Chairs power supplier CLP Holdings, the largest provider of electricity in Hong Kong in which family is big shareholder. Last year announced plans for fourth wind farm in India and opened energy-efficient appliance store Eco Home. Also heads Hong Kong & Shanghai Hotels, which is opening Shanghai Peninsula 2009. Board member of billionaire Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Mori Trust owns office buildings, apartment blocks and hotels in high-rent districts of Tokyo. Recent projects: a 37-story office building with Shangri-La Hotel, just outside Tokyo Station; a tower in Sendai to be northern Japan's tallest when complete in 2010. With older brother Minoru, also a billionaire, inherited initial real estate fortune from late father. Siblings who had vastly different approaches to property development went separate ways in 1999. Akira's hobbies: golf, Japanese chess and reading.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father founded Tana Oil & Gas 1980. Robert practiced tax law for one year; defected to father's firm 1981. Duo merged Tana's production properties with Texaco (now Chevron) 1989; received $480 million in cash and stock. Bought Omni Hotels for $500 million in 1996. Three years later sold rest of Tana to Unocal. Traded in half of his Chevron shares for cash and oil and gas fields 2007. Stake in Omni Hotels still largest piece of fortune; hotel market values down since last fall. Other holdings: Gold's Gym, Mexican retailer Waldo's. In July paid $140 million for 14% stake in Nashville hotel and concert company Gaylord Entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: In news recently for upping his stake in U.S. electronics retailer Circuit City in November when it filed for Chapter 11. Took over his family's discount retailer, Grupo Elektra, in 1987. Today it is one of Mexico's largest electronics retailers; also sells high-ticket items like Chinese motorcycles and cars. Seven years later launched television network TV Azteca, now nation's number 2 network and second-largest producer of Spanish-language television in the world. Opened bank subsidiary, Banco Azteca, in 2002; last year it provided on average 12,000 new loans a day. In 2008 expanded financial services company into Brazil and Peru. Gained notoriety in 2005, when U.S. Securities & Exchange Commission brought a lawsuit against him, alleging he concealed a deal between a TV Azteca subsidiary and another company he owned. Salinas agreed to pay $7.5 million to settle accusations, but neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. Afterward, says he delisted his companies from NYSE because of excessive cost and regulation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked construction jobs in Alaska before borrowing a bulldozer on credit and founding his own company in Montana. Grew with federal highway contracts. Rescued bankrupt Morrison Knudsen in 1996. Reorganized, renamed Washington Group International in 1998; lost in bankruptcy after dispute over later acquisition of Raytheon. Owns stakes in Montana's regional railroad; largest tug and barge fleet in British Columbia; Butte copper mine. Also heavy equipment, environmental remediation and aviation companies. Injected $160 million into containership owner Seaspan in January. Spends majority of time working on new yacht, Attessa IV, and philanthropy; donates time and money to Young Life's Washington Family Ranch camp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Austrian retail chain Billa, sold out to German REWE group in 1996. Invested proceeds in Austrian real estate and is now one of the country's largest, possibly largest, private real estate owners. Assets include 5-star Hotel Radisson in Salzburg, the historic building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange, and 4 palaces in Vienna. Former jazz pianist whose stage name was Charlie Walker has an authorized biography: Karl Wlaschek: A Success Story.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former secretary and third wife of the late Herbert Quandt, German executive who rescued auto maker BMW from bankruptcy.  Retired from BMW's supervisory board in 1997; still owns a 17% in auto maker whose revenues declined 5% in 2008 to $69 billion due to worldwide financial and economic crisis.  Her children, Susanne Klatten and  Stefan Quandt, have large stakes as well and are also billionaires.  Lives quietly in spa town of Bad Homburg near Frankfurt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune crushed as oil, commodity markets plunge; has lost $7 billion in 6 months. Stake in oil venture TNK-BP down 60% since September; investment in aluminum outfit Rusal down 85%. U.S. operations of LyondellBasell filed Chapter 11 just a year after multi-billion dollar merger saddled chemical giant with debt. Public outcry after Royal Bank of Scotland wrote off his 2.5 billion pound loan. Immigrated to U.S. from former Soviet Union 1978 at age 21; arrived penniless. Found way to Harvard Business School and Columbia U. Founded industrial holding company Access Industries 1986. Partnered with school friend Viktor Vekselberg, and later Mikhail Fridman. Trio made first fortune merging Tyumen Oil and British Petroleum (TNK-BP). Recently buying up New York City real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime billionaire appeared on our first international rankings of billionaires in 1987. Has run New World Development since 1970; the stock of the developer, which has interests in infrastructure, retail and telecom, has fallen almost two-thirds in the past year. Remains chairman and goes into the office every day. Son Henry is New World's managing director; eldest grandchild Adrian named to its board in 2007. Cheng fled China in a boat during World War II and got his start in Macau as a clerk in the jewelry store. Cheng eventually married the store owner's daughter and helped him build Hong Kong's biggest jewelry chain. Moved into real estate in 1952 before eventually making a fortune in real estate development. His private Chow Tai Fook Nominee also has numerous investments in public companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's leading oil tanker tycoon through control of Frontline Ltd. Made early fortune moving crude through the Persian Gulf during Iran-Iraq war. Frontline shares down 60% from 2008 highs on lower oil demand. Unfazed, Fredriksen's Arcadia Petroleum moving into oil exploration with deal to drill in the Falkland Islands. Upped stake in German shipper Tui and agitated for its breakup. Also has interest in world's biggest fish farmer, Marine Harvest. Born in Norway but renounced citizenship in favor of tax-friendly Cyprus. Runs empire from grand home in London's Chelsea district. Preparing his legacy: installed 24-year-old daughter Kathrine on Frontline board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kremlin connections helped conglomerate Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires Alexei Kuzmichev and Mikhail Fridman bail out distressed assets: when shares in mobile operator Vimpelcom were halved last fall, Deutsche Bank requested an early repayment of its $2 billion loan against which the shares were pledged; state owned Vnesheconombank put up funds to guarantee the loan. Though their 44% stake is safe for now; Vimpelcom stock keeps falling, down another 12% since its October low. Investment in oil giant faring no better; shares in TNK-BP down 63% over past year. An eight month power struggle at TNK-BP resolved when chief executive was removed and new management put in place; former German chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder, who has ties with Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, joining board. Kiev native ame to Moscow to study, with college buddies Kuzmichev and Fridman started commodities trader, Alfa-Eco, in 1989. Merged oil assets with BP in 2003 which Khan heads.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of property firm, Chinese Estates Holdings, boosted its 2008 profits thanks to well-timed equity sales. Upped his personal stake in firm by 15 percentage points in past year. Lau’s son resigned from its board in October. Owns stakes in other companies including retailer Lifestyle International, which his brother Thomas runs. Canceled his order in February for a new Boeing 787 Dreamliner. Art collector paid $39 million for Paul Gauguin&#39s “Te Poipoi” (“The Morning”) in November 2007. Also owns 3 jets and is said to be one of largest collectors of red wine, with at least 10,000 bottles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Harry moved to New York in early 1900s, created glassworks for Louis Comfort Tiffany. Began developing real estate 1901. Father, Sam, expanded in New York City and New Jersey; built LeFrak City in Queens 1959. Richard joined family business in 1970s, became chairman after dad died in 2003. Today portfolio includes 5,000 apartments in LeFrak City, 16-million-square-foot commercial, residential, retail complex in Newport, N.J. 'Mini-city' includes 429-room Westin Jersey City Newport hotel that opened in February, 2 new residential towers currently under development. Diversifying into Los Angeles, London real estate; owns interests in oil and gas wells.

name: Billionaires
bio: Personal fortune slammed as recession dampens need for home improvement tools. U. of Wisconsin grad built barns to pay tuition. Founded eponymous hardware store in 1972. Expanded into 11 Midwestern states by undercutting competition penny by penny. Today Menard's is the nation's third-largest home improvement chain after Home Depot and Lowe's. Race car buff sponsors Team Menard; son Paul drives for Yates Racing. Donates to Mayo Clinic's Luther Midelfort hospital in Eau Claire, Wis. Embroiled in $900,000 civil suit with ex-girlfriend. She claims he paid her inadequately for legal services; Menard denies the allegations.
title: president and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Menard, Inc.', 'title': 'president and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Murdoch's $5.6 billion gamble on Dow Jones has played out poorly for investors; stock down 70% in the 14 months since buying the company and its crown jewel, the Wall Street Journal, from the Bancroft family. Company lost $6.4 billion in its second quarter, including a $3 billion write-off from its newspaper unit. News Corp president and COO, Peter Chernin, recently announced he will step down in June. Lifelong love affair with the news began at 23, when Australia-born tabloid titan inherited one newspaper. Oxford grad built media empire with Australian and U.S. tabloids, Fox film studio and broadcast network, conservative-leaning cable outlets Fox News and Fox Business. Fox News has been top-rated cable news network for seven years. Fox Business is not publicly rated by Nielsen; claims ratings are up since financial crisis began last fall. Recent memo to staff warns that economic downturn will alter the world stage: "We are in the midst of a phase of history in which nations will be redefined and their futures fundamentally altered."
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'News Corp', 'uri': 'companies/news-corp', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune sliced in half as media industry decimated by advertising meltdown. Crown jewel magazine publisher Conde Nast, favored by luxury advertisers, forced to close six magazines last year. Four other titles--Wired, Architectural Digest, Vogue, Lucky--suffered more than 40% ad page declines in January over previous year. Son of Sam Newhouse, Russian immigrant's son who turned Bayonne Times into Advance Publications, nation's largest privately owned newspaper chain. Donald took over after father's death 1979; expanded and diversified into cable television. With brother Si, owns Bright House Cable (2.4 million subscribers). Combined stakes in Discovery Channel and Animal Planet into new publicly traded company last year. Si heads Conde Nast. Duo owns stunning art collection, which includes Rubens, Johannes Lingelbach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune sliced in half as media industry decimated by advertising meltdown. Crown jewel magazine publisher Conde Nast, favored by luxury advertisers, forced to close six magazines last year. Four other titles--Wired, Architectural Digest, Vogue, Lucky--suffered more than 40% ad page declines in January over previous year. Son of Sam Newhouse, Russian immigrant's son who turned Bayonne Times into Advance Publications, nation's largest privately owned newspaper chain. With brother Donald, took over after father's death 1979; expanded and diversified into cable television. Today duo owns Bright House Cable (2.4 million subscribers). Combined stakes in Discovery Channel and Animal Planet into new publicly traded company last year. Si heads Conde Nast (New Yorker, Vanity Fair, Vogue). Personally hand-counts ad pages in Conde magazines, competitors. Brothers own stunning art collection, which includes Rubens, Johannes Lingelbach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy, Monaco-based Israeli and his family own a vast global shipping empire, plus interests in banking and real estate. Through Ofer's holding company Israel Corp., controls Israel Chemicals, Zim (shipping) and refineries; stock down two-thirds over past year. Other maritime business, Royal Caribbean, also doing poorly; stock off four-fifths since last February. Owns extensive collection of impressionist and modern paintings, including several Chagalls. Donated $40 million to the National Maritime Museum of Greenwich last spring. Awarded an honorary knighthood by Queen Elizabeth in November, for his services to U.K. maritime heritage. Son Idan, who resides in Tel Aviv, is chairman of Israel Corp.; son Eyal, who lives in New York City, handles real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment tycoon thought to be a victim of Bernie Madoff's ponzi scheme. New York City native studied political science at Brooklyn College; earned M.B.A. from NYU. Bought contractor AM General in 1992 for $133 million; maker of military Humvees, luxury SUV Hummers. Sold majority stake to Ronald Perelman for $930 million in 2004. Global conflicts said to be lifting sales of Humvees; GM now looking to sell or phase out gas-guzzling Hummer. His Renco Group ordered to pay $1.8 million to New York state in dispute over polluted mining operations. Said to have spent $5 million to sponsor 20-volume encyclopedia featuring explanation of 613 Jewish commandments.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2005 jet-setting beer magnate swapped control of his Bavaria brewery for 15% of SABMiller, now worth $3.6 billion. Other holdings include stakes in Colombia's biggest TV broadcaster Caracol, packaging maker Biofilm and forestry company Refocosta. Born into a rich family with interests in breweries, took over management of its holdings in 1972 after his father retired. No longer involved in daily operations. Has homes in New York City, Paris and on Baru, his private island off the Caribbean coast of Colombia. Close friend of Colombian author and Nobel laureate Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Son, Andres, appears in U.S. gossip columns with socialite wife, Vogue magazine editor Lauren Davis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Max, arrived from Germany in 1926 with 5,000 canaries; started pet supply business Hartz Mountain Pet Products. Leonard joined business at age 21; sold company for $350 million in 2000 to private equity firm J.W. Childs. Began buying land in New Jersey 1960s; today owns 38 million square feet of commercial, residential, retail properties from Newark to Jersey City, including former Ford plant site in Edison, N.J. now slated for redevelopment. Son Emanuel oversees family's real estate empire, including hip Manhattan hotels Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand. Gave $30 million to alma mater NYU in 1988; business school now bears his name.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Satellite sultan's fortune sliced in half since last year as his 2 companies crash towards earth; Dish Network shares down 70% since last summer, EchoStar down 55%. This February lost out billionaire rival John Malone for control of Sirius Satellite radio. Former pro poker player sold TV satellites from truck with wife in 1980s. Built EchoStar Communications into satellite giant; company commands 13.7 million subscribers today. Spun off cable box manufacturer EchoStar Corp. in 2008. Still runs both companies. Suffered setback in race for high-definition TV dominance with Malone's DirecTV after $6 million satellite failed; launched another satellite this summer. Purchased Internet TV company Sling Media for $380 million September 2007.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'DISH Network', 'uri': 'companies/dish-network', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The brothers' secretive, privately held, diversified empire extends from oil refineries and gas stations to sawmills and forests as well as publishing and potato farms. Nearly all of its subsidiaries have been hit by the global recession as demand for its varied products plummets. Irving empire founded in 1881 by grandfather J.D. Irving now dominates the economy of New Brunswick and neighboring provinces. Investments continue: Irving Oil with BP Plc. plans to build a $7 billion refinery in St. John; teaming with Repsol YPF to construct a liquefied natural gas terminal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas tycoon has lost $3 billion since last year. Graduated from U. of Texas 1952; became bank examiner. Invested $5,000 in local Dallas drugstore; sold chain to Eckerd Corp. for $50 million. Built publicly traded holding company Valhi; stock down 65% since June. Stake in Titanium Metals has lost $1.15 billion over past 12 months. Recently donated to U. of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Texas Republican Party. In January his Waste Control Specialists won decade-long battle to dispose of low-level radioactive waste in West Texas.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: One of South America's most prominent businessmen oversees a diversified empire with interests in Venezuelan television stations, telecom outfits, local brewery Regional and Leones del Caracas baseball team. Has signed an agreement with China Central Television to distribute programming, including popular Latin American soap operas. Sold U.S. Spanish-language TV network Univision to a private equity consortium led by U.S. billionaire Haim Saban for $700 million in March 2007. Cisneros and his wife are familiar figures in high society, hobnobbing with former presidents, designers and fellow billionaires; George H.W. Bush is his fishing buddy. Boasts an extensive collection of Latin American art: one favorite is an Amazonian landscape by German artist Frank W. Post. His foundation promotes education and protection of indigenous people in the Amazon basin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Net worth of Greece's richest man and sole remaining billionaire plunged two-thirds this year as shares in his financial services, oil refining, real estate, shipping, and travel companies plummeted. Despite its stock price being halved, his private banking group, EFG International, is still on acquisition spree, expanding in Paris, Lebanon and Los Angeles and Bangkok in past year. Latsis, who has a Ph.D. from the London School of Economics, recently elected to the board of Institute of Advanced Studies in Princeton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Revitalized Formula One racing into one of the world's most popular sports, with contests held in cities from Monte Carlo to Malaysia. In 2005 he sold his remaining stake in the racing giant to CVC Capital Partners, a leading European private equity firm, then turned around and reinvested with CVC in a new joint company called Alpha Prema. The new corporation now controls 100% of Formula One Group, and Bernie still gets to direct the empire. Though his wealth weathered the economic downturn, personal life did not fare so well: reportedly split from wife of 24 years, former model Slavica Ecclestone. With fellow billionaire Lakshmi Mittal and pal Flavio Briatore, owns soccer club Queens Park Rangers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Golf course magnate and blogging shareholder activist forced resignation of Japan Airlines' president 3 years ago. Sold shares in airline in favor of stake in broadcaster TV Tokyo, latest target of his online browbeating. Claims to have sailed his 150-foot yacht around the world 3 times. Likes to collect expensive wines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former marketing executive created Red Bull energy drink with Thai business partner Chaleo Yoovidhya. Marketed it to young people using cheeky advertising and extreme-sports sponsorships. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the $4.3 billion (sales) company, which is expanding into India, South Korea and Pakistan. Now also sells in France where it had been banned because of its contents; still banned in Denmark, Norway, Iceland and Uruguay. Last year launched new, all-natural product, Red Bull Cola. Company has stakes in 2 soccer teams: Red Bull Salzburg and New York Red Bulls. Mateschitz's other interests include Seitenblicke magazine; luxury resort on Fiji island of Laucala; and Hangar-7, the event center on the grounds of Salzburg airport that houses his historical aircraft collection called the Flying Bulls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Internet and telecom company SoftBank bet heavily on mobile phones by snapping up Japan's Vodafone unit. Company gained 2 million new subscribers in 2008 (more than rivals) but posted drop in net profits, in part because it lowered charges to lure new customers. Committed to paying lenders $14 billion from cash flow over next decade. Runs country's top Internet site, Yahoo Japan; partners with News Corp. on Japanese version of MySpace. Owns baseball team Fukuoka Hawks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Thai energy drink producer T.C. Pharmaceuticals. Teamed up with Austrian Dietrich Mateschitz two decades ago to create energy drink Red Bull. Chaleo provided beverage formula and his partner contributed the marketing flair. Today Red Bull, which has $4.3 billion (sales), is expanding into India, South Korea and Pakistan. Launched a new natural cola in seven nations in 2008. Each partner owns 49% of the company. Chaleo's son, Chalerm, who owns one of Asia's leading wine producers, Siam Winery, holds remaining 2% stake in Red Bull.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunge in commodity and fertilizer prices eating away at Cargill family's fortune. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, started Cargill as a grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took reins 1909. Family owns 88% of company, employees the rest. Today sales exceed $120 billion. Net profits in 2008: nearly $4 billion, up 69% from previous year as global demand for commodities soared. Company controls food from stable to table; manufactures animal feed, meat, crops. Also involved in commodities trading, risk management. Owns majority of publicly traded fertilizer firm Mosaic; stock down more than 60% since August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunge in commodity and fertilizer prices eating away at Cargill family's fortune. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, started Cargill as a grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took reins 1909. Family owns 88% of company, employees the rest. Today sales exceed $120 billion. Net profits in 2008: nearly $4 billion, up 69% from previous year as global demand for commodities soared. Company controls food from stable to table; manufactures animal feed, meat, crops. Also involved in commodities trading, risk management. Owns majority of publicly traded fertilizer firm Mosaic; stock down more than 60% since August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunge in commodity and fertilizer prices eating away at Cargill family's fortune. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, started Cargill as a grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took reins 1909. Family owns 88% of company, employees the rest. Today sales exceed $120 billion. Net profits in 2008: nearly $4 billion, up 69% from previous year as global demand for commodities soared. Company controls food from stable to table; manufactures animal feed, meat, crops. Also involved in commodities trading, risk management. Owns majority of publicly traded fertilizer firm Mosaic; stock down more than 60% since August.

name: Billionaires
bio: French-born immigrant launched online auction outfit Ebay 1995. Computer programmer handed exec control to Meg Whitman 3 years later, remains chairman. Buy-and-trade giant weathered Internet boom and bust with loyal customers; today boasts 84 million users. Shares down more than 55% in past 6 months. Blogger keeps busy giving away fortune; created Omidyar Network 2004. Despite the economic gloom, philanthropic investment firm plans to increase its total donations in 2009; finances small businesses in developing economies, donates to nonprofits.
title: Founder and Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunge in commodity and fertilizer prices eating away at Cargill family's fortune. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, started Cargill as a grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took reins 1909. Family owns 88% of company, employees the rest. Today sales exceed $120 billion. Net profits in 2008: nearly $4 billion, up 69% from previous year as global demand for commodities soared. Company controls food from stable to table; manufactures animal feed, meat, crops. Also involved in commodities trading, risk management. Owns majority of publicly traded fertilizer firm Mosaic; stock down more than 60% since August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former butcher's apprentice owns and runs $9.5 billion (sales) Anton Schlecker drugstore chain; group's 11,000 locations account for 70% of Germany's drugstores. Have  3,000 stores in Austria, Holland, Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Portugal and Eastern Europe. Faced with increased competition at home, company has started its own drug mail order and wholesale businesses.  Wife Christa and children Lars and Meike help run the business. Soccer fan. Enjoys sport cars, apparently owns a Ferrari, Aston Martin, Porsche and Jaguar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left his medical practice in South Africa to join identical twin brother, Thomas, in founding generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. Brothers eventually built Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In February 2005 sold business as well as their 68% stake of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion.   Now brothers run their  Santo Holding investment arm which invests in the German biotech sector, in particular companies involved in cancer research. Said to love sailing, golf and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With identical twin brother, Andreas, founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986., eventually building it into  Germany's second-largest generic drugmaker. In 2005 sold business and their 68% of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion.  Brothers now manage their Santo Holding investment arm which invests in the German biotech sector, in particular companies involved in cancer research. Is said to be the more extroverted of the brothers. Reportedly collects modern art and Swiss watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Used blowtorch, soldering iron and plastic tubing to develop cardiovascular catheter. Founded Cook Group from Bloomington apartment in 1963; now the world's largest privately held medical device manufacturer. Products include stents, embolization coils, needles, vena cava filters. Sales now $1.5 billion. Just completed $500 million restoration of Indiana's French Lick Resort and Casino; site of 2010 PGA Championship. At work by 5 a.m.; eats in company cafeteria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former metals trader survived Russia's gangster wars but may not withstand collapsing markets and heavy debts, which he used to fund his company UC Rusal's expansion. The country's one-time richest man, ranked no. 10 in the  world and worth $28 billion last year, bought 25% stake in Norilsk Nickel  from fellow billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov in 2008 at the top of the market;  Norilsk Nickel's stock has fallen 80% since the deal. He recently received a $4.5 billion loan from a state-controlled bank in order to keep his Norilsk Nickel stake, which faced a margin call by Western banks from which he had borrowed. Other margin calls forced him to divest a $1.5 billion stake in  Canadian carmaker Magna International and a $500 million stake in German construction company Hochtief. He also sold a large part of his construction business in Russia to fellow billionaire Suleiman Kerimov. Married to a relative of Yeltsin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy money man withdrew bid to buy controlling stake in pro football's Pittsburgh Steelers from Rooney family in September. All-cash offer reportedly valued team at more than $800 million. Attended Bowdoin U.; ditched Ph.D. in economics to become oil analyst at Pittsburgh National Bank. Founded Duquesne Capital Management 1981 with $1 million. Went to work for George Soros' Quantum Fund 7 years later. Helped hedge fund manager "break" British pound 1992; duo said to have made $1 billion in one day when currency collapsed. Left in 2000. Duquesne believed to manage more than $10 billion. Bet in July that U.S. dollar would rise against other curriencies paid off: firm's funds all reportedly returned more than 5% net of fees in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Prince of petroleum hamstrung by shrinking demand for oil; shares of his publicly traded Continental Resources down 80% since July. Net worth halved since September. Youngest of 13 children grew up poor; parents picked cotton, raised entire family in one-bedroom Oklahoma house. First job: gas station attendant. Founded Harold Hamm Tank Truck Service 1966; firm became one of the largest oilfield fluid transporters in U.S. Started oil and gas exploration, production outfit Continental 1967; public 2007. Drilling the Bakken Shale in North Dakota; company is the region's biggest leaseholder with 500,000 acres. Partner in gas processing firms Hiland Partners and Hiland Holdings. Two years ago founded the Ames Astrobleme Museum, named after the crater in Oklahoma where he found a cache of high-quality oil created in part by destruction from a meteor strike 450 million years ago.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Continental Resources', 'uri': 'companies/continental-resources', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made tycoon has built a trading empire on a par with the region's older family-owned merchant dynasties. His Dallah Albaraka group has interests in Saudi media, real estate, agriculture, shipping, tourism and finance. Got start negotiating lucrative contracting deals for the Saudi government before striking out on his own. In 2002 launched sharia-compliant Albaraka Banking Group, quickly growing the $10 billion (assets) company into overlooked Muslim finance markets across Middle East, Africa and Southeast Asia. Also owns 5-star hotel in Mecca that caters to millions of well-heeled pilgrims who pass through annually on the Hajj.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of Harvard Ph.D. program; drove New York City taxi, studied harpsichord at Juilliard. Founded hedge fund Caxton Associates 1983. Has a returned an estimated 25% a year net of fees. Assets under management: $11.5 billion. Music aficionado donated collection of 140 scores and sketches by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms to Juilliard 2006. Paid $80 million for string of beachfront properties in Santa Barbara.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother and son jointly own one of world's largest producers of roller bearings, $11.4 billion (revenues) INA Waelzlager Schaeffler KG. Maria-Elizabeth has headed the business since 1996 when her husband died, while son, Georg, practiced international business law in Dallas, Tx. Georg is now back at his mothers side helping her run the company. Made big news last year when they announced a $15 billion takeover of much larger Continental AG, one of Europe's largest tire and auto parts producers with $21 billion in sales. Now control 90% of Continental, whose shares have lost more than half their value since the takeover was announced.  Faced with almost $30 billion in debt, mother and son are scrambling to find investors and pleading with state and federal governments for a tax funded bail out.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started eponymous discount brokerage firm in two-room office 1971. Took public 1987. Deregulation of brokerage commissions, online investing craze brought the masses. Client assets: $1.1 trillion. Stock down 53% since August amid tumultuous markets. Net income in 2008 fell by 50% to $1.2 billion. Last year stepped down as chief exec, remains chairman. Company launched online trading community in 2008; first social network offered by major brokerage firm.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Charles Schwab', 'uri': 'companies/charles-schwab', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of carbide industrial cutting tool manufacturer, Iscar, sold out near top of the market in 2006 to Warren Buffettês Berkshire Hathaway, which paid $4 billion for an 80% stake; retains remaining slice with son Eitan as president. Company growth slowing as carmaker clients falter. Through his four industrial parks Wertheimer seeds high-tech Israeli startups including Blades Technology, a maker of jet-engine blades. After fleeing Nazi Germany, the high school dropout joined the Palmach, the elite strike force of the Haganah, the pre-state defense organization. Former Israeli parliament member supports joint Israeli-Palestinian businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded windmill manufacturer Enercon in 1984; reportedly built the first wind turbine in his backyard. Trained engineer probably got his inspiration close to home; grew up in windy North Germany. In 1992 Enercon began producing non-polluting windmills without gears or hydraulics. The company is the world's fourth-largest windmill producer with a 14% market share and $2.5 billion in sales. It has 14,000 wind turbines in 30 countries. Enercon now expanding from wind to water: investing in hydroelectric power plants and seawater desalination projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006). Aspiring philosopher William inherited Ziff-Davis publishing company from father 1953; parlayed into niche media conglomerate (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Three sons cashed out when family sold 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994; dad retired to Florida. Plowed proceeds into Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, real estate, corporate debt, equities. Family trust said to be worth more than $10 billion. Rumor: trusts were having their best year ever in 2008, but held long positions in oil; eventually broke even as energy prices plummeted at the end of the year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006). Aspiring philosopher William inherited Ziff-Davis publishing company from father 1953; parlayed into niche media conglomerate (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Three sons cashed out when family sold 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994; dad retired to Florida. Plowed proceeds into Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, real estate, corporate debt, equities. Family trust said to be worth more than $10 billion. Rumor: trusts were having their best year ever in 2008, but held long positions in oil; eventually broke even as energy prices plummeted at the end of the year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006). Aspiring philosopher William inherited Ziff-Davis publishing company from father 1953; parlayed into niche media conglomerate (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Three sons cashed out when family sold 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994; dad retired to Florida. Plowed proceeds into Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, real estate, corporate debt, equities. Family trust said to be worth more than $10 billion. Rumor: trusts were having their best year ever in 2008, but held long positions in oil; eventually broke even as energy prices plummeted at the end of the year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rough year for one of Sin City's richest men. "Shelly" has seen his fortune drop $22 billion in past 12 months. Shares of his Las Vegas Sands casino company have fallen more than 95% in a year as gamblers stay home in Nevada and Macau. Remains bullish: "One day our stock will trade at $100 a share again." Personally injected $1 billion of his own cash into the company to help make a debt payment last fall. Company forced to suspend construction of billion dollar casinos in Macau; laid off nearly 11,000 workers last November in China. Continuing to build $5 billion casino reort in Singapore; scheduled to open later this year. Cab driver's son borrowed $200 from uncle to sell newspapers at age 12. Created computer industry's marquee event, Comdex, mid-1980s; sold show to Japan's Softbank for $862 million 1995. Built $1.5 billion all-suites Venetian Resort Hotel Casino and the 1.2-million-square-foot Sands Convention Center 1997. Enticed conventioneers to Sin City midweek, took emphasis off gambling. Unveiled $2.4 billion Venetian Macau in China in August 2007; 10.5-million-square-foot mega-resort features 3,400 slots, 800 tables, 3,000 suites and a convention center. In 2008 opened $1.9 billion Palazzo resort next to nemesis Steve Wynn's Wynn Las Vegas. Owns Israeli newspaper Israel Today.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Las Vegas Sands', 'uri': 'companies/las-vegas-sands', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Manuel and Placido, founded Bodega Aurrera discount supermarket chain in 1958. Through Grupo Cifra, expanded into VIPS and El Porton restaurants and Suburbia clothing stores. Cifra teamed up with Wal-Mart in the early 1990s and was later bought out by the American retailer; stores renamed Wal-Mart de Mexico (known as Walmex). Deal netted Arangos more than $2 billion. Brothers also own real estate in Mexico City, Baja and Acapulco, where Jeronimo reportedly has a cliffside mansion called Marbrisa, or Sea Breeze. Placido reportedly has extensive art collection, including pieces by El Greco, Henry Moore and Goya, of which he has made donations to the Prado Museum in Spain, where he is president of the board of trustees. Manuel founded the Mexican Center for Philanthropy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over family's shoe business. Turned it into Europe's largest shoe retailer Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH, a household name throughout Europe. Also owns U.S. retail chains, Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway. Son Heinrich runs daily operations. Committed philanthropist, regularly donates large sums to missionary and humanitarian organizations, including a program to help leprosy victims in India, which he visits annually.  Awarded the Martin-Luther Foundation's "Luther Rose" award for his social and charitable work last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: The coolest man in tech stunned investors after announcing he would take a six-month leave of absence beginning January, after finding his medical situation had become "more complex." Just a week earlier he had said the condition that had forced him to lose vast amounts of weight was just a "hormone imbalance." Apple shares fell 7% in after-hours that day; they are down 50% in the past 6 months. SEC now looking into whether the company misled investors. Firm reported record quarterly sales of $10.2 billion in January as iPhone shipments soared 88% over previous year. Currently marketing 'green' MacBook Pro line of computers: energy-efficient, longer-lasting batteries; premium pricing on its products may hurt Apple as consumers cut back on spending.

name: Billionaires
bio: Internet entrepreneur runs Japan's leading online shopping mall Rakuten. Battling Amazon by expanding items available for next-day deliveries. Plans to set up web stores in 27 countries over next 4 years. Broadcasting play thwarted after other shareholders of Tokyo Broadcasting System, in which he has 20% stake, voted to adopt takeover defenses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned small cork factory started by his grandfather in 1870 into world's largest producer of cork, $600 million (sales) Corticeira Amorim; group now also has real estate and tourism interests. No longer involved in daily operations, still owns 50% of the group. Most of his fortune now comes from his extensive investments in equities, particularly in finance and energy industries; holdings include 8% stake in Banco Popular; 27.5% in investment company Finpro; 25% in bank BIC Angola; and 18% in Galp, Portugal's former state energy company. Those stocks took beating, driving his net worth down by more than half. Also has land in northern Brazil that he hopes to develop into a tourist destination. With his two brothers, has established a separate private equity fund to take advantage of financial crisis and acquire failing companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: The 8th Earl of Cadogan heads his family's 300-year-old real estate trust, which owns 90 acres in London's Chelsea. The posh neighborhood is home to luxury retailers like Jimmy Choo and Fendi as well as high-end restaurants, all hit by the recession. A meddlesome landlord, Cadogan recently told longtime tenant Oriel restaurant it would have to close after a meal there proved sub-par and overpriced (reportedly closing sometime this year). Cadogan began his career at merchant banker Schroder Wagg. Took on the management of family's property portfolio in 1974.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation head of consumer products conglomerate Godrej Group, which started out as lockmaker 112 years ago. Now it makes everything from soaps and mosquito repellents to refrigerators and foods. Group changed its logo in 2008 for first time since its founding. Bulk of fortune comes from 3,500-acre landholding in suburban Mumbai. Following easing of decades-old land ownership restrictions has lined up ambitious plans to develop family estate. Son Pirojsha, a Columbia University M.B.A., works in property arm that has built Planet Godrej, five 50-story towers in Mumbai. Counts actor Richard Gere among close friends.

name: Billionaires
bio:
One of Russia's most mysterious tycoons. Born in Bukhara, Uzbekistan, lived
in Tashkent, then graduated from local university with degree in oriental
studies. Put Arabic-language skills to use in various Soviet military
organizations in Libya and Iraq. First moves as a businessman were with
Trans-World Group, once the largest metals-trading operation in Russia. Now
the main owner of UGMK-Holding, Russia's second largest copper producer in
terms of output and the biggest piece of his fortune. With other partners,
acquired stakes in large coal companies and transport-machinery production
outfits.

name: Billionaires
bio: Banana baron has lost $1.4 billion in last 12 months; investments in food, real estate and trucking industries all hit hard. Also raising cash to pay down bonds maturing in May; sold off Dole's flowers division, JP Fresh subsidiary, European ripening and distribution business in January. High school dropout drafted into Army 1943; settled in Detroit after WWII. Bought diner with $1,800 loan; flipped quickly for small profit. Built homes in Arizona, California; survived real estate market crash. Bought slice of Dole produce outfit, Castle & Cooke real estate firm. Actively pursuing health and nutrition research since his third wife passed away from cancer in 1985. Continues to expand his $1.5 billion North Carolina Research Campus; studying biotech, disease. Appeared on Martha Stewart Show in November, reportedly slated for upcoming Oprah feature.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and retired chairman of Fubon Group. Sons Daniel, chief executive, and Richard, vice chairman, have steered the financial services firm in recent years, now into telecom and media. Its Fubon Bank won Taiwan government permission in April to buy a 19.9% stake in the Xiamen City Commercial Bank, the first time the government approved a Taiwan bank to invest in a mainland counterpart. Bought Taiwan life insurance unit of ING in February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Salesman's son dropped out of college, took to road selling plush toys. Sold first line of stuffed animals 1986. Beanie Babies hit shelves 1993; created collecting craze. Launched Beanie Babies 2.0 in 2008; Ty Girlz in 2007. This year launched dolls with same names as President Obama's daughters Sasha and Malia; quickly renamed Sydney and Mariah after controversy erupted. Today Ty Inc. has licensing deals with Nickelodeon, Wonder Pets; partnerships with Paramount. Plowed profits into real estate. Owns Four Seasons hotel in New York, home of most expensive suite ever built in the U.S. Price: $30,000 a night. Developing Connoisseur Club; membership will allow access to Four Seasons and all Warner's resorts in California, Mexico. In September, reportedly bought penthouse in planned mega-skyscraper Chicago Spire. Asking price: $40 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded JCDecaux outdoor advertising company in 1964. Started out putting ads on "street furniture" such as public toilets and bus shelters. Now places advertising in airports, malls, subways and billboards in almost 50 countries. Company is China's top outdoor advertising firm. Leading provider of eco-friendly transportation in big cities, including bicycles for hire that can be dropped off at self-service docking stations. Touts its greenness: places recycling bins for batteries, glass or other waste near its street furniture. Decaux remains chairman of the $2.7 billion (sales) company; sons Jean-Francois and Jean-Charles are co-chief executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began building his empire in 1990 when, with partner Vitaly Malkin, he set up Rossiysky Kredit Bank. It is still his biggest holding. Over the years, sold other businesses he accumulated during country's privatization era and invested proceeds in Russian stock market.  Also has interests in hotels; a Russian chain of drugstores called Doctor Stoletov. Redeveloping a former factory in downtown Moscow into a deluxe housing development, the first blocks of which are supposed to be completed by 2011 or 2012.  Deutsche Bank was reportedly going to acquire a 10% stake in the project for $115 million in October 2008, but the deal fell through due to the much changed economic conditions.  Was the subject of some interest in the art world following his reported auction purchases of works by Picasso and the contemporary artist Peter Doig for prices well above their estimates.  Now lives in the Georgian village of Chorvila, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: Quit job as Enron president 1996; uneasy with 'asset light' approach. Formed pipeline firm Kinder Morgan with college buddy William Morgan. Purchased Enron pipeline business; added more pipes from ExxonMobil, ConocoPhillips, Shell. Picked up Terasen for $5.6 billion 2005. Now controls 37,000 miles of pipe, 165 terminals. Took company private in 2007 for $22 billion with investor Fayez Sarofim, Goldman Sachs. Changed name to Knight Inc. Owns 31%; Kinder Morgan Energy Partners remains public. Fortune has dwindled $300 million in past 6 months; value of pipeline assets have held up compared to other parts of the energy sector.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kinder Morgan', 'uri': 'companies/kinder-morgan', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former lawyer borrowed $300 from wife to start real estate developer Lerner Enterprises in 1952. Made fortune building massive shopping malls in the suburbs of Washington, D.C.: Tysons Corner, Tysons II, Wheaton Plaza, Landover Mall, Dulles Town Center, White Flint. Today owns 20 million square feet of commercial, retail space and 7,000 apartments. Also owns stake in NYC's Chelsea Piers. Moved headquarters to a new 'green' building in Maryland last October. Owns pro baseball's Washington Nationals and small stake in regional broadcaster Mid-Atlantic Sports Network. Opened $600 million Nationals Park last season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nephew of late Forbes 400 member Max Fisher (d. 2005) started out as a tax lawyer, founded real estate developer Related Cos 1972. Initially focused on building, financing low-income housing; branched into riskier luxury buildings in New York. Net worth down $1.3 billion in 6 months as real estate market slumps. First "encountered bad times" early 1990s, recovered. Related has developed more than $16 billion of property across the U.S., including Time Warner Center in Manhattan. Nabbed billion-dollar deal to develop Manhattan's West Side rail yards last May after Tishman Speyer abandoned the project; now postponed for a year because of the recession, frozen credit markets. Says he's still committed to the project; Related to eventually develop 12 million square feet of office, residential and retail space. Completed purchase of pro football's Miami Dolphins in January; paid longtime owner Wayne Huizenga $1.1 billion for the team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turbulent markets rocking venerable Chicago investor and his family fortune. Shares of General Dynamics down 55% in the past 12 months; fortune off more than 30% since last March. Financier father, Henry Crown, founded sand, stone and gravel firm with 2 brothers 1919. Material Service Corp. Firm became world's largest building materials distributor. Merged with General Dynamics 1959. Father died 1980. Fortune transferred to son Lester, who loaded cement trucks before joining dad's operation. Became chairman of General Dynamics 1983. Diversified family's fortune; today owns stakes in General Dynamics, Maytag, Alltel, JPMorgan Chase, Hilton Hotels, Rockefeller Center, basketball's Chicago Bulls, baseball's New York Yankees. Longtime Democrat raised money for Obama.

name: Billionaires
bio: Banker sold most of his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. With remaining assets built Banco Alfa, now Brazil's 16th-largest bank. Also owns Agropalma, Latin America's largest palm oil producer (now moving into biodiesel), and C&C, a chain of home improvement stores. Trained as a doctor and practiced medicine for 2 years. When his father died suddenly, Faria took his place running Banco Real.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father opened Rimi discount supermarket in the late 1970s, later partnering with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket giant Royal Ahold. In 2004 Hagen exercised an option to sell his remaining 20% stake in the venture, forcing Ahold to pony up $1 billion. Bought into department store chain Steen & Strom, then took the whole thing private in late 2007. Board chairman of consumer goods company Orkla, which has seen share price drop 25% over past year. Also invests in real estate and local companies through his Canica group. In January, announced launch of Norwegian private equity fund, Indo-Nordic Equity AS, together with Indian ambassador Mahesh Sachdev, which will invest $75 million in India's energy sector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former real estate executive made billions giving folks a place to stash their stuff. Started storage outfit in 1972 after coming across a full warehouse. Original name, "Private Storage," drove customers away; "Public Storage" brought the masses. Publicly-traded firm now largest self-storage company in world; 2,100 locations, 135 million square feet of rentable space in U.S. and Europe. Stock down nearly 40% in the past 12 months. Owns Thoroughbred horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Over the last year Kerimov has sold nearly all his Russian assets, including shares in Gazprom, government-owned Sberbank and a massive  housing development in suburban Moscow. The money allowed him to settle his debts and also to purchase stakes in a few European banks including Royal Bank of Scotland and Fortis, which have since seen the price of their shares collapse in just a few months. In December, bought large stake in Russia’s largest gold mining outfit, Polyus Gold, now his most valuable holding. In autumn 2006 was seriously injured in car accident after losing control of a Ferrari Enzo on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice. Recovery was prolonged and painful.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kremlin connections helped conglomerate Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires German Khan and Mikhail Fridman bail out distressed assets: when shares in mobile operator Vimpelcom were halved last fall, Deutsche Bank requested an early repayment of its $2 billion loan against which the shares were pledged; state owned Vnesheconombank put up funds to guarantee the loan. Though their 44% stake is safe for now; Vimpelcom stock keeps falling, down another 12% since its October low. Investment in oil giant faring no better; shares in TNK-BP down 63% over past year. An eight month power struggle at TNK-BP resolved when chief executive was removed and new management put in place; former German chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder, who has ties with Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, joining board. Came to Moscow to study, with college buddies Kahn and Fridman started commodities trader, Alfa-Eco, in 1989. Merged oil assets with BP in 2003. Now focusing on telecom; Kuzmichev leading latest negotiations in Nigeria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paid $100 million in cash last May to buy a house in Palm Beach, Fla. from U.S. billionaire Donald Trump. Made his fortune in fertilizer; entered the business in 1990, after studying medicine at the Perm Medical Institute. In 1995, named chairman of the board of Uralkali, Russia&#39s largest producer of potassium fertilizers, founded by the Soviets in the 1930s. In 2007 listed the company in London, raising $1 billion; by February 2008, he was worth $12.8 billion. Fertilizer market came to halt late last year, pushing down Uralkali’s stock. An additional headache for Rybolovlev is the Russian  government, which has demanded payment of a massive fine in connection with a 2006 disaster that ruined fertilizer fields.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met James Goodnight at North Carolina State. Started SAS 1976, now largest privately held software company in the world. Firm develops business intelligence software, databases. Major clients include banks, pharmaceutical companies. Record sales of $2.3 billion last year, up 5% over 2007. Still, software industry isn't immune to economic slump; publicly-traded competitors' stocks down more than 30% on average. SAS provides workers with free snacks and drinks, onsite health care, subsidized child care. Statistics wizard Sall runs dynamic data visualization software division.
title: Co-Founder, Executive Vice President
employment: {'name': 'SAS Institute', 'title': 'Co-Founder, Executive Vice President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Orascom conglomerate founder and fellow billionaire, Onsi Sawiris. Took over leadership of empire's flagship construction and fertilizer division in 1998; Orascom Construction shares tumbled 80% over past year. Chief still bullish, projecting 50% increase in group revenues from projects in Gulf and North Africa; company also sitting on $1 billion cash war chest. Spun off group's cement division 2 years ago to French giant LaFarge, landing Nassef a seat on the board and a 13% stake. University of Chicago grad launched boardroom battle last October at U.S. cement supplier Texas Industries, in which he holds 15% stake; succeeded in rallying shareholders to pass no-confidence votes against 2 board members to protest company's poor performance, no one was ousted. Asking for board seat and chance to increase stake to 25%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall magnate responsible for bringing indoor skiing to Dubai's deserts presides over retail real estate spanning the Middle East from Egypt to Oman. Took control of family's mall assets in 2000 after splitting with brother, auto tycoon and fellow billionaire Abdulla Al Futtaim. His 6.5 million-square-foot Mall of the Emirates hosts 2 million visitors a month and has helped put Dubai on the map as a shopper's paradise. Long-term tenant contracts help keep occupancy rates near capacity despite the region's economic downturn. Also operates Carrefour brand of supermarkets throughout Middle East. Continues to invest: working with Omani government to build the country's first luxury residential development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grocer's son bought up 7% stake in Whole Foods in December; shares up 27% since. Joined union local as a box boy at age 13. Founded investment company Yucaipa 1986; made fortune buying and selling supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen's, Ralph's. Loves labor: looks to friendly union leaders to bring him deals. Advised Dow Jones' union during company's negotiations with Rupert Murdoch over sale of Wall Street Journal, other assets to News Corp. Former President Bill Clinton became Yucaipa adviser 2001, reportedly cashed out for as much as $20 million last year as Hillary ran for President.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'The Yucaipa Companies, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of apartment managers ran Wyoming hotel and gas station. Bought 10% share in business; expanded to Utah, Arizona. Purchased Sinclair Oil 1976. Now owns 3 refineries, 1,000 miles of pipeline, 2,600 filling stations. Sold Barnett Shale natural gas acreage to Chesapeake Energy for $300 million in 2006. Drilling in North Dakota's Bakken Shale. Planning $1 billion expansion of Tulsa refinery; will increase capacity from 70,000 barrels per day to 115,000 by 2010. Agreed to pay $2.5 million fine, make $72 million in antipollution upgrades at 3 refineries. Fortune has fallen $1.6 billion in past six months amid difficult environment for oil refiners. Owns Snowbasin, Utah and Sun Valley, Idaho resorts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparently met Helmut Horten, founder of eponomyous German department store chain,in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was 19-years-old. Despite 30-year age difference, they wed 7 years later. He died in 1987 and left her an estimated $1 billion fortune.  Austria's merry widow now divides her time between a penthouse in Vienna, a residence in Tessin, Switzerland, and a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. Owns one of world's largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII. Rumored to have sold a 35.5 carat diamond, once part of the crown of Bavaria, for $24 million at Christie's auction in December. Said to enjoy hunting and collecting art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of buyout firm KKR forced to reconsider plans to go public via merger with European affiliate as markets freeze. Shares of Amsterdam-listed KKR Private Equity Investors down 80% since late August. Firm manages $60 billion. Annual gross returns through July 2008: 26.1%. Created firm 1976. Used junk bonds to buy underperforming companies, streamline operations, flip for profit. Most famous for $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco 1989. Owns massive art collection.
title: Co-Chair and Co-CEO
employment: {'name': 'KKR and Co', 'title': 'Co-Chair and Co-CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: U.S. real estate collapse bruising Kroenke's personal balance sheet; sports teams holding value. Made first fortune developing commercial and retail properties. Holdings include 5 ranches covering 1.5 million acres, shopping centers, office properties. Sports nut owns pro basketball's Denver Nuggets, hockey's Colorado Avalanche; both play at his Pepsi Center. Also owns stake in pro football's St. Louis Rams, English soccer titan Arsenal. Wife--and fellow billionaire--Ann inherited chunk of Wal-Mart stock after father James (Bud) Walton's death in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stepped down last year as chairman of $174 billion (sales) Samsung Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, after 2 decades at the helm. Credited with turning sleepy conglomerate into one of the world's most recognizable, high-quality electronics brands. Last year tumultuous for Lee: the Seoul High Court sentenced him to 3-year suspended jail term for tax evasion and slapped him with $80 million penalty. The ruling is being appealed. Paid $130 million in overdue taxes May 2008. His stake in Samsung Life Insurance was revealed to be 4 times greater than previously reported, bumping up his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: With $120 in savings, he and 3 brothers got start raising quail, chickens in 1982. Their Hope Group became one of China's largest makers of animal feed. Siblings split in 1995; Yongxing moved to Shanghai. His privately held East Hope Group is still one of China's biggest feed producers, making 100 types; core feed business has done well amid rising demand for meat in China as household incomes rise. Company is looking to expand in southern Vietnam. Also owns aluminum smelters and is investing in the plastics industry in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Executive producer of Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull; film grossed $782 million in worldwide box office in 2008. Along with pal Steven Spielberg and actor Harrison Ford, Lucas took no cash up front, didn't see any profits until the film made $400 million. Star Wars and its 5 sequels earned a combined $4.3 billion in worldwide box office (not adjusting for inflation). Toys, other merchandise have grossed another $13.5 billion. CG-animation film Star Wars: The Clone Wars released last summer. Founded Industrial Light & Magic in 1975 to create effects for original Star Wars; now Hollywood's most bankable special-effects shop. Foundation donated $175 million to USC film school 2006. Big Obama supporter awarded a Lincoln Medal for his work in education in February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Orascom conglomerate founder and fellow billionaire Onsi Sawiris. Heads up Orascom Telecom, one of largest mobile providers in Middle East, Africa and South Asia. Telecom tycoon's insatiable risk appetite backfiring; his personal fund, Weather Investments, saddled with $7.7 billion in debt from leveraged buyouts of Italian phone company Wind and leading Greek telecom companies Wind Hellas and Tellas three years ago. Sold 10% of fund to trio of private equity players for $1 billion last year to pay down debt. Not slowing down: in December paid a visit to Kim Jong Il to sign license agreement granting Orascom exclusive access to North Korea's cell phone market; first mobile company to invest in the pariah state.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Sun Pharma, India’s most valuable drugmaker, which he founded 26 years ago as a maker of psychiatric drugs in Kolkata. Expanded portfolio to include generic drugs for chronic diseases.  Took Sun public in 1994, then started buying ailing companies that he turned around. Company’s 2007 bid to acquire Israel’s Taro Pharma, a generic drugs maker, for $454 million is stuck in court following Taro’s decision to back out of the deal last year. Efforts to reach out-of-court settlement ongoing. Sun’s stock has held steady in a market that’s down 43% in past year. Still close to his college buddies. Has a portrait of his family deity in all Sun’s offices and factories.

name: Billionaires
bio: U. of Santa Clara student began career selling residential property; later moved into commercial real estate. Today Sobrato Development owns and manages 7.7 million square feet of commercial office space, 7,400 residential units, 350 vacant acres in Silicon Valley. Took advantage of growing tech companies' demand for prime real estate; collected higher rents. Biggest clients: Apple and Yahoo. Family foundation donated more than $300 million over last decade. Set up Sobrato Center for Non-Profits, offering rent-free office space to 30 non-profit agencies including YWCA, homeless shelter provider EHC Lifebuilders.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Big year on the big screen for Hollywood's most beloved director. Fourth installment of Indiana Jones franchise grossed $786 million worldwide. Was so confident that he didn't take his cut of the profits until the movie had made $400 million. In June his Dreamworks SKG stuck $1.5 billion agreement to start new film company with India's Reliance ADA Group; in February left Universal and signed distributing deal with Walt Disney Studios. Film school reject's third movie, "Jaws," started unmatched string of blockbusters ("E.T.," "Jurassic Park") and dramas ("Schindler's List," "Saving Private Ryan"). Produced first game for Electronic Arts last summer. Next up: The Adventures of Tintin and an Abraham Lincoln biopic. Charitable organization roughed up in Madoff scandal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow and her children control one of Brazil's largest steelmakers, Companhia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN). The Steinbruch and Rabinovitch families, through their Vicunha Textile, paid a reported $800 million in 1993 for control of CSN, a formerly state-owned steel company. In 2005 Steinbruch bought out the Rabinovitch stake for a reported $588 million. Her brother-in-law Eliezer Steinbruch, who shared control of CSN, died in mid-2008. She is not involved in running the business; son Benjamin serves as CSN's chairman and chief executive. The company layed off workers in recent months as the Brazilian economy slowed and demand from automakers fell. Her net worth dropped significantly due to CSN shares plunging by nearly 40% since last year and a much weaker Brazilian currency. The family also owns Banco Fibra.

name: Billionaires
bio: In late 1980s, acquired over 100-year-old  Knorr-Bremse AG and transformed it into world's leading manufacturer of braking systems for rail and commercial vehicles. The $4.5 billion (sales) group is a big player in China where it has five joint ventures and its own production plant.  Chairman of supervisory  board; said to  enjoy hiking, skiing and animal photography.  Has received various awards for his philanthropic contributions including his support of children cancer research and his aid to underdeveloped countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: The grave dancer meets "the deal from hell." Took control of Tribune Co. in December 2007 in $8.2 billion deal done with media giant's employees. Colossal debt, massive declines in ad revenue forced firm into bankruptcy in December. Firm sold majority interest in New York tabloid Newsday to Cablevision last April for $650 million. Agreed to sell pro baseball's Chicago Cubs and Wrigley Field to Ricketts family in January for $900 million. Made first fortune buying and selling cheap real estate from distressed owners with partner Robert Lurie (d. 1990). Sold Equity Office Properties to Stephen Schwarzman's Blackstone Group for $39 billion cash in 2007. Great timing: many of the buildings in the deal are now worth less than their mortgages. Still owns stakes in Equity Residential and Equity Lifestyle REITs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Choppy waters continue to wash away the fortune of the world's largest cruise ship operator. Carnival Corp. stock down 56% since September as recession-conscious tourists traded "fun ships" for "stay-cations." Today operates 89 ships under 11 brands, including Carnival, Princess, Holland America, Costa Cruises, Cunard Line. New mega-ship, Carnival "Dream," scheduled for maiden voyage this year. Owns pro basketball's Miami Heat.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Oldest son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri runs his real estate and private banking business from Geneva. Sold stake he inherited in family construction empire, Saudi Oger, to younger brother and fellow billionaire Saad in January 2008. His Horizon Developments focuses on commercial projects in Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Lebanon, markets that have been relatively cushioned from the global property meltdown. Major stakeholder in Abdali, a 20-million-square-foot mixed-use revitalization project in downtown Amman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard business school graduate pursued banking career; founded Turkish bank Finansbank in 1987. Sold 46% of the entity to National Bank of Greece for $2.76 billion in 2006 and remaining 9% stake for $700 million last year.
