Retail businesses expanding with new Gap and Banana Republic franchises in Russia. His private Ozyegin University enrolled its first students fall 2008. Calling for Turkish government to create a $30 billion support fund for Turkish industrialists.

name: Billionaires
bio: Uncle to Mashreq chairman and fellow billionaire Abdul Aziz, Saif oversees Al Ghurair Group, one of Dubai's oldest family empires; its post office box is number 1. Investments include steel, aluminum and the nation's toniest shopping centers. His 5 sons actively involved in the business; son Majed is chief executive and head of Dubai Shopping Malls Group. Planning massive promotional campaign to get customers shopping: "We cannot stand still and let the downturn hit us."

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparel maker is designer to the stars, dressing more than 10 celebrities for the Oscars in February, including best-actor winner Sean Penn and best-actress nominee Anne Hathaway. Also makes perfume, baby clothes, home decor and 5-figure watches. Recently opened 43,000-square-foot megastore on Manhattan's famous Fifth Avenue. Has licensed his name for a string of hotels; Armani Hotel Dubai is slated to open in fall 2009. Spent 2 years in medical school at the University of Bologna before dropping out in 1957 to take a job as a department store buyer. Presented with award by France's Legion of Honor in summer 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Revered voice among Brazilian business chairs family-owned conglomerate Grupo Votorantim, whose activities span steel, finance, cement and pulp and paper. The group celebrated its 90th year in 2008. His net worth plunged more than $7 billion since 2008 as commodities prices fell and the Brazilian real weakened. Votorantim also announced it lost $1 billion in late 2008 due to a bad bet on currency derivatives, but said its cash holdings would cover the loss. Antonio still pens a weekly column for Sao Paulo newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Wolfgang, inherited a fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Helped push out brother Gunter and sister Daniela in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud. Now holds 34% stake in $12 billion (sales) Maxingvest AG, formerly called Tchibo, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, Tchibo. Group also has 50% stake in Beiersdorf AG, which makes Nivea skin care products.  Michael is a managing director of the holding, Wolfgang is on the supervisory board. Brother Joachim, who had threatened to sue Michael and Wolfgang over alleged improprieties in the buyout to Daniela and Gunter, died last May after being  hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake. Left his share of the family fortune to a charitable foundation

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Michael (all billionaire), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Now holds 34% stake in $12 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, now Maxingvest AG, makers of Tchibo, a well-known German coffee brand. Group also has 50 % stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. Michaelis a managing director of the holding; Wolfgang sits on the supervisory board. Brother Joachim, who had threatened to sue Michael and Wolfgang over alleged improprieties in the buyout to Daniela and Gunter, died last May after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake and left his share of the fortune to a charitable foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund tycoon grazed by market turmoil: flagship fund believed to be down 5% last year; "Tensor" fund rose 36%. Parted ways with longtime partner James Palotta in January. Launched hedge fund 1980. Returned 125% net of fees in 1987 betting that market would crash. Annual returns said to exceed 22% net of fees. Tudor Investment's assets under management in the fall: $18 billion. Today he manages $10.5 billion (decline partly due to split with former partner). Hunts, fishes on private estate in Zimbabwe. Founder of poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation; annual benefit raised $56.5 million in one night last May.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Turkcell mobile phone company, which is the only Turkish ADR to trade on the NYSE. His Aksam media group this winter fueled the ire of Turkish prime minister Recep Erdogan with a story on the increase of pollution resulting from free coal distribution. But the British-schooled entrepreneur has endured trials before: in the past few years repaid more than $3 billion of debt accumulated at 2 of his banks, Pamukbank and Yapi Kredi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Clothing connoisseur has seen his fortune falter $1.7 billion in the past six month as "recessionista" shoppers shun luxury fashions; Polo Ralph Lauren shares down more than 57% since since September. Bronx native worked first job at Brooks Brothers, left business school to design ties for Beau Brummel 1967. Launched Polo later that year with $50,000. Sold 28% of company to Goldman Sachs in 1994 for $138 million; took public 3 years later. Today classic designs span men's and women's clothing, luggage, furniture, fragrances; now launching first line of line of watches with Compagnie Financiere Richemont. Collects European cars, including Bugatti, Bentley, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, Porsche; assortment displayed at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts in 2005.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ralph Lauren', 'uri': 'companies/ralph-lauren', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Israel's richest woman inherited 2 of the country's largest companies: $75 billion (assets) Bank Hapoalim and infrastructure behemoth Housing & Construction. Stake in late father's cruise operator Carnival down 50% since last February, rumored to want to sell off position. Last September via Arison Holdings formally launched Miya, a $100 million venture dedicated to reducing leaks in underground water pipes. Calls project her commitment to invest in "businesses that bring added value to the world." Founded Essence of Life in 2001, a nonprofit that works "to create inner peace" via workshops and lectures.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest American billionaire keeps getting richer. Wunderkind's Centaurus Energy hedge fund said to be up 80% in 2008. Energy trader diversifying into hard assets: power plants, storage facilities. Father was a lawyer, mother an accountant. Raised in Dallas, graduated in 3 years from Vanderbilt U. Became an oil trader at Enron in 1995; said to have generated $750 million of the firm's profits in 2001. Founded Centaurus on heels of Enron's bankruptcy. Returns said to exceed 200% a year since 2002.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers control 19% of Bouygues Group, diversified industrial conglomerate founded by their father in 1952. Martin is chairman and chief executive; Olivier is deputy chief executive. Company derives 40% of its $39 billion in sales outside of France; has interests in telecom, media, construction. Well-known projects have included the Hassan II mosque in Casablanca, Morocco; the University of Riyadh in Saudi Arabia; the English Channel Tunnel; the Kwun Tong viaduct in Hong Kong; motorways in Hungary and the Sydney CityRail airport link. Martin is a close confident of French President Nicolas Sarkozy and godfather of the president's son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swiss citizen made his fortune in U.S. tech company CA, formerly Computer Associates, an IT software maker. Haefner's 24% stake in the company can be traced back to 1968 when he sold his data processing business to University Computing, which was later acquired by Computer Associates. Company shares outperformed stock market in past year, down 17%. Back home in Switzerland, his Automobil-und Motoren AG (AMAG) is the country's biggest importer of Volkswagen, Seat, Skoda and Audi. His Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland has approximately 100 horses and has bred such winners as Simple Exchange and Media Puzzle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father's dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. Decade ago, sold his stake in GEA to MG Technologies for $1 billion in cash and 21% interest in combined group. Cashed out rest In March 2006 selling stake to various institutional investors for approximately $630 million.  Holds stake in  Conergy AG, a European supplier of wind and solar energy. Runs financial consulting firm, Luserve AG, from Switzerland, where he lives with his wife and six children. Enthusiastic sailor, owns yacht named Hetairos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nonexecutive chairperson of steel and power conglomerate O.P. Jindal group, named after her late husband who died in a 2005 helicopter crash. Sons Prithviraj, Sajjan, Ratan and Navin have carved up empire to run operations. In bid to secure supplies for its steel plants, group acquired iron ore mines in Chile, Bolivia. Also won oil exploration blocks in Peru. Amid falling steel prices, JSW Steel, led by Sajjan, recently added 3 million tonnes of new steel capacity to become country’s largest steel maker in private sector. Fortune is down $5.5 billion in past year. Navin is a member of parliament.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former plantation field supervisor now heads IOI Group, one of world's leading operators of palm oil plantations, refineries. His plants produce specialty oils, metallic stearates, fats used in soaps, detergents, cosmetics, food additives. Making inroads into Indonesian palm oil estates thanks to a 2007 joint venture with that country's Harita Group. In early February IOI proposed taking its 76%-owned IOI Properties private; IOI Properties is a leading real estate developer involved in building townships, shopping, malls, resorts in Malaysia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and executive chairman of one of world's biggest shopping mall chains, Westfield. Owns 119 malls in Australia, New Zealand, the U.S. and Britain. In October, opened a $2.4 billion mall in central London.  Hit by economic downturn; in January, Westfield announced dividend cut and $3 billion writedown of assets, sending stock tumbling.  Raised $1.9 billion in February. Czech-born Lowy moved to Hungary, then Palestine, arrived in Sydney in 1952 and opened a delicatessen. His three sons, David, Peter and Steven, work in the business. Named in a U.S. Senate investigation into tax havens like Liechtenstein; denied he or his family had ever hid money in offshore banks.  President of Football Federation Australia, sold his stake in Sydney FC team last year to avoid conflict of interest and is now leading Australia's bid to host 2018 World Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: Long family history in the construction industry: great-grandfather owned a brick factory and grandfather was in cement. Father Max divvied up his estate in 1984; while brother Stephen, also a billionaire, got construction company Eternit, Thomas was given Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement and concrete. Ran it for almost 2 decades; stepped down as chairman in 2003; still has a seat on the board and holds 20% stake. Construction downturn crushed company shares, which are down by half in past year. Wine connoisseur owns vineyards in Argentina, Australia, California and Switzerland; the Swiss vineyard is situated in Balgach, the town where he was born. Honorary Consul-General of the Republic of Cyprus in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: The richest man in the Philippines arrived there at age 13 from China to help out at father's small convenience store. Saved to start a small shoe store in Manila and built it into one of the country's largest retailers. Now controls the Philippines' largest shopping mall developer, SM Prime Holdings, which opened its 31st mall last year, run by son Hans Sy; country's largest bank, Banco de Oro Unibank, run by daughter Teresita Sy-Coson. Shares fortune, which includes stakes in a dozen companies with wife and children. Last year bought a 60% stake in Manila's National University for an undisclosed sum. In December family's SM Investment Corp. announced plans to start building casinos in Manila.

name: Billionaires
bio: Who cares if her ratings are down a bit? The Queen of All Media&#39s brand is holding its value despite the worldwide recession as viewers remain endlessly riveted by her money-saving tips, celebrity interviews and relatable weight issues. Rural Mississippi native worked TV news circuit in Nashville, Baltimore. Turned faltering Chicago morning program into much-loved talk show. Nationally launched The Oprah Winfrey Show in 1986; now airs in 144 countries, brings in 44 million US viewers each week. Her production company Harpo produces Dr. Phil, Rachael Ray; adding show hosted by frequent guest Dr. Oz. Starting the Oprah Winfrey Network with Discovery; launch set for late 2009 or early 2010. Harpo Films just inked cable deal with HBO after 15 years at ABC. Foundation recently donated to schools in Newark, Atlanta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese-literature major got start in air-conditioning wholesale market in his native Nanjing 1990. Soon shifted to retail. His Suning Appliance, rival of former billionaire Wong Kwong Yu's Gome, now has $5.5 billion in sales. Despite slowing Chinese economic growth, plans to hire 36,000 people this year, bringing total number of employees up to the more than 100,000. His elder brother, property developer Zhang Guiping, is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded retailer Metro AG in 1964.  Metro now has $85 billion in sales. Beisheim still owns some 19% of the publicly traded company.  Also manages Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, which invests in internet and technology companies. In Berlin, owns Beisheim Center, a high-end complex with apartments, office buildings, two five star hotels, shops and cafes. Widower with no children, he has homes in Switzerland, Paris and Germanyês Rottach-Eggern. Sports fan supports several foundations that mainly fund athletic programs

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father's one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; eventually built it into Power Corp., a $29 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant; stock down more than a third over the past year. Company owns Montreal daily La Presse as well as 6 other newspapers in Quebec and Ontario. It also controls Power Financial, which includes life insurer Great-West Lifeco and Investors Group, the largest mutual fund company in Canada. Desmarais' son, Paul Junior, and Paul Junior's brother, Andre, share the chairmanship of Power Corp.; at 82, dad remains active as chairman of Power Corp.'s executive committee. Desmarais Sr. collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec. Family is friends with French President Nicolas Sarkozy, who in a 2008 speech said he is president thanks, in part, to Desmarais' friendship, advice and loyalty.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish immigrant wed Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson; inherited 36 million J&J shares when he passed away in 1983. Stock down 33% since September. Waged bitter battle with stepchildren over late husband's estate in 1986; incurred $17 million in legal bills. Converted Princeton, N.J. estate Jasna Polana into lavish golf course in 1996. Now travels around Europe. Renaissance, Baroque art collector recently sold Gentileschi painting at Christie's for $5 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited chunk of Wal-Mart stock after father James (Bud) Walton's death 1995; stock flat in past 12 months. Husband Stan made first fortune developing commercial and retail properties, later moved into sports: owns pro basketball's Denver Nuggets, hockey's Colorado Avalanche, plus stakes in football's St. Louis Rams and English soccer titan Arsenal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of Grupo Mexico, mining company that his late father founded, that also includes Mexico's largest railroad company, Ferromex, and subsidiary, Southern Copper. Grupo Mexico has taken a lashing from falling commodity prices and accidents, including the Pasta de Conchos mine disaster in 2006 that killed 60 miners. Its Cananea Mine, one of the largest open-pit copper mines in Mexico, has been on strike since July 2007. Ongoing legal dispute: Grupo Mexico bought smelter Asarco in 1999, filed for bankruptcy protection in 2005. Two years later Asarco sued Grupo subsidiary Americas Mining Corp., alleging it had cherry-picked prized assets from cash-starved Asarco. The courts ruled in its favor in August; parties awaiting decision on amount to be awarded to Asarco. In 2008 bought movie theater chain Cinemex.

name: Billionaires
bio: Best known for his tour outfit Globus, founded by father Antonio in 1928 with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano. Today Sergio owns a portfolio of lakeside property there. Globus tours escort travelers seeking guided tours of Europe, Africa and Asia. Bulk of wealth comes from family investments kept in bonds, which helped safeguard fortune from global recession. Says he doesn't invest in equity markets. Also owns several charter airline businesses. Loves expensive toys: has a helicopter, a Falcon private jet, a yacht (Lady Marina) and a $600,000 Mercedes Maybach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped then husband Amancio Ortega make dressing gowns and lingerie in their home. Home business became one of world's most successful apparel manufacturers, Inditex, which also owns Zara retail stores. Couple divorced years ago, but Mera still holds 7% stake in now $12 .3 billion (sales) business. At time of Inditex's public offering also got $600 million in cash, which she's invested  in a Spanish film production outfit, a marine fish farming group, a company that looks for cancer treatments in compounds found in the sea, and a maker of a fingerprinting identification system for newborns. Has received various awards for her contributions to Spanish society via her Paideia Foundation, which helps people with physical and mental disabilities.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied chemistry at UC, Berkeley, earned Ph.D. from Caltech. Cofounded Intel 1968; ignited PC revolution. Created Moore's Law: computing power will double every 18 months (later updated to 2 years). Today Intel microchips found in desktops, laptops, cell phones, digital cameras, GPS navigators. Shares down 45% since August 2008. Company working with Facebook to upgrade social networking outfit's data servers. Has donated $5 billion worth of shares to Gordon & Betty Moore Foundation since 2000. Foundation doles out $200 million annually; supports biodiversity preservation, space exploration, Caltech.
title: Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Intel', 'uri': 'companies/intel', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Leapfrogs onetime partner and fellow billionaire Rinat Akhmetov to take the top spot as Ukraine's richest. Sold his Ukrsotsbank last year at top of the market to Italy's UniCredit Group for $2.2 billion. Invested cash in real estate, including property on Sardinia's Costa Smeralda and a $160 million London home, and added to multimillion-dollar art collection that includes works by Damian Hirst, Jeff Koons and Andreas Gursky. Spreading the wealth: invited Paul McCartney to give a free concert in Kiev's independence square before a crowd of 500,000 last June. Meanwhile, value of remaining asset, steep pipe maker, Interpipe, has fallen 70% as demand dries up. Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma used his Ph.D. in pipe design to found Interpipe in 1990. His $25 million (2008 budget) foundation is active in health, education, culture, human rights and promoting Ukraine internationally.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of buyout firm KKR forced to reconsider plans to go public via merger with European affiliate as markets freeze. Shares of Amsterdam-listed KKR Private Equity Investors down 80% since late August. Firm manages $60 billion. Annual gross returns through July 2008: 26.1%. Created firm 1976. Used junk bonds to buy underperforming companies, streamline operations, flip for profit. Most famous for $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco 1989.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers own almost 16% of retailer Metro. Also own Travel Charm, a chain of 12 luxury hotels and spas located in Germany, Austria and Italy. Fund the  Mercator Foundation which helps immigrant children in Germany improve their language and professional skills through  extracurricular study programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: In surprising move, brothers sold their stake in generics maker Ranbaxy Laboratories, founded by their grandfather in 1961, to Japan’s Daiichi Sankyo, for $2 billion last year. Stock tanked after the sale and is currently trading more than two-thirds below deal price. Fall attributed to U.S. ban of 30 Ranbaxy drugs after discovery that 2 of its Indian factories didn’t meet FDA standards.  In February, the FDA halted drug aplications from one factory altogether for having allegedly falsified data and test results. Company has retained former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani as adviser on this matter. Older brother Malvinder continues to run company as chairman and chief executive. Younger sibling Shivinder, who oversees family’s interest in health care services, recently acquired stake in a hospital in Mauritius. Brothers are both Duke University grads. Malvinder is a keen photographer and art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Introduced his family company's rice crackers to China in 1990s; now Want Want Holdings, which he heads, is one of China's most popular food brands. Boosted fortune in past year by briefly taking Singapore-traded Want Want private in 2007, spinning off noncore hospital, hotel and property businesses, and then relisting in Hong Kong in March 2008 under the name of Want Want China Holdings. Also expanding in hotels. Son Tsai Shao-Chung and nephew Cheng Wen-Hsien are board members. Expanding into new businesses with investment in Hong Kong broadcaster ATV and purchase of China Times in Taiwan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Wheelock & Co., which owns landmarks like Hong Kong's Times Square and Harbour City; also has shipping interests. Holds advisory posts at JPMorgan Chase and General Electric. Became chair of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, which had made him the de facto trade ambassador, in 2000; gave up the post 7 years ago. Considered possible candidate for city's chief executive in 2012; lost race 1996. Daughter Jennifer leads family's Hong Kong luxury retailer Lane Crawford.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former tailor and China's richest newcomer made his fortune selling fashion to the masses. His trendy retailer, Metersbonwe, targets the 18-to-25-year-old set, hires pop stars as spokespeople and launches 3,000 designs in a year. Opened first store in 1995; now has 2,600 stores and 9,000 employees. Took company public last August in one of China's most successful public offerings of the year, raising $200 million. Stock up 28% since; Zhou and his daughter still own 90% of the company. Opened Metersbonwe Costume Museum in 2005; contains more than 8,000 pieces from the Ming Dynasty up to 1930s Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: The credit crisis is punishing the construction and private equity markets, and the Bechtel fortune as a result. Fourth-generation leader of engineering giant Bechtel Corp., firm that built the Hoover Dam, and Chunnel. Father, Stephen, became president 1960, chairman 1973. Riley started as mechanic's helper at age 14; still has first Bechtel paycheck. Chairman and chief executive in 1990. Sales up 32% to $27 billion in 2007; firm booked $34 billion in new work last year. New jobs include a 1,600-megawatt, coal-fired power plant in Illinois and a liquefied natural gas processing plant in Angola. Completed U.K.'s first high-speed rail line and Tacoma Narrows Bridge near Seattle earlier this year. Believed to still have stake in privately held money management firm Fremont Group.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Bechtel Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The credit crisis is punishing the construction and private equity markets, and the Bechtel fortune as a result. Third-generation leader of firm that built the Hoover Dam, Turkey's Ankara-Gerede Highway and the Hong Kong International Airport. Became Bechtel president at age 35, chairman 13 years later. Son Riley now runs the $27 billion (sales) construction outfit. Father and son each believed to own 20% of the company. In July 2007 celebrated opening of Tacoma Narrows Bridge near Seattle, the longest suspension span built in the world since 1960s. New projects include a $1.9 billion expansion of its Worsley Alumina refinery in Western Australia. Owns stake in money management firm Fremont Group.
title: Former Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In March 2009 consummate self-promoter set off on an 8-day journey around the world to coincide with the launch of V Australia, the latest addition to his airline conglomerate. His low-cost airline, Virgin America, celebrated its first year of flying in August, but Alaska Airlines recently filed a complaint that its rival is violating U.S. foreign ownership rules on domestic airlines and asked the U.S. Department of Transportation to conduct a public inquiry. Virgin America CEO David Cush dismisses the Alaska complaint. Branson says he'd gladly hire Captain Chesley (Sully) Sullenberger, the U.S. Airways pilot who successfully crash-landed his plane in the Hudson River in January. Continues to expand businesses; plans to change his 2 private Caribbean islands, Necker and Mosquito, into renewable energy meccas. Son of a barrister and flight attendant got his start with a mail-order record business almost 40 years ago, then turned it into retail chain Virgin Records; now empire spans air travel, rail, health care, finance, telecommunications and entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sam (d. 1971), founded Canadian distilling company 1924; made fortune during American Prohibition by smuggling whiskey across border. Used profits to acquire Joseph E. Seagram & Sons 1928. Edgar Sr. crossed border himself to head U.S. business, brother Charles ran Canadian outfit. Expanded operations: Absolut (vodka), Tropicana (juice). Son Edgar Jr. staged ill-fated entrance into Hollywood; traded juice, nylon business for $5.7 billion stake in MCA/Universal 1995. Remainder of ownership grabbed by Vivendi for $34 billion 2000. Entertainment lost family billions of dollars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of money management and hedge fund firm Bridgewater said to have returned roughly 10% last year. Jazz musician's son executed first trade at age 12. Studied finance at Long Island U., went to work in commodities division of Merrill Lynch 1972. Harvard M.B.A. 1973. Traded futures at brokerage CBWL-Hayden Stone. Feuded with boss, founded Bridgewater Associates at age 25. Assets peaked at $165 billion in 2006; today manages $80 billion--including billions in hedge fund assets. Firm's web site claims 52% drop reflects "Bridgewater and its clients agreeing to shift its management of traditional accounts that require more funding to its highly diversified Pure Alpha fund, which requires less funding."
title: Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Bridgewater Associates', 'title': 'Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Though initial offerings of his sugar and flour companies were oversubscribed in 2007, stocks in both have fallen nearly 70% since last February. Using his role as committee member on government economic advisory board to encourage federal government to rescue the nation's capital markets. His conglomerate, the Dangote Group, has expanded its cement operations with new plants across Nigeria and as well as South Africa and Ethiopia. Sparring with new Nigerian billionaire Femi Otedola over oil and gas concessions; Otedola parried by buying up stock in Dangote's companies. Dangote began career as trader at age 21 with loan from his uncle; built his Dangote Group into conglomerate with interests in sugar, flour milling, salt processing, cement manufacturing, textiles, real estate, and oil and gas. Closely linked to Nigeria's former president Olusegun Obasanjo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Navy vet made billions getting people clean with shampoo and sloppy with tequila. Cofounded hair-care outfit John Paul Mitchell Systems with Paul Mitchell (d. 1989) in 1980 with $700; slept in car, sold products door-to-door in Los Angeles. Created tequila maker Patron Spirits with Martin Crowley (d. 2003) in 1989. Revenues of both companies up in 2008. With help of celeb friends Clint Eastwood and Wolfgang Puck, made $50 bottles of tequila a necessity at high-end restaurants, nightclubs. Today company sells nearly 2 million cases a year; only Jose Cuervo sells more in the U.S. Today owns an estimated 70% of Patron; Bacardi bought minority stake for undisclosed sum in July. East L.A. native loves philanthropy: "Success unshared is total failure." Supports Food4Africa, Mineseekers, Blazer House.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Texas wildcatter H.L. Hunt (d. 1974), who was said to be the inspiration for J.R. Ewing character on TV's Dallas. Relatives sold their Hunt Petroleum to XTO for $4.4 billion last year; none of Ray Lee's assets involved. Friend of former Presidents Bush Sr. and Jr. drew fire last year when he landed an oil concession in Iraq's Kurdish north. Sees future in natural gas: massive LNG plant in Yemen almost complete, another planned in Peru. Cattle rancher's real estate holdings include Hyatt Hotels, commercial property around Dallas.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Rupert, owns 33% of money management firm Franklin Resources; stock down more than 60% since last summer. Company's Templeton Global Income Fund down 25% since August. Father, Rupert Sr. started Franklin Custodian Funds in 1947; retired in 1955. Charles became chief executive in 1957. Rupert joined firm, then called Franklin Distributors, in 1965. Brothers formed holding company Franklin Resources in 1969; took public 1971. Today Charles serves as chairman; Rupert Jr. vice-chairman.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Accordion-playing fire-breather founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus, which has no animals, no speaking and no star performers, became a for-profit group in 1985. Bought out majority partner in 2000; today owns 95% of company. Hit jackpot when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas in 1991. Today group has six permanent shows in Sin City, including Beatles-themed "Love," which opened in June 2006; show replaced Siegfried & Roy at the Mirage. Up next: an Elvis-themed show in Vegas. Last August sold 20% of Cirque to two Dubai firms for $600 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Usually low-profile currency speculator became one of first high-profile victims of credit crunch. Invested $1 billion in Bear Stearns starting in 2007; lost nearly all of it when government JPMorgan Chase bailed out investment bank in March. Don’t count him out. Nicknamed The Boxer in part because his name recalls that of legendary heavyweight fighter Joe Louis but also because of dealmaking style. Bought one-third stake in pub operator Mitchells & Butlers last summer in distressed sale. Cashed out of sports betting firm Ladbrokes. Through his Tavistock Group, sold biotech CovX to Pfizer in January 2008. Other holdings include 8,000-plus acres in Orlando, British soccer team Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs) Football Club. Building luxury resort with buddies Tiger Woods and Ernie Els near Lyford Cay in Bahamas. Born above a pub in London’s East End, helped his family build a catering business. Sold it and became a currency trader. Some reports claim he made more on collapse of sterling on Black Wednesday in 1992 than George Soros. Still active trader.

name: Billionaires
bio: With $120 in savings, he and 3 brothers got start raising quail, chickens in 1982. Their Hope Group became one of China's largest makers of animal feed. Siblings split in 1995. Now runs New Hope Group, with interests in milk , meat, feed, even chemicals. Took advantage of falling prices for dairy firms after China's milk-safety crisis last year to purchase stakes in small brands. Acquired stake in chemical maker Hebei Baoshuo last year. Also has stake in China Minsheng Banking. Donated $1.5 million to 2008 China earthquake victims. Brother Liu Yongxing is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive construction tycoon, rarely ever seen in public.  His 140-year old Shapoorji Pallonji group which he chairs, is run by sons Shapoor and Cyrus. Got noticed when he built a palace for the Sultan of Oman in 1971. Bulk of fortune is private. Listed entity Forbes & Company sells water purifiers under Eureka Forbes brand. Goldman Sachs paid $50 million for minority stake in engineering arm Sterling & Wilson last year. Biggest asset remains 18.4% stake in Tata Sons, holding company of Tata Group which derives over 60% of its $48 billion revenues from overseas. Group undergoing financial hangover after buying binge of expensive acquisitions, notably Corus Steel and Jaguar Land Rover, forcing Tata Sons to pledge shares. Became Irish citizen in recent years but maintains a residence in Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Global recession has been especially harsh to media heir and onetime richest Australian as fortune more than halved amid collapsing casino industry, rumored angst and plain bad luck. Son of legendary media tycoon Kerry Packer, inherited $5 billion empire after dad&#39s death in 2005. Quick to put personal stamp on business, spun off media assets and bet on gaming business, Crown, which started trading in December 2007. Recent market carnage spared no part of his empire. Crown shares down 60% in past year on top of $290 million of writedowns forced by losses at Las Vegas casinos. Family&#39s financial firm, Challenger, suffered $145 million of writedowns and a 64% decline in stock price; stake in Consolidated Media Holdings shrank by two-thirds. Resorted to liquidating lifestyle: recently put luxury yacht up for sale and sold stake in family cattle farm for reported $275 million. Still, year wasn’t all bad: Packer and his model wife, Erica, welcomed their first child, daughter Indigo, in July.

name: Billionaires
bio: This month his holding companies Mintha Holding and Fulnek Enterprises via which he owns an 80%-plus stake in Magnitogorsk Iron and Steel Works, agreed to postpone receiving company dividends "while the market situation is deteriorating;" he along with other directors will also forgo salaries. Company stock has collapsed 82% over past year. In February, Magnitogorsk signed a $100 million first credit agreement with Sberbank. Began career at Magnitogorsk in the 1960s, becoming general director in 1997; defended plant from takeover attempt the following year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cartoon Schlepper's investments down an estimated 30% in past 12 months. Made first fortune with popular kids' show Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Sold Fox Family Worldwide, joint venture with Rupert Murdoch's Fox Television, to Disney for $5.2 billion in 2001. Sold majority stake in German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 to KKR and Permira for $4 billion in 2007; then, with partners, bought A. Jerrold Perenchio's Spanish-language media outfit, Univision, for $13.7 billion. Network settled long-running dispute with Televisa over program license agreements in January. Co-owns stake in Israeli telecom company Bezeq; increased stake with partners to 41% last September.

name: Billionaires
bio: Long family history in the construction industry: great-grandfather owned a brick factory and grandfather was in cement. Boyhood dream was to become a missionary. Went to law school instead. First job in family's construction firm Eternit was as secretary to a top executive. Soon moved up to a job in sales. In 1978 became firm's president. Brother Thomas, also a billionaire, got cement firm Holcim. At age 47, sold Swiss businesses to concentrate on philanthropies, mainly in Latin America. In 2003 donated all of the shares of GrupoNueva, his conglomerate of companies that operated in the region, worth $1 billion, to his Viva Trust, which includes a group of forestry and construction companies whose profits are then used to promote causes like sustainability and education. Much of wealth is now held in a diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and private equity investments and is handled by professional managers. Art collector favors contemporary painters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Blackstone Group struggling to stabilize private equity juggernaut amid seizure of credit markets, spiraling real estate values. Firm's "economic" loss in 2008: $1.33 billion. Shares down 59% in 12 months and 83% since public offering in 2007. With Peter Peterson founded Blackstone in 1985 with $400,000 balance sheet; diversified into real estate, hedge funds, financial advisory. Firm now manages $95 billion, down 20% since June. Likely successor: Hamilton ("Tony") James.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Blackstone Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded generic drug maker Apotex in 1974; today sales exceed one billion. Last year pharmaceutical giant Bristol-Meyers Squibb succeeded in blocking Apotex's generic competition to its blood thinner and is trying to get reimbursement for lost sales; analysts predict Apotex will not have to pay. Family remains locked in court fight with relatives who allege they are owed a piece of the fortune; Sherman filed countersuit, rebutting their claims. Son Jonathan Sherman is new owner of Ontario's bankrupt Steelback Brewery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Settled in U.S. in 1977 from Taiwan, became chief engineer for Alpha Micro. Cofounded Kingston Technology with John Tu in 1987; today largest privately held computer memory firm in U.S. Company's USB flash drives and flash cards grace cell phones, digital cameras, MP3 players. Sun and Tu work from cubicles in the middle of Kingston sales floor. Pair started memory-chip outfit Camintonn 1982, sold 4 years later for $6 million. Later formed Kingston. Sold 80% stake to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, bought it back for just $450 million 3 years later.
title: COO

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Keyence, leading maker of sensors. Strong sellers include measurement and control devices for factories. Expects net profit to fall 29% to $464 million this business year. Company pays engineers more than $100,000 on average to attract industry's best talent, but personal items such as photographs are banned from employees' work spaces.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bank clerk used profits from real estate deal to open bank in 1966. Today Public Bank has 14,000 employees, with 90% of them in Malaysia and the rest in other branches in Cambodia, Laos, Sri Lanka, Hong Kong and China. Donates to medical institutions supporting heart and dialysis research and to the Malaysian Nature Society to fund planting of trees. Set up Public Islamic Bank Berhad, a wholly owned subsidiary of Public Bank, in November 2008. Ardent soccer fan, also enjoys photography, a hobby he’s nurtured since his school days. Says he enjoys food but "doesn’t indulge in ostentatious dinners."

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied electrical engineering in Germany after family fled from China 1949. Cofounded Kingston Technology with David Sun in 1987; today largest privately held computer memory firm in U.S. Company's USB flash drives and flash cards grace cell phones, digital cameras, MP3 players. Sun and Tu work from cubicles in middle of Kingston sales floor. Pair started memory-chip outfit Camintonn 1982, sold 4 years later for $6 million. Later formed Kingston. Sold 80% stake to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, bought it back for just $450 million 3 years later. Plays drums in a band.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded his first hospital in 1984. Named it Asklepios after Greek God of medicine. Now owns 110 hospitals with $2.9 billion in sales in 2007, the last year available; employs 36,000 worldwide. While 96 are in Germany, also has hospitals in Portugal, Greece, Russia, Romania; has six in California in the U.S operated by Pacific Health Corp. Also has joint venture with Tongji University in China. Practiced as an accountant and lawyer before founding the hospital chain; has degrees from Insead at Fontainbleau, France, and an MBA from Harvard University. Owns the Kempinski Hotel Falkenstein in Koenigstein, a five star luxury spa and hotel in the Taunus mountains near Frankfurt, Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Record-label tycoon started out playing in a band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father's death. Moved to London in 1975 and founded Zomba Recordings, whose crown jewel is Jive Records. Ventured stateside in 1978, signing acts like Billy Ocean and the Cars, later Britney Spears, Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync. Sold Zomba Recordings to BMG for $2.7 billion in 2002. Now lives in the Cayman Islands, spending part of his time on charitable foundation, Elma Philanthropies, which works in nine African countries on children's education and health issues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family's scrap-metal business into a media, utilities and oil empire, Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille. Conglomerate sold its stake in media giant Bertelsmann in 2006. In July 2008, at age 82, he completed what some say is the greatest coup of his career by playing a key role in pushing through the stalled megamerger of CNP's subsidiary Suez with French utility Gaz de France. Stock of the resulting European energy giant, $106 billion (sales) GDF Suez, is down 40% since peaking last summer, but company is pushing ahead with European expansion, recently bidding for British nuclear power stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marcel Merieux, a former laboratory aide of Louis Pasteur. Founded BioMerieux in 1974, which had roots in his father's first laboratory, Institut Merieux. Now chairman of the board. Its biotech outfit specializes in in-vitro diagnostics and the diagnosis of infectious diseases such as HIV and tuberculosis. Eldest son Rodolphe was killed in 1996 at age 27 when TWA flight 800 crashed over Long Island. Second son, Christophe, who was expected to take over from his father, died of cardiac failure in July 2006 at age 39. Third son Alexandre, 32, is a member of the board. Family supports the Merieux Foundation, which helps developing countries combat infectious diseases.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last fall, oil trader Gennady Timchneko bought a 5% stake in Mikhelson's independent gas producer Novatek; now nominated for seat on its board. Stock down 65% over past year. Looking to expand base from northwestern Siberia; prospecting in Africa, Syria and Caspian Sea countries. Sold 19.5% stake in First United Bank in February. In 1987, inherited management of expansive Soviet enterprise that built pipelines, roads and industrial facilities. Four years later reorganized the company and began gathering up oil and gas production licenses, even accepting them as payment for construction work in order to build Novatek. In 2006 Gazprom bought nearly 20% of Novatek from Mikhelson and his partners, a deal widely seen as a way for the firm to ensure its survival; now Mikhelson is candidate for Gazprom board. Prolific art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: After sale of jointly-owned pipe producer TMK in fall of 20006, began divvying up assets with partner, billionaire Andrey Melnichenko. Now building banking presence. In December, announced merger of his MDM Bank, one of Russia's private lenders, with Ursa Bank; combined entity will have more capital to cover reserves for potential loan losses as Russia's economy continues to deteriorate. Pair still together owns coal miner SUEK which is reportedly planning to issue GDRs this year valued up to $1 billion. Left university to sell pipes and copper cable in 1990s; Melnichenko was his banker. Pair began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once Colombia's top builder, Sarmiento parlayed his construction fortune into a financial services empire, Grupo Aval Acciones y Valores. Over the years bought up stakes in four Colombian banks, a leasing company and a pension fund. The group has been less affected than many by the world economic downturn; shares at one of Aval's holdings, the Banco de Bogota have dropped only around 17% over the last year. Sarmiento has canceled plans to bid for a new Colombian television network license with Venezuelan billionaire Gustavo Cisneros.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Minnesota state senator started as a napkin stamper at Carlson Wedding Service. Bought majority interest from owner Bill Carlson 1975, founded Taylor Corp.; today has more than 80 subsidiary operations, including wedding invitations, printing, stationery. Invested in agribusiness on Iowa and Minnesota farmland. Sells liquefied eggs to food companies and restaurants; diner owners love product because it's inefficient to crack eggs on cooking lines. Majority owner of pro basketball's Minnesota Timberwolves.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the trio of Brazilians who share control of Anheuser-Busch Inbev, the world's largest beer company. With his former investment banking partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira, turned around Ambev, a Brazilian beermaker, and merged it with Interbrew of Belgium in 2004 to form Inbev. In November 2008 Inbev closed the $52 billion acquisition of Anheuser-Busch. The trio also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. Telles is reportedly a keen spearfisher and likes to spend time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister in law Wilma Tisch, controls family fortune built by their late husbands, famed investors Preston and Laurence Tisch. Duo started with small New Jersey hotel 1946. Acquired Loews Theatres 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. holding company includes diverse assortment of investments: oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk), insurance (CNA). Spun off cigarette maker Lorillard (Newport, Kent) to Carolina Group in 2007; last year sold Bulova watch group to Citizen for $250 million. Loews stock hammered by global meltdown; shares down 56% in past 12 months. Owns stake in pro football's New York Giants.

name: Billionaires
bio: In October Wrigley finalized $23 billion buyout of family's gum company by privately held candy giant Mars; combined company is now the largest confectionery operation in the world. Wrigley Co. founded 1891 by great-grandfather, who moved to Chicago to sell soap, then baking powder. Discovered gum more popular. Fourth-generation Wrigley took over 1999, stock rose 113% in his 9 years as chief executive and executive chairman.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened first apparel store in Barcelona 1984. Today his Mango group, known for producing reasonably priced trendy women's apparel, has more than 1000 stores in 89 countries and $1.7 billion in sales. Launched a men's wear collection, Mango HE, last year. Also has shares in Banco Sabadell, one of Spain's largest banking groups; sits on its board. Media-shy entrepreneur's family came to Spain from Turkey in 1960s; apparently an enthusiastic sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Accused by the SEC of insider trading in November; regulators allege he avoided $750,000 in paper losses after selling shares in Canadian Internet search outfit Mamma.com before damaging information was released to the public. Vowing to fight the charges. Owner of pro basketball's Dallas Mavericks took a swing at buying baseball's Chicago Cubs; lost out to Ricketts family. Also dabbling in extreme sports; created mixed martial arts league HDNet Fights to compete with Frank and Lorenzo Fertitta's lucrative Ultimate Fighting Championship. Former bartender sold Internet video outfit Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in stock 1999; hedged stock before tech bubble burst. Reinvested in entertainment; owns stakes in HDNet, 2929 Entertainment, Lion's Gate.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Sound sultan played clarinet as a child. Hired by Ampex at age 16, played integral role in developing company's first videotape recording system; left to get Ph.D. in physics at England's University of Cambridge. Founded Dolby Laboratories in London 1965; made fortune by eliminating background noise from recordings. Public 2005; shares down more than 30% in the past 12 months, posted surprisingly strong first quarter earnings in February. Acquired cell phone sound-compression outfit Coding Technologies last November for $250 million.
title: Founder and director emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Dolby Laboratories', 'uri': 'companies/dolby-laboratories', 'title': 'Founder and director emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Campbell Soup's founder, John Dorrance I, has led quiet life in South Dublin since cashing out of family business; from 1995 to 1996 sold off majority of his inherited 10.5% stake in soup for $1.5 billion. A well-timed bet: stock is down 23% from the date he sold his largest block of shares. Renounced U.S. citizenship and moved to Ireland shortly before selling, purportedly to avoid estate and capital gains taxes on coming windfall. Keeps a low profile and reportedly spends time in Bahamas with Finnish wife when not home in Ireland. Past pet causes have included legalization of game ranching in Wyoming and fox hunting in Great Britain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor who minted billions shorting subprime credit in 2007 lost some of his luster last year: flagship fund down 27.8%. Assets down 65% to $9 billion since September. Son of a utility superintendent started at Kidder, Peabody & Co. junk bond desk 1985. Spent time in junk bond departments at Wachovia, Barclays. Bought troubled plasticsmaker AAB Manufacturing 1990; quickly lost entire investment. Founded Harbinger Capital in 2001 with $25 million. Firm now manages 2 funds with roughly $9 billion in assets. Became a billionaire two years ago betting against subprime; "Special Situations" fund boasted 170% return in 2007. Recently added to hefty stake in power producer Calpine Corp. Tesfied in congressional hearing in November along with quartet of billionaire hedge fund managers. "Not everyone who runs a hedge fund was born on 5th Avenue--that is the beauty of America." Net worth up this year despite losses because last year's estimate failed to take into account the value of his stake in Harbinger.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James (Bud) Walton, and his brother Sam ran handful of small 5-and-10 stores in Arkansas, Missouri. Brothers built first Wal-Mart 1962. With sister Ann Walton Kroenke, inherited large stake in the retailer after Bud's death 1995. Shares worth $2.2 billion today. Bought pro hockey's St. Louis Blues 1999 with husband, Bill; sold 6 years later. Founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet in New York City 2003. Owns Providence Bank (4 locations in Missouri), plus commercial real estate in California, Florida, Nevada, Missouri.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Steven, left father's real estate firm 1979, started buying small manufacturing companies during 1980s junk bond craze. Result: Equity Group Holdings. Acquired crippled REIT, fused with other manufacturing, industrial companies to form Danaher. Revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years. Sales: $12.7 billion.  Stock down 36% in past six months. Took pump-and-valve manufacturer Colfax public last May, shares down 71% since.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold electronics for father's company before opening car stereo store called Sound of Music 1966 in St. Paul, Minnesota. Changed name of growing chain to Best Buy in 1983; took public two years later. Began transitioning stores to familiar warehouse format in 1989; piled inventory high on the sales floor. Stock down 38% in the past six months. Sales in 2008 up 11% to $40 billion. Company bought 50% stake in U.K.'s Carphone Warehouse for $2.1 billion last year. Pledging to donate $40 million to diabetes research at University of Minnesota over the next five years.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate heiress whose father, Country Garden's chief, Yeung Kwok Keung, transferred holdings to her ahead of 2007 initial offering.She's now China's richest woman despite losing $5 billion in the past year, in part due to company's ill-timed acquisitions during market peak. Not much else known about her other than the fact she is an Ohio State grad and her wedding video is posted on YouTube.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Sodexo as catering and river cruise company in 1966 in a warehouse in Marseilles. Today the $17.3 billion (2007 sales) company supplies food to the U.S. Marine Corps, handles security for the Alaska natural gas pipeline, operates prisons and has majority stake in the Lido, the Parisian topless cabaret that features ice dancers and trapeze artists. Last year acquired 90% stake in Yachts de Paris, one of the best-known cruise companies operating on the Seine. Bellon stepped down as chief executive in 2005 but remains chairman. Penned autobiography, "I've Had a Great Time".

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandmother founded H.E. Butt Grocery in 1905 from a small house in Kerrville, Tex. after husband fell ill with tuberculosis. Today HEB operates 307 stores, employs 71,000 workers. Sales in 2008: $15.2 billion. Expanding in Texas and Mexico. Also operates Central Market, catering to wine-and-cheese set; stores shun big brands in favor of organic foods. Now selling insurance, cell phone plans, defensive driving courses. Each year company donates 5% of pretax profits to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tampa tycoon holds the majority of his fortune in an asset class that holds value in a recession: sports teams. Owns pro football's Tampa Bay Buccaneers, English soccer giant Manchester United. Man U won both English Premier League and Champions League in 2008, but massive debt load continues to hamper profitability despite rising revenues. Inherited watch-parts business from father at 15; eventually expanded family empire into shopping malls, sports teams. Shopping: today owns 7 million square feet of retail space. Glazer Children's Museum slated to open in Tampa Spring 2010. Sons now manage family assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jewelry business insiders call British diamond merchant Graff the new Harry Winston. Specializing in the highest end of jewelry retailing, Graff has 30 stores worldwide. Clients include the Sultan and Queen of Brunei and Donald Trump. As financial markets tanked this year, Graff made bold public purchases, including the 35-carat Wittelsbach Diamond, which he snapped up in December at a Christie's auction in London for $24 million, the most ever paid for a diamond at auction. A self-made tycoon, Graff spent childhood in London's gritty East End, dropping out of school at age 14 to become a jeweler's apprentice. In 2008 Graff achieved full vertical integration when he bought a stake in publicly traded diamond miner Gem Diamonds. Other assets include jewelry company Graff Diamonds International, a polished diamond trading company in Antwerp, a real estate company in Luxembourg and a stake in a South African diamond wholesaler. Graff splits his time between homes in Gstaad, London, Cap Ferrat, New York City and his 150-foot Feadship yacht. Also owns a vineyard and winery in Stellenbosch, the Napa Valley of South Africa, and an extensive modern and contemporary art collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built Seven & I Holdings into Japan's leading retailer, with department stores, supermarkets and 12,000 7-Eleven stores. Has expanded 7-Eleven to China and other parts of Asia. Company opened banking unit and is expanding overseas to counter weak consumer spending at home. Honorary Chairman Ito recently gave away 10% of his shares in company to longtime employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oakley sunglasses founder fulfilling lifelong passion for filmmaking, photography - and building a new optics fortune in the process. Founded Red Digital Cinema in 2005; firm is the first to offer "affordable" high-definition digital cinema cameras to the masses. Red One camera sells for $17,500. Elite Hollywood directors - including Peter Jackson (Lord of the Rings), Steven Soderbergh (Ocean's Eleven) - using Red Digital equipment on set. Spent 32 years developing cutting-edge optics technology; some Oakley glasses can withstand a shotgun blast. Employees dubbed him "mad scientist" 1980s. Finalized sale of Oakley to Italian design firm Luxottica late 2007; personally netted $1.2 billion. Views Oakley like a daughter graduating: "I'm still loving and loyal to her, but I'm no longer responsible."

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Charles, owns 33% of money management firm Franklin Resources; stock down more than 60% since last summer. Company's Templeton Global Income Fund down 25% since August. Father, Rupert Sr. started Franklin Custodian Funds in 1947; retired in 1955. Charles became chief executive in 1957. Rupert joined firm, then called Franklin Distributors, in 1965. Brothers formed holding company Franklin Resources in 1969; took public 1971. Today Charles serves as chairman; Rupert Jr. vice-chairman.
title: Vice Chairman and Director
employment: {'name': 'Franklin Resources', 'uri': 'companies/franklin-resources', 'title': 'Vice Chairman and Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction worker's son feeling pinch of publishing industry slowdown. Studied biophysics at MIT while working for first U.S. computer magazine, Computers & Automation; made associate publisher by graduation. Founded International Data Group 1964; launched trade magazine Computerworld 3 years later. Now has more than 300 magazines, trade shows, 450 Web sites. Last year sales rose 6% to $3.2 billion. Company has invested $950 million in venture capital companies in China, $150 million in India, $100 million in Vietnam, $100 million in Korea. Created McGovern Institute for brain research at alma mater.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'International Data Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Colorful, cussing cell phone mogul, already operating in dozens of Caribbean islands, is quickly expanding in the South Pacific in such places as Fiji, Tonga and Papua New Guinea, despite coups, riots and government threats to nationalize. One trick is to endear his firm to masses by lowering prices and upping philanthropy. Angry mobs in Haiti’s food riots last year spared his phone stores from burning and looting out of respect for the "Company of the People." Spent $700 million buying up shares in Irish newspaper company, Independent News & Media, in effort to oust former billionaire investor, Anthony O’Reilly; stake now worth $50 million. Also has interests in radio stations, online recruiting sites in China, and Portuguese resort. Son of human rights activist, started nonprofit Front Line to fly activists in danger out of hot spots.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy media mogul transformed struggling Univision into broadcasting juggernaut; today world's leading Spanish-language broadcaster. Bought channel from Hallmark for $550 million in 1992 with Latin American partners; sold to a Haim Saban group for $13.7 billion last year. Great timing: network now worth a fraction of what he sold it for. "Jerry" began as talent agent for MCA. Created Embassy Communications with former TV producer Norman Lear (All in the Family), sold programming interests to Coca-Cola for $485 million 1985. One of largest landowners in Malibu. Said to have raised more than $500,000 from relatives and associates for John McCain's presidential campaign.
title: Founder & Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendant of one of the greatest capitalists in American history is worth $700 million less than he was last fall due to losses suffered by his stock and real estate portfolio. Claims world-class art collection--including Monet, Matisse and Renoir works--has largely retained its value. Grandfather turned $4,000 in oil refining into Standard Oil, oil and gas giant that fueled American industrial revolution. Company broken up in landmark antitrust case 1911; much of Standard Oil lives on as ExxonMobil. At annual meeting last year Rockefeller family members demanded ExxonMobil adopt greener measures. Bequeathed $100 million to alma mater Harvard to fund study abroad and arts programs; largest ever alumnus donation. Nonagenarian visited 10 countries last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Budapest, raised in California. As UCLA senior, brokered $1 million airplane deal for Air New Zealand while juggling economics classes, 2 lifeguarding gigs. With $150,000 savings and a $1.7 million bank loan, started International Lease Finance with fellow Hungarians Louis and Leslie Gonda. Sold airplane leasing firm to AIG for $1.3 billion 1990. Started pushing for AIG to sell off ILFC after insurance giant posted $7.8 billion first-quarter loss in 2008; prized unit now on the block. Likely buyer: an investment group that includes Udvar-Hazy and other ILFC executives. AIG reported record-setting $62 billion loss in fourth quarter, stock down 97% in 2008 but Udvar-Hazy claims to have sold off his stake months before government bailout burned AIG's shareholders. Donates to Stanford, Harvard-Westlake in Beverly Hills, Smithsonian. Flies his own Gulfstream V.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime head of Esprit has sold more than $2 billion worth of shares in recent years. Smart move: his remaining stake in Esprit has lost more than half its value in past 12 months. Now nonexecutive director of Esprit, got his big break in 1971 when company's American founders hired him as their primary sourcing agent; eventually bought rights to the clothing brand in Europe and Asia. Married to former Taiwanese movie star Brigitte Lin. Said to be an amateur paleontologist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish-born developer fled Europe during World War II for then Palestine. Studied architecture, then went to Canada, where he established his real estate business. Today his property business spans Canada, U.S., Europe and Israel. Israeli properties, including malls and high-rises, got a boost last year from strong shekel, which reached 10-year high against dollar last summer. Debt-averse octogenarian thinking of succession. Through his Azrieli Foundation supports architecture, education and the arts. Past president of Canadian Zionist Association, last year published book about contributions of Jewish and gentile Canadians to establishment of Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of steel tycoon John Hillman Jr., owner of Pittsburgh Coke & Chemical. Diversified family fortune via Hillman Co: real estate, venture capital, private equity. Early backer of venture capital monster Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, buyout titans Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Invests in biomedical and technology companies. Co-owns downtown Pittsburgh's office and retail center PPG Place. Donates through family foundations; $20 million to U. of Pittsburgh for cancer research, $10 million to Carnegie Mellon. Wife, Elsie, is actively involved in Republican politics.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older sister Esther, also a billionaire, inherited Fomento de  Construcciones y Contratas from late father. Their husbands ran the company  from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The  sisters then ran the company jointly until 1997 when Alicia sold her share to Esther for $800 million. Invested proceeds in companies such as Acerinox, Iberdrola and Banco Sabadel; hotels in Spain, Italy and Portugal; and U.S. real estate. Lost half her fortune over the past year, amid economic downturn. Last September tried to redeem about $6 million she had invested in a Madoff vehicle. Her hedge fund Omega, of which she owns 60%, manages $400 million in funds, down from $1 billion a year ago. Through her charitable foundation, sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. at places like Columbia University's medical center. Has been linked romantically with the Duque de Huescar, heir to the Spanish aristocratic house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of the founder of Danish toymaker Lego. Ran company for 25 years before stepping down in 2004 after several years of losses; remains its sole owner and vice chairman of the board. Despite downturn, world's sixth-largest toymaker by sales ($1.4 billion) has turned a profit since 2006 thanks to restructuring and the sale of assets like its four Legoland amusement parks. Holds numerous awards, including a knighthood in Denmark's Order of the Dannebrog; member of Toy Industry Hall of Fame.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemical engineer grandfather John T. Dorrance developed method of canning condensed soup that used half as much water, reduced costs by a third. Result: Campbell Soup Co. Today world's biggest soupmaker. Sales: $8 billion in 2008. Earnings slumped in latest quarter as consumers wait longer to restock their cabinets. Stock down 28% in past six months. Publicly traded firm also controls Pace (salsa), Pepperidge Farm (Goldfish, crackers), Prego (spaghetti sauce).

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of discount shoe store chain ABC Mart. Group is accelerating store openings to capture penny-pinching consumers. Sales, profits strong so far in this fiscal year. Former amateur boxer stepped down as chairman in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Future Electronics in 1968 and built it into the world's third-largest electronics distributor; products include semiconductors and electromechanical components. Building new $50 million distribution center in Germany. Supports Alcor Life Extension Foundation, which promotes cryonics, the science of freezing bodies with the intent to restore life when technology becomes available.

name: Billionaires
bio: After finishing university, Vancouver magnate parlayed car dealerships into advertising, fishing and supermarket empire. Acquired 9 new companies last year, including Guinness World Records. Despite troubles in his auto and coal export subsidiaries, expects to remain on the prowl for opportunistic buys in 2009. Also owns stake, sits on board of Canadian telecom company, BCE Inc., which in December experienced the collapse of what would have been the biggest leveraged buyout in Canadian history. Runs eclectic tourist attractions including Ripley's Believe It or Not and owns massive Palm Springs lair that once belonged to Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Split from his longtime partner, Mikhail Prokhorov, beginning in early 2007. Has not helped his pocket book. Fortune has fallen more than $17 billion in past year, as shares of his biggest holding, world's biggest nickel producer Norilsk Nickel, collapsed by three-fourths. Still his stake in Norilsk is not as large as he hoped, as Prokhorov sold out to billionaire Oleg Deripaska instead of him. As part of division of assets, Potanin still has a stake in Rosbank. Sold 20% stake in Polyus Gold to another billionaire, Suleiman Kerimov, late 2008.  Has variously served as a deputy prime minister of the economy under Boris Yeltsin and as partner to George Soros in telecom monopoly Svyazinvest. Active in philanthropy in Russia and is a supporter of the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell, left father's real estate firm 1979, started buying small manufacturing companies during 1980s junk bond craze. Result: Equity Group Holdings. Acquired crippled REIT, fused with other manufacturing, industrial companies to form Danaher. Revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years. Sales: $12.7 billion.  Stock down 36% in past six months. Took pump-and-valve manufacturer Colfax public last May, shares down 71% since.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Former jute trader and banker made early move into infrastructure building power plants, highways. Shot into limelight in recent years by winning hotly contested bids to modernize airports in Hyderabad and Delhi. His newly built international terminal at Hyderabad was inaugurated by Congress party president Sonia Gandhi last March. Is also constructing new terminal in Istanbul with Malaysia Airports and Limak Group, a Turkish conglomerate. Paid $930 million for 50% stake in InterGen, a Dutch utility last June. His Delhi airport is facing funds crunch since auction of plots for airport hotels found no takers and banks backed out. Government recently allowed him to charge passengers an airport development fee to cover shortfall. Likes reading spiritual books.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older of 2 living billionaire brothers descended from a Middle Eastern banking family. In 2006 Moise sold to his brother Joseph his stake in Banco Safra, now Brazil's 9th-largest bank, plus stakes in Safra-owned banks in New York, Luxembourg and other locations, for an undisclosed sum that was estimated at $2 billion. The brothers recently sold their voting shares in pulp and papermaker Aracruz Celulose. Joseph and Moise's deceased brother Edmond had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife Lily.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the trio of Brazilians who share control of Anheuser-Busch Inbev, the world's largest beer company. With his former investment banking partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Telles, turned around Ambev, a Brazilian beermaker, and merged it with Interbrew of Belgium in 2004 to form Inbev. In November 2008 Inbev closed the $52 billion acquisition of Anheuser-Busch. The trio also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. Sicupira earlier worked as an investment banker in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Bangkok street vendor of fried mussel pancakes made his fortune selling inexpensive beer and whiskey. Took his ThaiBev company public in 2006 in Singapore after mostly Buddhist protesters stopped the listing on Thailand's stock exchange; may still eventually pursue Thai listing. His popular Chang Beer can be seen on the jerseys of Liverpool's Everton football team. Through his privately held TCC Land, also owns residential buildings in Singapore and Thailand, hotels in Asia and the U.S. including Plaza Athenee hotels in New York City and Bangkok. Recently acquired hotels in Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Regains title as world's youngest billionaire after younger tycoons like Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg dropped out of ranks.  First appeared in Forbes' ranks at age 8 but officially inherited fortune  in June 2001 on his 18th birthday.  Went to high school in Rome; in June 2008 received an M.A. in economics and theology from the University of Edinburgh in Scotland. But hardly needs to earn his keep.  Assets include real estate, art and a tech company and  30,000 hectares of woodland in Germany, one of the largest forest holdings in Europe.  Calls family castle,  Schloss Emmeram, home.  Eligible bachelor is also a racecar driver, tours with a German auto-racing league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Russia's largest private bank, Alfa Bank, a business within the Alfa Group conglomerate owned by fellow billionaires Mikhail Fridman, German Khan and Alexei Kuzmichev. In February, dismissed aid after rumors surfaced Aven was seeking prime ministership of Latvia. Considering tapping government lifeline to refinance Alfa's foreign debt. Moscow native was formerly minister of foreign economic relations. In 1994 met Alfa Group's Mikhail Fridman (now a billionaire) and soon became a shareholder of Alfa-Bank. Owns largest private collection of Russian art in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Identical twins live in a mansion on the isle of Breqhou and have signifanct investments on its neighbor, Sark: the islands are part of Guernsey, a feudal possession of the British crown governed independently of the United Kingdom. In December elections, Sark voters rejected candidates backed by the brothers; the billionaires fired nearly 100 employees in response, but the jobs have since been reinstated. Share empire spanning Ritz London, InterContinental Hotel Group, home shopping network Littlewoods and the Telegraph Newspaper Group. Recently bought 100 year-old Woolworth brand, whose stores shut down; relaunching as as online seller. Brothers started together in the accounts department at General Electric, flipped houses and purchased first hotel in 1975.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production still among biggest private oil companies; sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Lee invests with Sid; billions of dollars in Cayman Islands investment accounts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production still among biggest private oil companies; sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Brother Lee invests with Sid; billions of dollars in Cayman Islands investment accounts. Friends of Dubya were guests at 2007 White House dinner for Queen Elizabeth. Last year Sid's identity stolen; scofflaw got 15 years in prison for creating fake credit cards, forging $720,000 check from Bass Enterprises.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media baron first struck it rich as a founding investor in production company Endemol, associated with such reality TV hits as Deal or No Deal, Fear Factor and the Big Brother franchise. Sold Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000; two years ago acquired 5% stake of Endemol sparking rumors that he wanted it all back. Also bought into RDF Media, which produces Wife Swap. Focusing on developing TV properties via Talpa Media.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of oil baron J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976) spent four years in family business, then sold Getty Oil to Texaco for $10 billion 1986. Now spends time composing music for operas, including PlumpJack and Joan and the Bells. PlumpJack also the name of his Napa Valley winery. Avid San Francisco Giants fan packages wine in screw caps, claims they're better than corks. Commands $200 a bottle. Reportedly lost millions last year in failed tech startup Pay By Touch.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Israel, raised in Michigan. studied real estate finance at Michigan State; spent 20s learning buyout business alongside older brother Alec. Created Platinum Equity 1995; rebuilds distressed companies, flips for profit. Today owns, manages 24 firms. Sold steel distributor PNA Group for $500 million profit last August. Launched private equity arm in 2004 with $3 billion committed from institutional investors. Closed $2.75 billion second fund last September.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Hon Hai Precision Industry in 1974 with $7,500. The group is world's largest contract manufacturer, assembling Apple iPods, iPhones; Nokia cell phones, Nintendo Wii systems among others. Hon Hai's stock has tumbled by more than half in past year on increasing labor costs in China and worries about a slowdown in demand for some of the devices it makes. Looking to cut costs by shifting some production to Vietnam. Reported to have laid off 100,000 of its 750,000 workers since economic downtown. Gou's daughter sits on board of directors of Hong Kong-listed subsidiary Foxconn.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wife and business partner of roofing magnate Kenneth Hendricks (d. 2007) took over as chairman of ABC Supply, nation's largest wholesale distributor of roofing materials, earlier this year. Sales: $3 billion. Also now controls Hendricks Holding Co. Diane met Kenneth at age 21, shared love of real estate. Started ABC Supply 1982. Diane formed American Patriot Insurance Agency 1986.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'ABC Supply', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother, Ingeburg, and four brothers, Gunter, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang, inherited a fortune from her father, coffee magnate Max Herz. A nasty family feud led her and her older brother Gunter to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, to their mother and other three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. She and her brother now own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in 140-year-old German shipping company, Germanisches Lloyd.  Sold a stake in Puma to Francois Pinault's PPR group for well more than $1 billion in 2007. Reportedly considering buying up a sizable stake Hong Kong apparel company, Esprit Holding.  Brother Joachim died last May after being  hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, three brothers, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang, and sister Daniela, inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz.  Headed the family Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, for almost 35 years. A  nasty family feud led him and his sister Daniela to sell their combined 40% stake in the German consumer goods group to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. Now he and his sister own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in 140 year old German shipping co, Germanisches Lloyd.  Sold a stake in Puma  to Francois Pinault's PPR group for well over $1 billion in 2007. Reportedly considering buying up a sizable stake Hong Kong apparel company, Esprit Holding.  Brother Joachim died last May after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.  Raises horses at his stud farm; races his yacht, All Smoke

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of hotel impresario Conrad Hilton (d. 1979) has seen his estimated net worth fall $500 million in the past six months. Sold off final remnants of father's empire 2007. Blackstone bought Hilton Hotels for $26 billion; personally reaped $800 million from the deal. Initially resisted following in father's footsteps, then rose from elevator operator to president. Became chairman 1979. Has now pledged to leave $1.2 billion to Conrad Foundation. Flies gliders, balloons, helicopters, fixed-wing aircraft at his 750,000-acre ranch in Nevada.
