name: Billionaires
bio: Savvy sports investor completed sale of pro football's Miami Dolphins to billionaire Stephen Ross in February; total pricetag was $1.1 billion. Still owns 5% of team. Son of residential housing contractor; served in Army. Bought garbage trucks; founded trash titan WMX in 1968. Retired 1984. Bought stake in small video-rental chain Blockbuster 3 years later; company sold to Viacom for $8.4 billion 1994. Now diversified: cash, bonds, real estate, AutoNation, Republic Services. Owns several private jets, plush Gary Player-designed golf course.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sudanese-born "Mo" founded Celtel, a mobile phone company that now serves 15 African countries. Sold it in 2005 for $3.4 billion; pocketed $1.4 billion. The London resident now spends his time on philanthropy and investing in Africa. Created Mo Ibrahim Foundation to award monetary prize to former African heads of state who have shown exemplary leadership in such areas as promoting political freedom; awarded first $5 million prize in October.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout drove a taxi in London before moving to Bahrain to help run family's baby products shop. Found himself in charge after brother, father and mother all died within a year of one another. Expanded that first shop into one of the Middle East's largest retail empires, cornering the market on affordable apparel, shoes, furniture and baby goods. Stores span the Persian Gulf and India. Value pitch has helped group weather the turndown, but plans for Landmark-brand hotels now on hold. Active philanthropist in India; sponsors schools, an orphanage and a health center for slum-dwellers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James, was former chairman of New York Stock Exchange who joined Wall Street specialist firm that became Spear, Leeds & Kellogg. Joined father's firm early 1970s; sold to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion in 2000. Invested a few million dollars in IAT reinsurance outfit 1980s; today is firm's controlling shareholder. Firm owns stakes in TRC (environmental engineering and consulting), Evans & Sutherland (digital theaters). Firm recently sold off bulk of its shares in pharmaceutical manufacturer Chattem. Stake in medical device maker Thoratec up 50% in last 12 months. Owns 3,000-acre hunting range in New Jersey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of ESL Investments has seen his net worth fall $1.5 billion in the past 12 months. Much of his portfolio in Sears Holdings: shares down 66% since last March; margins falling amid retail woes. Also controls 40% stake in AutoZone; shares up 34% since last March. Lawyer's son spent spare time in high school reading corporate reports and financial textbooks. Studied at Yale. Took job at Goldman Sachs, mentored by Robert Rubin. Snagged early investment from Richard Rainwater. Founded his own investment shop in 1988. Nabbed Kmart in bankruptcy buying up its bonds on the cheap. Merged with Sears, Roebuck; became chairman of combined company 2005. Clients have included Michael Dell, Tisch family's Loews Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother, Estee Lauder (d. 2004), sold skin cream concocted by chemist uncle. Emphasized personal customer attention, free gifts. Operation became cosmetics giant; today family's 70% stake worth more than $6 billion. Labels include Clinique, Aveda, Bobbi Brown, La Mer. Serves as Estee chairman; son William is chief executive. Shares down more than 50% in the past 12 months. Like brother, Ronald, owns large art collection. Donated $130 million to Whitney Museum last year.
title: Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Estée Lauder Cos', 'uri': 'companies/estee-lauder-cos', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime term-limit proponent making exception for fellow billionaire. Supporting Michael Bloomberg in his run for a third term as New York City mayor. Mother, Estee Lauder (d. 2004), sold skin cream concocted by chemist uncle. Emphasized personal customer attention, free gifts. Operation became cosmetics giant. Labels include Clinique, Aveda, Bobbi Brown, La Mer. Shares down more than 50% in past 12 months. Ronald owns stakes in Central European Media Enterprises, Israeli TV station. Like older brother, Leonard, owns vast art collection. Paid $135 million for 1907 Klimt portrait 2006, the largest sum ever paid for a single painting at the time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheese king weathering recession. Leprino Foods supplies cheese for budget-friendly fare like Dominos, Papa John's, Pizza Hut pizzas, Hot Pockets, string cheese. Father, Mike Sr., came to the U.S. in 1914, settled in Colorado. Whipped up homemade mozzarella and ricotta cheese for local customers in 1950s. Son Jim joined company at 18; turned modest family business into world's largest mozzarella producer. Today Leprino Foods operates 12 plants around U.S. and Europe. Sales: $2.6 billion. By-products whey protein, lactose, sweet whey powder used in infant formula, yogurt. Plans for plant in Colorado expected to boost dairy production, fuel local economy.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Forced out of McCain Foods' day-to-day operations in the 1990s after family feud; remains vice chairman with one-third stake in the company, which is the world's largest producer of frozen french fries. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods in 1995, where son Michael is chief. In February Maple Leaf announced a $25 million proposed settlement to a class action brought against the company after a strain of listeria causing 20 deaths was linked to its Toronto plant last summer. Donates to philanthropic causes like National Ballet School of Canada and National Gallery of Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: Midwestern grocer survives the downturn as thrifty customers increasingly frequent his discount stores. Father, Hendrik, emigrated from the Netherlands 1907, became barber. Opened Meijer Grocery 1934 with son Frederick. Duo launched Meijer Thrifty Acres in 1962; offered one-stop shopping. Frederick took over after father's death 1964. Today there are 185 Meijer stores in 5 states.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of brewer and sodamaker Empresas Polar, one of Venezuela’s largest private companies. Grandson of company founder. Leftist president Hugo Chavez publicly threatened to nationalize Polar if it was caught hoarding food; Polar said it has no role in the country’s food shortages. Runs one of Venezuela’s largest charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Lebanese prime minister founded telecom company Investcom with brother at height of Lebanon's civil war in 1982. After public offerings in London and Dubai, sold company to South Africa's MTN Group for $5.5 billion 3 years ago; family remains MTN's second-largest shareholder. Runs M1 Group, a holding company invested in real estate, Geneva airline Baboo and classy fashion line, Faconnable. Public service career launched in 1998 when Tripoli-born businessman was appointed to Lebanese cabinet as Minister of Public Works & Transport. Three-month stint as prime minister came in wake of Hariri assassination after predecessor Omar Karami quit in frustration. Known for moderate ways, recently hosted the First Conference for Centrism in Lebanon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother and business partner of onetime Lebanese prime minister and fellow billionaire Najib Mikati keeps low profile. Founded telecom company Investcom with brother at height of Lebanon's civil war in 1982. After public offerings in London and Dubai, sold company to South Africa's MTN Group for $5.5 billion 3 years ago; family remains MTN's second-largest shareholder. Co-founded M1 Group, a holding company invested in real estate, Geneva airline Baboo and classy fashion line, Faconnable. Got start as cofounder of Abu Dhabi's Arabian Construction Company in late 1960s; 20 years later sold his stake and moved back to Lebanon.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former biochemistry student and soccer player successfully transformed his family's fledgling fertilizer company into a $125 million chemicals business. Later began bankrolling films for U.S. directors before going on to produce such classics as Pretty Woman, The War of the Roses, Fight Club and Mr. and Mrs. Smith. Latest films haven't done as well; last year executive produced What Happens in Vegas with Cameron Diaz and Ashton Kutchner; though it made money, received lackluster reviews. This year oversaw, Bride Wars, with Kate Hudson and Anne Hathaway, which received similarly tepid reviews. Closed television production unit last summer. Formed joint venture with Elisabeth Murdoch's (daughter of billionaire Rupert Murdoch) London production company Shine Group to produce films.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fueled 1980s buyout craze with junk bonds, padded fortunes of The Forbes 400: Carl Icahn, Ted Turner, Ronald Perelman, Henry Kravis. Pleaded guilty to 6 counts of securities fraud in 1990. Served 22 months. In January President Bush denied petition for presidential pardon. Invested in education outfit K12. Longtime philanthropist has donated more than $1 billion to medical causes: melanoma, AIDS, leukemia, breast cancer, prostate cancer, Alzheimer's.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tycoon's publicly-traded hedge fund marred by redemptions and sluggish returns; shares of Och-Ziff down more than 70% in past 12 months. Wharton grad took job in arbitrage at Goldman Sachs 1982; worked with famed investors Edward Lampert, Thomas Steyer, Richard Perry. Left to launch Och-Ziff hedge fund with $100 million initial investment from Ziff brothers. Took public 2007. Assets under management: $22.3 billion, down 30% since last summer. Flagship fund lost 16% in 2008; has clawed back 4% so far this year.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Och-Ziff Capital Management Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Erlling Persson, who founded trendy apparel retailer Hennes & Mauritz in 1947.  Lotti, as she is known to her friends, is its second largest shareholder.  The biggest shareholder is brother Stefan has run the company since 1982. Nephew Karl-Johan Persson will become its chief executive this summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunging in energy prices caught oilman off guard; his energy funds reportedly lost $1 billion in a nine-month period last year. Wildcatter studied geology at Oklahoma State; graduated 1951. Worked for Phillips Petroleum for 3 years; became bored, quit. Started Mesa Petroleum 1956 with $2,500. Discovered oil, gas and debt. Sold to Richard Rainwater; shook oil industry with attempted takeovers of Phillips, Gulf, Unocal. Today runs investment firm BP Capital; owns vast water rights in Texas Panhandle. Has donated over $500 million to charity in past 4 years. Promoting "Pickens Plan": determined to attain energy independence in the U.S. with a mixture of wind, nuclear and drilling proposals, plus incentives for natural-gas-powered heavy-duty vehicles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Instinctive investor was weary of the energy bubble; liquidated extensive oil holdings last May. Sees opportunity again; has been buying back energy stakes since late last year. Made risky bet on Thornburg Mortgage in 2008. Total loss: $100 million. "The worst investment I've ever made." Also invested in bonds, private equity. Part owner of Pebble Beach golf course. Son of middle-class wholesaler studied at Stanford; brief stint at Goldman Sachs before leaving to run Bass family's $50 million portfolio in 1970, lost money first 2 years. Acquired large stake in Disney 1984; went solo 2 years later to manage personal investments. Made billions betting on oil; once claimed to be the largest individual shareholder of Chevron, ConocoPhillips.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino mogul buying in on the cheap. Sold New Frontier Hotel & Casino for $1.2 billion in 2007 to El-Ad Group (owners of Manhattan's Plaza Hotel). Vegas casinos hammered since. Paid MGM Mirage $775 million for Treasure Island casino resort in December. College dropout flipped burgers for a living. Made initial fortune investing in oil, real estate. Built 64-story Trump International Hotel & Tower with Donald Trump 2005, duo split $500 million. Married Aleksandra Nikolaenko last year; former Miss Ukraine appeared in 2004 Miss Universe contest. Two-time winner of the Forbes 400 charity poker tournament.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Stefan Schorghuber who died unexpectedly in November 2008 at age 47.  Husband Stefan oversaw a family fortune that included breweries, real estate, construction, and services.  The mother of three says she will follow in her husband's footsteps as head of the group's supervisory board; worked for several years alongside her husband in the group's hotel, ski lift and golf segments. Family is well-known in Munich for its support of modern art and its subsidized holidays for underprivileged children and their families.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former steelworker built Jiangsu Shagang into one of country's largest steelmakers. Looking to lock in raw materials, Shagang agreed to take a 45% stake in Australian iron ore prospector Grange Resources; merged it with its Australian iron ore unit, Australian Bulk Minerals. Shen is vice chairman of the China Iron & Steel Association and a member of the 17th National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York City developer owes his fortune to one building: iconic 9 West 57th Street. One of Manhattan's premier office buildings, with panoramic views of Central Park and Midtown; home to several high-profile financial firms, including KKR; commands rents of up to $200 per square foot. Vacating tenant Bank of America moving employees to newly completed One Bryant Park. Also owns several apartment buildings on Upper East Side. Received city approval last March for $4 billion plan to redevelop 9.8 acres of former Con Edison land along Manhattan's East River, no development so far. Sued by Citibank claiming default on a loan to finance the project. Recently donated land to aid expansion of NYU's Institute of Fine Arts; additional $4 million for fellowships and financial aid.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Geneva-headquartered Steinmetz Diamond Group, which he inherited from his father. The company is De Beers' largest buyer of rough diamonds; as luxury sales contract, business faltering. His real estate holdings in Kazakhstan, Russia and eastern Europe down significantly as buyers dry up. Worth of mining assets, including privately held Cunico and publicly traded Katanga Mining, down 75% since last year. Remains opportunistic: won rights to world's largest undeveloped iron ore deposit in December, snagging it from Rio Tinto. The concession, situated in the turbulent West African nation of Guinea, could be worth $5 billion. With wife, oversees the Beny & Agnes Steinmetz Foundation, which donates to schools, hospitals, army units and the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) surgeon who created mobile hospital bed; started medical supplier Stryker Corp. Son Lee died in plane crash 1976. John Brown took reins; public in 1979. Now makes joint replacements, surgical tools, medical software. Third generation now controls 30% of medical device maker; shares down 45% in past year. Sales in 2008: $6.7 billion. Ronda sits on board, vice chairman of Greenleaf Trust.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his Olav Thon Gruppen, the country's largest private real estate company by market cap, owns 420 properties in Norway and 25 abroad. The portfolio includes 61 shopping malls as well as office buildings, retail stores, hotels (7,000 rooms) and several Oslo restaurants and pubs. Entire portfolio suffering with declines in Norwegian market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Often called the Siberian hermit; rarely leaves remote town of Surgut. Avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth. A professional driller, he was appointed chief executive of Surgutneftegas at 33. In early 1990s privatized the company with his fellow managers. Company announced late last year that it would cut oil production due to lowered demand; in good position though, has accumulated $16 billion in cash, more than any other Russian oil company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemical engineer grandfather John T. Dorrance developed method of canning condensed soup that used half as much water, reduced costs by a third. Result: Campbell Soup Co. Today world's biggest soupmaker. Sales: $8 billion in 2008. Earnings slumped in latest quarter as consumers wait longer to restock their cabinets. Stock down 28% in past six months. Publicly traded firm also controls Pace (salsa), Pepperidge Farm (Goldfish, crackers), Prego (spaghetti sauce).

name: Billionaires
bio: Faltering lumber industry chopping down Emmerson's fortune; timberland values have fallen 15% since August. Sierra Pacific reportedly cutting jobs, scaling back benefits. Father, Curly, owned a lumber mill. Archie took Sierra Pacific public 1969, private again 4 years later. Bought 522,000 acres of Santa Fe Southern Pacific Railroad timberland with a $460 million loan in 1988. Today company owns 1.7 million acres of timberland in California and Washington; nation's second-largest lumber producer by volume. Wears jeans, drives pickup truck. Son Mark handles finances.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soaring, then plunging, commodity prices have taken Forrest on the wild ride of a lifetime. The one-time stockbroker and keen amateur boxer started his first mining company Anaconda Nickel (now called Minara) in 1994.  Then hitched his fortune to an iron ore mine in the rugged Pilbara region of Australia's north-west. He founded Fortescue Metals Group in 2003, in which he has a 35% controlling interest. His net worth peaked at $12.7 billion in June 2008 when the mining stock hit its all-time high; by the time we locked in stockprices in February, his fortune had dropped $10.8 billion. Known by his school boy nickname "Twiggy," Forrest is a descendant of the first premier of the state of West Australia, Lord Forrest of Bunbury. Former stockbroker has donated millions to combat poverty and alcoholism among Aborigines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-chief investment officer of the bond-centric Pimco Total Return Fund--now the world's largest mutual fund with $140 billion in assets. Predicted housing meltdown two years ago, trimmed exposure to mortgage-backed securities. Result: fund up 2.8% in past 12 months as the rest of the world's markets crashed. Believes troubled banks are too numerous for the government to successfully nationalize all of them: "The U.S. isn't Sweden, and not just because our blondes aren't au naturel." Arranged gambling pools while studying at Duke; spent a summer working the slots at Harrah's in Lake Tahoe. Vegas stint playing blackjack turned $200 into $10,000 in just 4 months. Vietnam vet; earned M.B.A. from UCLA. Fixed-income pioneer one of first to trade bonds for profit. Oversaw $10 million portfolio at Pacific Life in 1973. Bond division spun off, public in 1994. Later sold to Allianz AG for $4.7 billion.
title: Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Pacific Investment Management Company LLC', 'title': 'Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Quit Moscow for London a couple of years ago after trouble with the government. At end of 2006, was accused of violating terms of his oil license and failure to pay taxes. Gutseriev, who denies the charges, sold his oil firm, RussNeft, to billionaire Oleg Deripaska and left the country. Russia, which apparently wants him for fraud and money laundering, is seeking extradition and reportedly alerted interpol. Born in Kazakhstan, where his Ingush family had been deported after World War II. Later became president of state oil company Slavneft. In 2002 was dismissed before privatization, but was able to return to big oil: over four year period, Swiss trader Glencore helped him buy a number of small Russian oil firms, which he united into RussNeft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stockbroker's son invested $4,000 to set up cable company with frat brother 1963. Brought cable programming to rural cities. Continental Cablevision grew into nation's largest privately held cable firm; sold to US West for $11 billion in 1996. Bought back company, renamed MediaOne. Flipped to AT&T for $58 billion 3 years later. Today chairs investment firm Pilot House Associates; owns $85 million stake in Energy Transfer Equity. With partners, sold telecommunications firm Aloha Partners -- then the largest owner of 700 megahertz radio frequency -- for $2.5 billion in 2007. Invested in GlobalPost, a syndicated news service that provides newspapers and websites outsourced international coverage via a network of part-time foreign correspondents.
title: Chair

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharmaceuticals titan's fortune flat in the past 12 months despite economic turmoil; claims to have held much of his portfolio in cash and low-risk securities rather than risky equities. Korean War vet earned law degree at night from DePaul U. Became sales rep for Miles Laboratories. Partnered with Phillip Frost 1972; acquired Key Pharmaceuticals. Increased sales 100-fold with top asthma drug and cardiovascular patch; merged with Schering-Plough for $836 million in 1986. Launched Kos Pharmaceuticals 1988; took public 9 years later. Dominated market with cholesterol-lowering drug Niaspan. Sold to Abbott Labs in 2006 for $4.2 billion. Donated to Hillary Clinton's presidential bid; also gives to Metropolitan Museum of Art and Tufts U.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Fisk earned 3 master's degrees, Ph.D. in physics from Cornell, now runs S.C. Johnson, maker of Pledge, Raid, Windex, Ziploc, Glade. Company crusading for environment despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Kids each attended Sam's alma mater, Cornell, before joining company. Company crusading for environment despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Kids each attended Sam's alma mater, Cornell, before joining company. Heads industrial cleaning arm JohnsonDiversey. Company crusading for environment despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Kids each attended Sam's alma mater, Cornell, before joining company. Helen runs Johnson Financial and Johnson Outdoors; publicly traded camping and military supplier shares down more than 70% in past 12 months. Company crusading for environment despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Winnie oversees family foundation. Company crusading for environment despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, Fadesa Inmobiliaria. Took company public in April 2004; sold his 55% stake in company to real estate group Martinsa for $3 billion in September 2006, just before collapse of the Spanish real estate bubble. Holds 5% stake in Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, one of Spain's largest banks. Collects art from Spanish province of Galicia; enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Greek immigrants founded Mitchell Energy & Development in 1946. Wildcatter made fortune in North Texas gas fields. Sold to Devon Energy for $3.5 billion in cash and stock 2001. At time of acquisition Mitchell Energy was one of largest producers of natural gas, producing 55,000 barrels a day. Devon stock down 60% since last March. Invested cash in real estate: owns Bald Head Island in North Carolina, hotels in Galveston. Nature enthusiast continues to donate to alma mater Texas A&M after his $35 million donation in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of conglomerate Hong Leong Group Malaysia gets biggest part of fortune from stake in its investment holding company, Guoco Group. Has other interests in financial services, property development and hotels across Southeast Asia. Just acquired a 3% stake in Intercontinental Hotels Group. Shares control of massive Hong Leong Group with Singaporean cousin, Kwek Leng Beng, and Kwek’s family. Inherited fortune from his father, one of 3 brothers who started a small banking group in the 1920s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sole heir to once deeply troubled estate left by late father. Battled for 14 years to win control of his assets from her stepmother. Legal hurdles cleared in 2003 in time to catch boom in iron ore demand. In late 2007, after decades of promise, Rinehart's family company, Hancock Prospecting, shipped its first ton of iron ore as part of a joint venture with mining giant Rio Tinto. Her Hancock is reportedly scouting for a Chinese partner in upcoming iron ore and coal mine projects; lobbying Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd to allow cheap Asian labor into Australia; Rival miner Cazaly Resources and fellow  billionaire Andrew Forrest teaming up in effort to wrest rights held by Rio Tinto and Hancock to iron ore deposit Rhodes Ridge. Claim Rinehart team failed to develop site under Australia's "use it or lose it" clause.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable news pioneer sold remaining stake in Time Warner 2006, retired from company's board. Now focused on philanthropy, real estate, restaurant business. Has donated more than $1.5 billion to charity. Recently launched $200 million campaign to fight malaria in Africa through United Nations Foundation; also supports Nuclear Threat Initiative, Turner Endangered Species Fund. Largest individual landowner in the United States owns 2 million acres across 12 states and Argentina. Also commands 50,000 bison. Ted's Montana Grill serves bison burgers in 19 states, 57 locations. Released autobiography "Call Me Ted" in November.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of United Overseas Bank, the largest in Singapore, was educated in mainland China. Son Wee Ee Chong is now chief executive after Wee stepped down in 2007 after 33 years at helm; his father founded the bank in 1935. Family also owns large land bank in Singapore. Avid tennis player. Set up the Wee Foundation earlier this year; family donated $30 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Launched Wahaha as a mini grocery story in a school in 1987. Still runs company, which is now China's biggest beverage producer with $3.8 billion in sales in 2007. Wahaha and rivals such as Taiwan-owned Tingyi have been thriving as consumer spending in China has boomed amid rapid Its joint-venture partner Groupe Danone has accused Wahaha of contract violations and illegal use of Wahaha trademark; an estimated 30 lawsuits have been filed in 7 countries. Wahaha denies the allegations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of college and founded a trading outfit 20 years ago. Now his Adani Group has interests in power, infrastructure and edible oils. Owns and operates Mundra Port, India’s largest in private sector, which listed in 2007. Also owns country’s biggest special economic zone, after recently securing government permission to merge three zones on the western coast.  Plans to invest $9 billion in power plants scaled down after company postponed listing its power subsidiary. Survived last November’s militant attack on Taj Mahal Hotel in Mumbai, where he was dining with a client.

name: Billionaires
bio: Loses position as richest Ukrainian billionaire as commodity prices tank. His iron and steel holding company Metinvest is feeling brunt of downturn with sales of finished products down by 50%. 'Rescheduling' its planned $15 billion, 5-year investment program; but going ahead with acquisition of U.S. miner United Coal, though rumored to be renegotiating the $2.5 billion price. His energy company, DTEK, is also looking to buy companies worth between $50 million and $500 million in coal and power generation sectors of Russia, Ukraine and Eastern Europe. Son of a coal miner, built his business in the mid-1990s by forging ties with then prime minister Viktor Yanukovych. After his ally lost 2004 presidential election had his key asset, Ukraine's largest steel company, Kryvorizhstal, reprivatized. Presidential elections scheduled for 2010 may put Yanukovych back in power; Akhmetov also rumored to be contender. Says that downturn will not stop him from spending $150 million on charity during next 5 years; also funding his Effective Governance Foundation to the tune of $50 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over family's auto assets, including UAE's exclusive Toyota distribution, when he parted ways with brother, mall magnate and fellow billionaire Majid Al Futtaim, in 2000. May be regretting the decision: shopping remains Dubai's national pastime while auto sales wane worldwide. Has small retail foothold: owns licenses for popular brands Toys R Us, Marks & Spencer and Ikea. Real estate holdings struggling as economy has soured; signature project, the 1,300-acre megacity "Dubailand," facing possible delays with its $2.2 billion Universal City, originally planned as one the world's largest theme parks.

name: Billionaires
bio: New disclosure rules for Saudi Arabia's stock exchange revealed Al Issa to be one of the largest individual shareholders in the market. Controls significant stakes in 2 of the kingdom's financial giants, Banque Saudi Fransi and Riyad Bank, as well as food-focused conglomerate Savola, operator of popular HyperPanda chain of supermarkets. Also active investor in Saudi's nascent tourism sector: last year signed management contracts for 2 Jeddah hotels, one with British hotelier Rocco Forte for new boutique property and one with Kempinski for a 5-star "green" resort.

name: Billionaires
bio: With 3 billionaire brothers, Sulaiman, Saleh and Mohammed, built small desert money-changing business into world's largest Islamic Bank, Al Rajhi Bank. His 6% stake down by nearly half over past year despite fact that sharia-compliant bank's ban on interest-earning loans helped shield it from credit crunch fallout. Also owns stake in fellow Islamic banking billionaire Saleh Kamel's Albaraka Group. Other investments include cement, Syrian banking, beverage packaging and a mattress factory. Recently backed startup private bank trying to promote cross-investment between Gulf and the West.

name: Billionaires
bio: Barber's son was high school valedictorian, Eagle Scout; as a child sold popcorn in Minnesota. Earned $14 a week working nights at an aircraft factory while playing ice hockey at UCLA; graduated Phi Beta Kappa. Harvard M.B.A., Loyola law degree. Studied for C.P.A. exam in spare time as naval officer during World War II. Founded law firm in 1953, Ace Beverage 3 years later. Earned exclusive rights to distribute Budweiser in parts of Los Angeles. Now oversees more than 40 subsidiaries in agriculture, insurance, auto dealerships, manufacturing. Portfolio includes 4 million square feet of real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime go-between for major oil companies and state-owned oilfields in the Gulf settled in Britain in 1980 after fleeing the late Saddam Hussein's Iraq. His General Mediterranean Holdings today owns 3 dozen hotel and office properties in France, U.K., the Middle East and Chicago; also invests in construction, pharmaceuticals and finance companies. Wired $3.5 million in April 2005 to Chicago developer and pal Antoin (Tony) Rezko, the Syrian-born businessman who helped raise money for Senator Barack Obama's early political campaigns and was convicted last year on fraud and extortion charges. Also owns Team Lebanon of A1 Grand Prix Race series.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up in France and Switzerland; late father, Heinz, was once the world's largest Picasso collector. Studied business at NYU. Took first job buying and selling real estate for Bass brothers. Founded own private investment firm 1986 (later renamed Berggruen Holdings). Bought stake in Portugal's Media Capital for $9 million 1992; sold shares to Prisa for $150 million after taking it public 2006. Invested $8 million in eyewear outfit FGX 2000, pocketed $200 million cash after selling part of stake to other investors, taking the rest public. Recently created three special-purpose acquisition companies (spacs); raised $2.6 billion to buy and sell companies, reap big rewards for shareholders. First spac took GLG Partners hedge fund public June 2007; shares down 80% since. Once shy investor ramping up public image; claims P.R. campaign will help with "deal flow" and philanthropic endeavors. Today invests in art, real estate, private equity. Owns Indian hotel chain, Turkish wind-power licenses, Israeli real estate, 9 vocational colleges in U.S. Homeless: sold apartments in New York, London, Los Angeles; lives exclusively in hotels. Has seen net worth decline $700 million since September.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother, Edgar Sr., inherited Seagram spirits empire that was built up by their father, Sam, and sold to Vivendi in 2000. His Andrea & Charles Bronfman Philanthropies, which annually gives $15 million to a host of causes, was one of few major Jewish charities not directly affected by Bernard Madoff’s $50 billion Ponzi scheme. Helped found Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youths from North America on educational tours of Israel. Started the Andy Prize in memory of his late wife, Andrea, who was killed by a taxi while walking their dog near their Manhattan apartment in January 2006; prize awarded annually to an Israeli decorative artist for excellence in ceramics, jewelry, textile or glass. Got married for a third time in September in a Manhattan ceremony.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ningbo-born entrepreneur moved to Hong Kong in 1949. Made early fortune in textiles. Delisted his Nan Fung Textile 1989; moved into real estate and became still richer. Today his Nan Fung Group has stakes in Singapore billionaire Ng Teng Fong's Sino Land and in Hong Kong's Lai Sun Development. Apparently partnered with Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong on some projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Merged his staffing company French Ecco with Klaus Jacobs' Swiss Adia in 1996 to create Adecco. Now one of world's largest employment agencies, with $29 billion in sales. Per Swiss law, stepped down as co-chairman of Adecco in 2005 at age 73 and is now honorary president. Keeps busy on the boards of Akila Finance and security systems provider Securitas. Lives as a tax exile in London. Partner Klaus Jacobs died in September 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Replaced as chairman of steel giant Evraz in December by fellow billionaire Alexander Abramov with whom he cofounded the group; Frolov remains chief executive. Stock has fallen almost 90% in past year. He and Abramov bought a stake in Highlands Gold Mining in January  from billionaire Roman Abramovich,  large Evraz shareholder. Had sold part of his Evraz holdings to Abramovich back in 2006. Got start working as research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy. Has a Ph.D. in physics and mathematics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded temporary employment agency Randstad Holding in 1960. Took company public in 1990. Last summer Randstad merged with Dutch group Vedior to form world's second-largest temp agency with combined revenues of more than $22 billion. Although retired, Goldschmeding remains vice chairman of the supervisory board and still owns 44%. Enjoys sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard Business School grad became friends with Warren Buffett in 1962. Early investor in Berkshire Hathaway; today owns 10,000 shares worth $900 million. Founded investment advisory firm First Manhattan 1964; assets were $10 billion as of January, down from $14 billion a year earlier. On Berkshire board. With wife, Ruth, donated $25 million to Yeshiva University medical school last year.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'First Manhattan Co.', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Midea Group, household appliance maker he founded 23 years ago. Sales of group, which makes residential and commercial air conditioners, washing machines, exceeded $13 billion in 2008. Owns 24% of popular appliance maker Wuxi Little Swan, known for its washing machines. Midea Group is building a new 420-feet-tall corporate headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Bronson Ingram became chairman of Ingram Industries in 1995. Bronson and his siblings inherited his father's oil-and-barge business 1963. Today Nashville company is one of the nation's largest distributors of books, print on demand. Merged book and print-on-demand divisions in June to form Ingram Lightning Group. Son David runs spinoff Ingram Entertainment: distributor of DVDs, video games. Original barge business chaired by son Orrin; president, chief executive of Ingram Industries. Son John chairman for entire operation. Martha remains on board as chairman emerita; Vassar grad and performing arts buff prominent in Nashville society. Also chairs Vanderbilt University Board of Trust, the largest non-government employer in Nashville.
title: Former Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ingram Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Former Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Jackson's fortune is down $400 million in a year, but recession victims continue to raise a glass; his vineyards and wine business still bring in nearly $1.3 billion in sales each year. Grew up during Depression; became farmer. Planted grapevines on 80-acre pear and walnut orchard in California 1970s. First Kendall-Jackson wine on market 1982. Now produces more than 4 million cases of vino a year on 14,000 planted acres. Committee of Sonoma County Supervisors recently approved Kendall-Jackson bid for new winery/tasting room in Knights Valley, Calif. Owns 80% of 2007 Preakness champ Curlin; judge blocked his attempt to buy out remaining interest in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Matriarch chairs privately held media giant Bennett, Coleman & Co. run by her sons Samir and Vineet. Group publishes such leading newspapers as The Times Of India and the Economic Times. Also owns FM radio stations and television channels Times Now and Zoom. Last June acquired U.K.’s Virgin Radio for $76 million, renaming it Absolute Radio. Launch of new business television channel ET Now is imminent.  Chairs Times Foundation, group’s philanthropic arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: While student at University of Waterloo, launched Research In Motion, now among Canada's largest and most successful high-tech companies. Though President Barack Obama glamorized company's BlackBerry brand by being the first U.S. President to be tech-connected, firm's stock price has fallen two-thirds since reaching a record high in June 2008. In February Ontario Securities Commission ordered Lazaridis along with fellow billionaire and Co-chief Executive James Balsillie and Chief Operating Officer Dennis Kavelman to pay $62 million to settle backdated options case; several days later all 3 were charged with same offense by the U.S. Securities & Exchange Commission. Lazaridis founded Waterloo's Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in 1999; has since donated $150 million to the quantum physics research institute. Chancellor of University of Waterloo.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1981, took over L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB, which his father Lars founded in 1944 as a construction company.  Today the $3.3 billion (sales) diversified holding company concentrates on property management and investments; has about 150 properties in its portfolio.  Enjoys hunting and curling; was once a junior world champion of curling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime architect led investor buyout of previously state-owned oil company, Rompetrol, in 1998; took over as chief executive in 2001. Via acquisitions built the company into a $4.6 billion (sales) multinational refiner. In 2007 sold 75% of the group to Kazakhstan's state-owned energy operator, KazMunaiGaz; remains at the helm. Investing in real estate; in January bought Fabian Romania, a U.K.-listed property fund via his Black Sea Global Properties. Owns Adevarul Holding media trust, which publishes Forbes Romania under license from Forbes Media LLC. Former parliamentarian is member and key backer of the Romanian Liberal Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned fortune building up energy conglomerate Perez Companc, which he later sold to Petrobras for $1 billion in 2002. Now controls big stake in food giant Molinos Rio de la Plata, diversified maker of pasta, flour and frozen vegetables. Currently spending $15 million to build a meat-processing plant capable of slaughtering 25,000 head of cattle each year. At wife Maria Carmen's urging, launched ice cream parlor chain Munchi's.

name: Billionaires
bio: Civil engineer, holds 12% of Spain's largest construction company, $27.6 billion (sales) Actividades de Construccion y Servicios S.A., which he has headed since 1993. Well known in Spain as onetime president of popular Real Madrid soccer club, once the team of stars like David Beckham and Zinedine Zidane; ran club from 2000 to 2006. Resigned in February 2006 after string of defeats.

name: Billionaires
bio: NYU grad took over father Joseph's Brooklyn pharmacy. Formed generic-drug distributor Kinray after dropping out of law school 1975. Today company is the largest independent pharmaceuticals and generics distributor in the world. Highly automated operation supplies more than 3,000 independent pharmacies in 8 northeastern states. "Stewie Rah Rah" entertains celebrity, model friends with lavish summer barbecues at his 25-acre Hamptons estate. Donated $2 million to Columbia Medical Center, benefits eating disorder prevention. Supports Make-A-Wish foundation, Friends of the Israel Defense Forces, Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recession dampening demand for tasty treats. Dad, Robert Sr. (d. 2006), parlayed soy-based whipped cream, nondairy coffee creamer into frozen food empire. Bob Jr. became president of Rich Products 1978. David inherited 56% when Sr. passed away. Sales: $2.8 billion. Today company makes more than 2,000 food products: toppings, desserts, pizzas, breads. Cashing in on China's growing middle class with 3 factories supplying Asian customers with Western desserts. Hollywood making movie out of his memoir, "Fish Fights." Owns Buffalo Bison minor league baseball team; squad became the New York Mets Triple-A team in September.

name: Billionaires
bio: Net worth down 28% in six months as property values decline. Vietnam vet's Majestic Realty one of country's largest commercial builders; owns 70 million square feet in Los Angeles, Denver, Las Vegas and Dallas. Built Staples Center arena in Los Angeles with Philip Anschutz; also owns stakes in pro basketball's L.A. Lakers, hockey's L.A. Kings. Unveiled plans last April for 75,000-seat stadium to be completed by 2011 NFL season in hopes of luring a team to Los Angeles. USC grad donated $23 million to alma mater's fine arts school in 2006.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Majestic Realty, Co.', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 40% of $11 billion (sales) Helm AG, which has interests in trading, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. Became chairman of executive board in 1984 when father, Hermann, the companyÍs founder, retired. Dad still owns other 60%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ebay's first president and full-time employee is no longer involved in the company; now focuses on inspiring social action by launching entrepreneurs through his Skoll Foundation and producing movies through Participant Media. Backed the Oscar-winning film, An Inconvenient Truth, the global-warming documentary that featured former Vice President Al Gore. On tap for 2009: The Soloist, starring Robert Downey Jr. and Jamie Foxx, and The Informant, with Matt Damon. Skoll pumped gas in Toronto before getting an M.B.A. from Stanford in 1995. Received Producers Guild of America's Visionary Award in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cambridge-educated humanities professor at left teaching gig at San Jose U. to start for-profit University of Phoenix 1970s. Firm became Apollo Group; went public 1994. Today enrolls more than 380,000 students in more than 100 programs for associate, bachelor's, master's degrees online or in classroom. Son, Peter, serves as vice chairman. Benefiting from recession as the unemployed workers look to retool their job skills. Shares up 22% in the past 12 months. Company has faced numerous lawsuits in recent years; fined $10 million for allegedly violated Higher Education Act by paying its recruiters based on number of students they enrolled.

name: Billionaires
bio: In March 2003 the Stroher family sold their almost 80% stake in Wella AG, the world's biggest professional hair care group, to Proctor & Gamble for $4 billion.  Silvia Stroher's $1 billion share made this great-granddaughter of the company founder a very wealthy woman. She and her husband, a former male nurse, have a well-known collection of contemporary German art that includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer..

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Ursalib, upped his stake in the financial services firm in fall 2008. Is building a chain of luxury clinics called Metaclinic; already has a homeopathy clinic and cosmetics distributor. Former air force lieutenant colonel and a veteran of the Afghan war; met Leonid Fedun, also a former military officer, who was a privatization consultant for Lukoil. After setting up Nikoil (later renamed Uralsib) in partnership with other top Lukoil managers such as Vagit Alekperov, Tsvetkov helped them gain a controlling stake in the oil company; for his services was rewarded with a sizable Lukoil stake. Still sits on the oil firm's board but has since sold most of the stake; retains less than 1%. Passionate about Eastern philosophy and yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine-born oil and aluminum baron continues deal-making in chemicals, power plants, gas storage despite severe losses in his largest assets. Oil company TNK-BP shares down 63% over past year; an eight month power struggle finally resolved when chief executive was removed and new management put in place. Former German chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder, who has ties with Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, joining board. Things even shakier at aluminum giant, UC Rusal, which he formed with fellow billionaire, Oleg Deripaska, when they merged their companies. Firm's debts add up to $16.3 billion: $7 billion to foreign banks, $6.5 billion to Russian banks, and $2.8 billion owed to Russian richest man, Mikhail Prokhorov, for a 25% stake in Norilsk Nickel. Bankruptcy, nationalization and even sale to Chinese investors rumors are swirling. Meanwhile shares of Swiss electronics maker Oerlicon, in which Vekselberg holds a 33% stake, have fallen more than 90%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded YTL Corp., one of Malaysia's largest conglomerates, with interests in construction, utilities, hotels, property development and technology. Son Francis runs YTL's daily operations. YTL, which has nearly $3 billion in cash, bought a majority in Macquarie Prime Real Estate Investment Trust in December 2008, thus gaining control of 2 Singapore landmarks, Wisma Atria and Ngee Ann City, as well as 7 properties in Tokyo and Chengdu, China. Also announced in December plans to buy PowerSeraya, Singapore's second-largest power generator, from Temasek Holdings for $2.4 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-chief executive of Research In Motion, now among Canada's largest and most successful high-tech companies. Though President Barack Obama glamorized company's BlackBerry brand by being the first U.S. President to be tech-connected; firm's stock price has fallen two-thirds since reaching a record high in June. In February Ontario Securities Commission ordered Balsillie along with fellow billionaire and Co-chief Executive Mike Lazaridis and Chief Operating Officer Dennis Kavelman to pay $62 million to settle backdated options case; several days later all 3 were charged for same offense by the U.S. Securities & Exchange Commission. Avid cyclist teamed up with 7-time Tour de France winner Lance Armstrong to cycle for cancer donations; helped raise over $1.3 million last year. Supports Waterloo Regional Children's Museum and donates to other causes like Lazaridis' Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $3 billion (sales) Hubert Burda Media Holding, which publishes well-known German magazines such as Focus, Bunte and Freundin. Burda's early bet on internet is helping company compete in a difficult sector. Committed philanthropist: supports the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German literature;  established the Felix Burda Foundation, committed to reducing the mortality rate of colon cancer in Germany; formed the Burda Academy of the Third Millennium, an inter-disciplinary forum for researchers and thinkers.  Holds the Leo Baeck Prize for his efforts to bring together Jewish and non-Jewish communities in Germany. Recently awarded the Federal Cross of Merit. Married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwangler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied accounting at U. of Southern California; traded bean counting for real estate 1975 with $1,000 savings. Now owns 209,000 square feet of office space, 3,100 luxury apartments across the U.S. Majority of Casden Properties bought by Aimco in 2002 for $2.4 billion. Recently completed high-end mixed-use development featuring 350 luxury rental homes in Westwood Village in Los Angeles. Claims to have reaped more than $400 million in net profits. Partners with Cerberus Real Estate in other California projects. Fortune down $600 million in past 6 months as property values decline. Recently contributed to Museum of Tolerance in L.A.; proceeds were used to build a re-creation of Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal's office. Developing 400-foot White City Tower in Tel Aviv. Appointed by former President George W. Bush to United States Holocaust Memorial Council in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family emigrated from Greece when he was 6 months old; family settled in Harlem, dad became a busboy. Worked as a grocery store clerk while attending NYU; dropped out after a friend offered him a chance to buy a piece of the store. Opened first grocery store at 100th St. and Broadway 1969; owned 10 stores by age 24, made $25 million a year in revenue. Plowed $5 million into Manhattan real estate 1977; property worth $100 million 5 years later. Today his Red Apple Group owns hundreds of millions' worth of property; New York's Gristedes grocery chain. Stumbled upon Chapter 11 proceedings of United Refining Company; purchased oil refiner's stock for $7.5 million. Today firm owns 372 gas stations, Pennsylvania refinery. Took blank check company United Refining Energy Corp. public in December 2007; raised $450 million hoping to grab an energy company as asset prices dwindled. Now trying to buy bankrupt SemGroup; energy transport outfit sued him in February, accusing him of trying to "hijack" their reorganization plans. Prospects for running for mayor of New York crushed last fall after Gotham's City Council approved law allowing billionaire Michael Bloomberg to run for a third term.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dolan's Cablevision stock shot up following company's $30 million dividend last August; shares down 65% since. Company wrote down newspaper assets by more than $400 million last Fall. Selling high-yield bonds to pay off debt; $1.25 billion raised so far in 2009. Family's stake in Cablevision worth $1 billion. Attempted to take company private in 2005: initial $7.9 billion offer eventually swelled to $10.6 billion by 2007; final offer blocked by shareholders. Inventor's son founded network that became Home Box Office. Traded channel with the old Time Inc. for a cable company with 1,500 Long Island customers in 1973. Became Cablevision; today serves 3 million. Company owns Radio City Music Hall, basketball's New York Knicks, hockey's New York Rangers. Hoping to best rival Verizon FiOs with roll-out of free WiFi network for Tri-State customers; plan will cost $300 million over next two years.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Cablevision Systems Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Air Force flight surgeon took HCA, nation's largest hospital operator, private with Bain Capital, KKR and Merrill Lynch in 2006. At the time the $33 billion leveraged buyout was the largest in history; eclipsed by $45 billion purchase of power giant TXU four months later. "Being private in these times is a blessing. The timing couldn't have been better." Founded Hospital Corp. of America with father and Jack Massey 1968; took public following year. Led management buyout 1989; took public again 3 years later. Merged with Richard Rainwater's 1994, became chief exec again 3 years later. Nashville native left board in January, now focused on philanthropy through family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold drug manufacturer Ivax to Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005; today owns $850 million in Teva stock. Teva, world's largest generic-drug maker, acquired rival Barr Pharmaceuticals for $7.5 billion last July. Studied French literature at U. of Pennsylvania. Took over Key Pharmaceuticals with partner Michael Jaharis; created new delivery systems for old drugs. Sold to Schering-Plough in 1986; founded Ivax the following year. Chairs the boards of Ladenburg Thalmann, Opko Health; also on Smithsonian board. Enjoys gardening.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Victor, runs Li & Fung, firm supplying fashions, furnishings and toys to retailers, including Wal-Mart, Target. Has 10,000 suppliers worldwide. Firm raised half a billion in September. Biggest creditor of KB Toys, which went bankrupt in December and owes Li & Fung $5 million. Stock dropped 58% in 2008. In late February paid $80 million to take over Liz Claiborne’s ailing global distribution network. The company will now be supplying Liz Claiborne brands such as Lucky Brand, Juicy Couture and Kate Spade to retailers around the world. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take helm 1970s. William is managing director, Victor chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started clove company Djarum in 1950. After he died in 1963 sons took over and turned it into Indonesia's second-largest maker of clove cigarettes after the Wonowidjojo family's Gudang Garam. Now bulk of fortune comes from country's second-largest bank, Bank Central Asia, in which they have 50% stake. Their biggest real estate project, Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, residence, office tower and hotel complex, opened late last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started clove company Djarum in 1950. After he died in 1963 sons took over and turned it into Indonesia's second-largest maker of clove cigarettes after the Wonowidjojo family's Gudang Garam. Now bulk of fortune comes from country's second-largest bank, Bank Central Asia, in which they have 50% stake. Their biggest real estate project, Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, residence, office tower and hotel complex, opened late last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune down $700 million as media industry suffers advertising meltdown. Hearst Corp may close or sell Northern California's largest paper, San Francisco Chronicle, which reportedly lost $50 million last year. Also put Seattle Post-Intelligencer up for sale in January after years of losses; paper will fold if a buyer isn't found. Grandson of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William's father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who 'won' failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation's largest newspaper chain via sensational 'yellow' journalism. Infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspaper (Houston Chronicle) and magazine (Cosmopolitan, Esquire) divisions, cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E). Also TV, radio stations. Longtime chief exec Victor F. Ganzi resigned suddenly last June amid reports of clashes with Hearst family over direction of the company; replacement Frank Bennack Jr. has since appointed several new executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger sister Alicia, also a billionaire, inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. Their husbands ran FCC from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The  sisters then ran the company jointly  until 1997 when Esther bought her sister's stake for $800 million. Now owns 45% of $18.6 billion (sales) FCC;  sits on its supervisory board.  Holds the Gold Cross for Social Solidarity for her social work; her Esther Koplowitz foundation, supports and houses the mentally and physically impaired. Member of Spanish nobility, she is married to Fernando Falco, Marques de Cubas, scion of an old Spanish family. Apparently loves ballet and classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $5.5 billion (sales) HCL Group, which he cofounded in 1976 as a garage startup, built India’s first microcomputer, precursor to the PC. Expanded into software services; clients include Boeing and Nokia. Undeterred by financial turmoil, went on an acquisition streak last year, outbidding Infosys Technologies to snatch London-listed IT consulting firm Axon, for $700 million. In quarter ended December snatched contracts worth an incredible $1 billion. Hosted annual customer event in Florida last November attended by 600 guests with Al Gore as keynote speaker. Nadar was conferred the Padma Bhushan, among India’s highest civilian honors in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: After father's death in 2005 became sole owner of candy company Storck GmbH, makers of Werther's Original, Riesen, Toffifee, and others. Fourth generation of his family to run the $1.9 billion (sales) group. Company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve Germany's endangered stork population.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blackstone cofounder traded private equity for philanthropy: has pledged more than $1 billion to his Peter G. Peterson foundation. Goal: to educate Americans about dangers of balooning budget deficit. Son of a Greek immigrant graduated summa cum laude from Northwestern University. Appointed secretary of commerce by Nixon 1972. Tapped to run Lehman Brothers a year later. With Stephen Schwarzman, founded Blackstone Group in 1985 with $400,000 balance sheet; diversified into real estate, hedge funds. Firm now manages $95 billion. Went public June 2007; stock down 85% since. Retired from Blackstone in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founding patriarch of Egypt's most famous business dynasty saw shares in primary holding, Orascom Construction Industries, plunge 80% over past year; remains chair. His 3 sons run construction, telecommunications and tourism divisions. Studied agriculture in college after lawyer father urged him to pursue farming. Found it boring, instead opened a small contracting firm in Upper Egypt. Construction baron forced to rebuild empire after it was nationalized by Nasser in 1960s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State law school dropout started women's sportswear store in 1963 with $5,000 loan from aunt. Took Limited Brands public 1969. Today company owns Victoria's Secret, Bath & Body Works, C.O. Bigelow, La Senza, White Barn Candle and Henri Bendel brands. Less people perusing aisles last year. Stock down 70% in the past six months. Sold 75% interest in Express brand to Golden State Capital for $600 million in 2007 to focus on higher-margin lingerie, beauty product operations. Supports Jewish causes with wife, Abigail, via Wexner Foundation. Elected chairman of Ohio State's Board of Trustees in February.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Limited Brands', 'uri': 'companies/limited-brands', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Started selling signs at 13. Dropped out of U. of Nebraska to join Merchant Marine Academy. Served in South Pacific during WWII. Took over family&#39s Whiteco Industries in 1946. Turned it into billboard, real estate empire. Sold billboard division to Chancellor Media Corp. for $960 million 1998. "At that price, what the heck?" Sold 100 hotels to Robert Johnson for $1.7 billion 2006. Unloaded heaps of real estate in early 2008 before prices fell.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fronted family friend Fred DeLuca $1,000 to open Pete's Super Submarines 1965. Shop tanked; DeLuca opened a second outlet to give illusion of success. Sold first franchise 1974. Today there are 30,000 Subway sub stores across the globe. Created healthy buzz with infamous Jared commercials claiming formerly obese airline worker lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Revenues last year: $12.9 billion.
title: Co-Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief of Caudwell Group, the U.K. mobile phone giant best known for its Phones4U brand. Cashed out in 2006: sold his 85% stake in the group for $2.3 billion. Avid sportsman now spends time in more active pursuits: In 2007 was one of 200 people to climb to Mount Everest base camp as part of a medical experiment to test the effects of altitude on the body. Donated $1 million to fund the project called Caudwell X-treme Everest. Former Michelin engineer entered cell phone business in 1987. Sold only 26 phones in first 8 months from his store in Hartshill Stoke-on-Trent. Caudwell Group sales reached $3.6 billion in 2005, the last year he headed the company. Now spends most of his time raising money for his Caudwell Children charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Running shoe tycoon's fortune sprained as retail markets stumble. Estimated net worth down 35% since last August. New Balance Arch founded in 1906 to correct orthopedic foot problems. Bought company on day of Boston Marathon 1972; company had 6 employees. Shunned expensive endorsement deals with high-profile athletes, focused on selling comfort and performance to die-hard runners. Sales exceeded $1.6 billion in 2007; company makes 25% of its shoes in U.S. Expanding business to athletic equipment (lacrosse, hockey, soccer); bought Vital Apparel Group last December.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Family friend Peter Buck fronted DeLuca $1,000 to open Pete's Super Submarines 1965. Shop tanked; DeLuca opened a second outlet to give illusion of success. Sold first franchise 1974. Today there are 30,000 Subway sub stores across the globe. Created healthy buzz with infamous Jared commercials claiming formerly obese airline worker lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Revenues last year: $12.9 billion.
title: President and Co-Founder
employment: {'name': "Doctor's Associates (Subway)", 'title': 'President and Co-Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother William, heads global export trading firm Li & Fung; connects Chinese factories with U.S. retailers, making up two-thirds of its global sales. Supplys toys and clothing to Wal-Mart; other clients include Target, Disney. Gloomy export outlook has shares down 25% since last September. Firm purchased Liz Claiborne's sourcing business for $83 million cash in February. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started distribution company a century ago in Guangzhou, China; sold porcelain, silk. Victor named chairman of International Chamber of Commerce last July; urged governments to avoid protectionist policies that will eliminate rather than save jobs: "Getting global trade flowing again is the best means to restart growth and help us out of the recession."

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Fujian Province, Hui is one of China's largest property barons. Owns properties in Beijing, on Nanjing Road and in Fujian Province; opened Hyatt on the Bund, overlooking Shanghai's financial district. Lost more than half his fortune in past year as shares of his property developer, Shimao Holdings, plunged, leading Standard & Poor's to lower its credit rating. Diversifying, Hui bought stake in minerals firm Bel Global Resources in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Entrepreneur who built Quanta Computer, into world's largest notebook computer maker; remains chairman. Company churns out machines for Hewlett-Packard, Dell, others. Patron of arts is director of Cloud Gate Dance Theater. Company's shares little changed in past year amid strong demand for low-cost computers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley real estate titan's fortune down $200 million since September amid recession. Son of a Bank of America executive converted California farmland into valuable Silicon Valley office space during the 1960s with lifelong partner John Arrillaga. Sold offices to tenants Google and Cisco, created cities of Mountain View and Sunnyvale. Sold half of their portfolio in 2005; the next year made $1.1 billion selling more than 5 million square feet of office space and research facilities. Devout Mormon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Executive chairman of Alliance Boots, European pharmaceutical retailer; faces slackening demand as consumers pinch pennies. Going ahead with plan to merge company's 300-store chain of eye shops with competitor Dollond & Aitchison, creating the second-biggest optician in the U.K. Nuclear engineer turned his family's ailing Naples drug wholesaler into Alliance UniChem Group, which merged with U.K. pharmacy chain Boots Group in 2006 to form Alliance Boots; took it private in $22 billion deal in May 2007 with financing from private equity firm KKR.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker continues as a nonexecutive director of his family's financial-services company, Schroders. Brother-in-law George Mallinckrodt is a longtime company director; nephew Philip Mallinckrodt promoted to board in December. Shares of Schroders down 17% over past year, performing better than the FTSE 100, which is off 27%. In spare time flies planes and breeds Middle White pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Warren Buffett's lifelong friend was first his rival; vied against the Oracle of Omaha for the hearts of girls in high school. Studied civil engineering at Colorado State; went to work for father's employer, Kiewit Construction (now Peter Kiewit Sons'). Chief executive 1979. Pushed company into telecom, fiber optics, power plants. Retired 1998, still chairman of Level 3 Communications. Today sits on the Berkshire Hathaway board. Owns minority share in Omaha Royals minor league baseball team. Donates to Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha. This April he'll receive the Horatio Alger Association's Norman Vincent Peale Award for his philanthropic and humanitarian efforts.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Money man had a tumultuous summer in 2007, but flagship fund said to have finished up in 2008. Founded hedge fund from office above communist book store 1988. Today D.E. Shaw manages $30 billion across hedge fund, private equity, investment banking, insurance operations. Firm bought FAO Schwarz toy store out of bankruptcy last May. Sold 20% of equity in management company to Lehman Brothers in 2007; no longer involved in day-to-day operations. Solves scientific riddles as head of D. E. Shaw Research.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'D. E. Shaw & Co., L.P.', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, founder of $3.5 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany's leading publishing groups. Now owns more than 52% of company, which publishes more than 170 papers in 33 countries, including leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest daily tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes foreign language editions of Forbes in Poland and Russia.  Active in various philanthropic organizations; has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations.  Latest honor:  the Federal Cross of Merit for her efforts to promote social,  cultural and scientific dialogue worldwide.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest of 7 boys left school at age 17 to join father's 3-man firm supplying parts to oil and gas companies. Took over after father's early death. Today his RGM International owns pulp and papermaker April and palm oil producer Asian Agri, both hit by falling commodity prices. Asian Agri recently won defamation lawsuit against Tempo magazine for publishing a report on company's alleged tax evasion. Tanoto changed last character of his Chinese name to mean "peace" instead of "river."

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Turkey's largest construction company, Enka. Company now run by son, Mehmet Sinan Tara, who dropped out of the billionaires ranks this year as its share price plummeted more than 60%. One billion worth of contracts in Russia may dry up as real estate market there fizzles. Born in Macedonia, he established Enka at age 27 in Istanbul with brother-in-law Sadi Gulcelik.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Donald has seen better days. Last month Trump Entertainment Resorts filed for bankruptcy; he resigned from the casino company's board of directors a few days beforehand. His $1 billion hotel and condo tower in Chicago is struggling to close previously agreed-to sales and can't find new buyers. Says he's finding opportunity amid calamity: "We're buying things we couldn't have dreamed of buying two years ago. And we have a lot of cash." Example: recently bought lush golf course along the Potomac River outside Washington D.C. Sold a Palm Beach estate to Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev for $100 million in July. Son of Brooklyn developer invaded Manhattan in mid-1970s, borrowed heavily, talked tough, became a billionaire. Nearly lost it all in 1990 real estate crash; bounced back, embraced reality TV. Prized buildings: Trump Tower, 40 Wall Street, 1260 Avenue of the Americas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns iron ore and steel producer Metalloinvest with Andrei Skoch and Vasily Anisimov. Trio planned to take it public in 2008 and had  investment bankers lined up, but it was postponed indefinitely because of  the financial crisis. Skoch and Anisimov, who have smaller stakes in the  company, both dropped out of the billionaire ranks this year. Another bad bet by Usmanov:  paid $2.5 billion for a 5% stake in Norilsk Nickel last year. At press time it was worth just $600 million. Also has a 25%  stake in publicly traded British soccer club, Arsenal. Owns the biggest Russian business daily, Kommersant, and has shares in two extremely popular social networking websites. His most valuable asset is his stake in Russia’s telecom outfit, Megafon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beijing property developer. She and husband, Pan Shiyi, who are Soho China's chief executive and chairman, respectively, are one of China's best-known business couples, renowned for their stylish buildings. Zhang got start at international firms Goldman Sachs, Travelers Group. Started Soho with husband in 1995. Pan who writes a popular blog transferred his shares to her in 2005; company listed in 2007. At a time when fortunes of rival developers have crashed, Zhang's initially held up in part because of good business from repeat customers, who account for about half of sales, but more recently its stock has been faltering.
title: Cofounder, CEO
employment: {'name': 'Soho China Ltd.', 'uri': 'companies/soho-china', 'title': 'Cofounder, CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of 25-year-old Agaoglu Group, a builder of hotels, resorts, and ski lodges in Turkey. Net worth up this year because of greater asset transparency; owns 90 million square feet of developable land on western coast of Turkey and continues to buy up parcels opportunistically. Despite the downturn, his new Istanbul residential estate project called My City Bahcelievler sold 300 units in 3 days in mid-February. Announced plans to invest $2 billion in tourism projects including hotels and malls last March.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his small scrap-metals trading outfit into London-listed Vedanta Resources, a metals, mining group with bulk of assets in India. In 2007 beat Lakshmi Mittal in race to buy Indian iron ore producer Sesa Goa acquired for more than $1 billion. Abandoned plans in 2008 to restructure Vedanta into 3 units after investors protested that it was unfair to minority shareholders. His Sterlite Industries agreed to buy bankrupt U.S. copper miner Asarco for $1.7 billion, less than the $2.6 billion it was going to pay last year before the global meltdown. Has pledged $1 billion to set up Vedanta University in eastern India. Plans to give away 75% of wealth to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley real estate titan's fortune has fallen $200 million since September. Son of Basque immigrants, attended Stanford; with lifelong partner Richard Peery converted California farmland into valuable Silicon Valley office space during the 1960s. Duo sold offices to tenants Google and Cisco, created cities of Mountain View and Sunnyvale. Sold half of their portfolio in 2005; the next year made $1.1 billion selling more than 5 million square feet of office space and research facilities. Arrillaga donated $100 million to alma mater in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund maven spent summers manning fishing boat for NYSE board member Walter Frank; fellow fisherman convinced Bacon to apply to Columbia business school. Launched hedge fund Moore Capital 8 years later. First year returned 86% on bet that Gulf war would cause oil prices to spike. Today manages $16.5 billion, down from $20 billion in September. Two years ago, bought Forbes family's Colorado ranch for $175 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production still among biggest private oil companies; sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Ed studied architecture at Yale. Built hotel in the Himalayas; spent $200 million building Biosphere 2 project in Arizona 1990s, sold with surrounding land to housing developer for $50 million in 2007 with agreement University of Arizona can conduct scientific experiments in the Biosphere. Donating millions to protect Yale historic buildings. Fine Line investment firm holds interests in venture capital, ranches in Texas, Kansas, Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings, Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto, all billionaires, formed Benetton Group in 1965; now a $2.7 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley; stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. Is also deputy chair of Edizione SRL, the family holding company that owns stakes in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks in both down over 50% since last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Carlo, also billionaires, formed Benetton Group in 1965. The $2.7 billion (sales) clothing company sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley; stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. Chairs Edizione SRL, the family holding company that owns stakes in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks in both down over 50% since last year. Created La Ghirada, an indoor-outdoor sports complex for basketball, volleyball and rugby in Treviso, Italy. Makes investments via personal holding company Regia SRL.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1965 formed Benetton Group with siblings: Luciano, Carlo and Gilberto, also billionaires. The $2.7 billion (sales) clothing company sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley; stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. Edizione, the family holding company, owns stakes in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks in both down over 50% since last year. Giuliana originally knitted sweaters that brother Luciano would then peddle by bicycle; sold under a variety of labels before becoming United Colors of Benetton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Gilberto, also billionaires, formed Benetton Group in 1965. After running it for 40 years, now chairman of the $2.7 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley; stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. The family also owns a large chunk of Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks in both down over 50% since last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former lawyer cofounded JMB Realty with U. of Illinois roommate 1970. Prospered until early 1990s real estate crash. Didn't give up: founded private equity firm Walton Street Capital 1994. Today JMB Realty portfolio includes Chicago's Four Seasons Hotel, MGM Tower in Los Angeles. Spent $1 billion building casinos in Mississippi and Canada, developing another in Pittsburgh's North Shore. Casino valuations languishing as economy tanks.
