SugarHouse casino project in Philadelphia mired in lawsuits and political bickering. Contemporary art collector donates to Northwestern Hospital, Whitney Museum, Jewish United Fund. Net worth down 30% in past 6 months as investments, property values decline.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen's fortune comes mainly from Zijin Mining, one of the country's largest nongovernment mining companies. Overseas investments include gold project in Tajikistan and copper and molybdenum mine in Peru. Already traded in Hong Kong, shares began trading in Shanghai in 2008. Also a major shareholder in Fujian New Hua Du Supercenter. In April Chen hired Tang Jun, former head of Shanda Interactive, as his holding company's chief executive. Plans to increase overseas investments in minerals and eventually hopes to list 4 of the holding company's other businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of a handful of self-made female billionaires in the world. Chairs Huabao International, which makes fragrances and flavorings for use in cigarettes, detergents, beverages, dairy products and cosmetics. Founded the company a decade ago and took it public through a backdoor listing. Sold chunk of shares in 2008; also bought a tobacco-flavorings outfit last year, which she sold back to Huabao. Still owns two-thirds of its shares. Holds several leadership positions in local industry groups

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Hyundai Motor, world&#39s fifth-largest carmaker. Building its own steelmaking plant to be completed by 2011. Automaker is doing surprisingly well in the U.S.; Genesis model won North American Car of the Year award. U.S. sales were up 14% in January versus year ago, thanks in part to its program that lets people return newly purchased cars if they lose their jobs. Presidential pardon in August 2008 put Chung’s fraud conviction behind him. Avid sports fan began supporting Korea Archery Association after a Korean woman won a gold medal in 1984; paid for various high-tech training devices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Entrepreneur credited with helping transform Ireland's economy in late 1980s with proposal for Dublin's International Financial Services Centre. First gig was selling programs at Dublin soccer stadium Tolka Park while a student. After school, started at Citibank and worked briefly as banking consultant for Pricewaterhouse Coopers in Kabul, Afghanistan until Soviet invasion. Founded NCB Stockbrokers in 1981 and built it into Ireland's largest independent brokerage. Sold NCB in 1994 for $39 million, used proceeds to fund own private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. Sold one of his best-known assets, London City Airport, in 2006. Current investments include diamonds, software, nursing homes, Latvia's Rietumu Bank and majority stake in Glasgow soccer club Celtic. Also owns share in Barbados' Sandy Lane Hotel, where son Brett recently proposed to Irish singer Andrea Corr. Known as The Kaiser for trademark gnarly mustache.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs $8.4 billion (2007 sales) Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao, one of Brazil's largest retailers, which sells everything from food and clothing to TVs and appliances; also known as Grupo Pao de Acucar. His stake in the retailer increased in 2006 when his father, Valentim Diniz--who founded the company in 1948--divided his shares among his children. Abilio Diniz shares control of the company with French retailer Groupe Casino. A fitness fanatic, exercises several hours a day, has run multiple marathons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brooklyn-raised hedge fund mogul expanding. Last March his Millennium Partners bought London hedge fund Castlegrove Capital. Goal: "participate actively in the consolidation of the hedge fund industry." Launched Millennium Partners hedge fund 1989; annualized returns said to exceed 15% net of fees. Assets down 20% to $11.5 billion since last fall.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive ex-Hollywood stunt pilot built fortune as a middleman between Toyota and southern car dealerships. Today Gulf States Toyota drives Friedkin Cos.; has exclusive distribution rights for Toyota vehicles, parts in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Arkansas. Sales believed to exceed $4 billion. Fortune hampered by crash of the car market. Son Dan chairman of Gulf States. Hunts big game on Tanzania reserve.

name: Billionaires
bio: His grandfather founded Gerling Konzern as a small insurance company in 1904; his father turned it into a major player in the world insurance business. But despite his training as an economist, Rolf showed little interest in his legacy and eventually sold his 94% stake in the company in November 2005  to Germany's Talanx Group for estimated $1.6 billion. His focus is now on his Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world's impact on the environment

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Chicago hedge fund outfit Citadel reeling from steep losses: flagship Wellington Fund plunged 55% in 2008. Shut down Fusion, a $1 billion hedge fund-of-funds, in October. Net worth down $2.2 billion--60%--since September. Started trading stocks from Harvard dorm room; founded Citadel with $4.6 million 1990. Opportunistic investor bought up battered portfolios from distressed hedge funds Amaranth and Sowood in 2006 and 2007, respectively. Today firm manages $13 billion (down 35% from peak last year); accounts for roughly 10% of U.S. equity trading volume. Also nation's largest market maker in equity options. One of five billionaire hedge fund managers to go before congressional panel in November; argued for creation of "central clearing houses" to keep tabs on fiendishly complex financial instruments. Bought Jasper Johns painting "False Start" for $80 million in 2006.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Geologist father and uncle ran small oil and gas firm until late 1970s. Headington played tennis at U. of Oklahoma. Started Headington Oil in 1977; produces more than 4.5 million barrels of oil and natural gas equivalent each year. Rapid exploration; redeploying cash into drilling program in South Texas. Sold Bakken shale assets in North Dakota to XTO Energy for $1.8 billion in cash and stock last May. Built stylish hotels Lumen and Joule in Dallas during past three years. Bankrolled The Young Victoria, movie based on life of British queen; flick opened in March in the U.K. Also working on new movie, Edge of Darkness, starring Mel Gibson.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former IBM software engineer cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues in 1972. Successfully built up North American market for SAP, then left the firm in 1997 after a falling-out with his partners. Trained mathematician holds an honorary professorship of mathematics from the University of Karlsruhe for his support of talented students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields. His charitable foundation gives money to cancer and AIDS research, art and historic preservation.  Divides his time between a home in Hamburg and one in the U.S.  Avid golf player.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunging oil and gas prices have halved the fortune of former Exxon geologist; today owns third-largest privately held oil company in America. Founded Hilcorp Energy 1989 with partner Thomas Hook; bought former Goldman Sachs banker out for $500 million 2003. Loaded up on debt to finance expansion. Pumped an estimated 13.1 million barrels of oil and natural gas equivalents from 1,900 wells in 2007. Buys proven oilfields, deploys technology to extract more energy. Acquired 19 fields in Gulf of Mexico from Chevron last August. Gives to Houston Zoo, Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left family grocery business to pursue career as a lawyer. Joined Harris County, Tex. prosecutor's office 1954 after graduating from U. of Texas; district attorney was soon impeached for "running a string of whorehouses." Shunned private sector job offers to start own personal injury firm. Struck gold representing Pennzoil against Texaco 1987; $11 billion lawsuit lined coffers with estimated $345 million fee. Recently represented Clear Channel in tortuous interference case against major banks. Fees irrelevant: "I don't need any more goddamn money." Holds fortune in diversified portfolio of cash, treasuries and scotches. City of Houston recently named skate park in his honor. "I don't know anything about skateboarding."

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of consumer lender Promise, retired 8 years ago to grow mangoes, bananas in greenhouses on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido, known for its frigid winters and heavy snowfalls. Promise is now run by son Hiroki, whose recent acquisitions and alliances have led company to post higher profits; also reported decrease in loan losses thanks to tighter screening of loan applicants.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist cobbled together 1,925 pharmacies to create one of the biggest pharmacy chains in North America. The Edmonton, Alta. Katz Group is also one of Canada's largest private companies. Starting in the 1990s Katz bought up distressed pharmacy chains with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hired capable executives to turn the chains around. Bought Edmonton Oilers for $200 million in 2008 and stuck to his business strategy, hiring new executives to help drive the team's success. Now developing entertainment and sports district in downtown Edmonton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmer's son founded Commonwealth Brands 1990, made fortune with discount cigarettes. Spent little on advertising; outperformed big brands by keeping prices low. Sold for $1 billion in 2001, netted an estimated $750 million. Reinvested in real estate: owns 1.7 million acres in New Mexico, Florida, Texas. Wildlife conservationist sold stake in Kentucky Downs last year. Churchill Downs stock down 50% from September highs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father was a drill sergeant stationed at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. R.J. claims he taught himself to read at age 3; connected sounds from TV with letters on cereal box. Studied business at Radford U., then law at U. of Virginia. With partners (a physician and a pharmacist), founded pharmaceutical distribution outfit General Injectables & Vaccines 1983. Sold stake for $70 million 1998. Launched New River Pharmaceutical 1996 to target thyroid ailments, ADHD. Sold to Shire in 2007 for $2.6 billion; personally netted $1.2 billion. Plowed proceeds from both sales into private equity firm Third Security. Biotech investments and cash holdings relatively unaffected by market downturn. Bird lover owns falcon, eagle, owl, hawks. Writes, produces electronic music in personal recording studio.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil, gas, steel market crashes have cut his fortune in half in the past 6 months. One of 4 sons of Fred Koch, who invented method of refining gasoline from heavy oil. Expanded oil industry in U.S.S.R. 1930s; returned home before World War II. Founded Koch Industries, passed to sons after death in 1967. Bill attended MIT. With brother Frederick, sold stake to brothers Charles and David for $1.3 billion in 1983. Later sued for more, case settled 2001. Used inheritance to create energy conglomerate Oxbow; produces calcined petroleum coke, coal, steel, natural gas. Sales: $3.7 billion. Art and wine collector sued the Acker Merrall & Condit auction house in 2007 for selling him counterfeit vino; paid $500,000 for four bottles alleged to have belonged to Thomas Jefferson.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of New England Patriots lost star quarterback, Tom Brady, in first game; rallied to finish 11-5 but missed playoffs for first time in six years. Father was teacher and clothingmaker. Bob went to Columbia U., then Harvard Business School. Today Kraft Group Holdings includes paper companies (Rand-Whitney, International Forest Products), real estate, private equity, New Englans Revolution soccer team. Estimated sales exceed $1.5 billion. Bought struggling Patriots franchise in 1994 for then-record $172 million. Team played in four Super Bowls this decade; won three. Now worth $1.3 billion. Opened $550 million Patriot Place: shops, hotel, medical facilities. Donates to education, family and children's causes.
title: Chairman & CEO
employment: {'name': 'The Kraft Group', 'title': 'Chairman & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: World's largest cutter and polisher of diamonds is trying to hold his empire together. Selling select properties, acquired via his Tel Aviv-traded conglomerate, Africa Israel Investments, to meet debt obligations; stock down 84% over the past year. High end diamond business slowing as demand dries up;  jewerly stores in Russia holding their own as Russians flock to gems because of unsteady banking sector. Born in Uzbekistan, his Lubavitcher Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. Made his name undercutting De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former plant manager has built China's largest private-sector construction equipment manufacturer, Sany Heavy. Famously opposed investment by U.S. private equity firm Carlyle in domestic rival Xugong Group Construction Machinery years ago, citing national security. Carlyle finally withdrew its bid last year. Reduced his own salary to 1 renminbi or equivalent of 14 cents, as cost-cutting measure during economic slowdown.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Beijing property developer Oceanwide Construction, which owns very visible properties in the city, including Glory China Center, on East Chang, an avenue leading into Tiananmen Square. Its stock has fallen steadily since the last billionaires ranking was published. Plan for an additional share offering was rejected by Chinese regulators. Company announced net profit drop of at least 50% in first 9 months of 2008. Lu also has stake in Minsheng Banking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swooped in with $530 million loan to save Sirius XM from bankruptcy in February, thwarting advances from longtime rival Charles Ergen's competing Dish Network. In return, Malone's Liberty Media gets 40% of the satellite radio operator and two board seats. Plan to spin-off majority stake in DirecTV into separate public company, Liberty Entertainment, is pending regulatory approval. Cable baron and partner of TCI cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996) sold nation's largest cable company to AT&T in 1999 for $54 billion; reinvested proceeds. Liberty Media owns stakes in cable (QVC, Starz), cell phones (Motorola), pro baseball (Atlanta Braves).

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio native got start as Campbell Soup accountant, soon after took general manager post at 5-employee pet food firm Iams in 1970. Became president, chief executive before buying company 1982. Expanded business with premium puppy chow; focused on nutrition, high-end breeders. Sold out to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999; was the largest acquisition in P&G history at the time. Wife runs Mathile Family Foundation; annual proceeds go to Dayton community projects. Promotes entrepreneurship through Dayton business center Aileron; founded with $30 million donation 1996. Penned book "Dream No Little Dreams."

name: Billionaires
bio: Started footwear maker Geox after he came up with an idea in 1989 to put tiny holes in the bottoms of shoes to release sweat; initially tried to sell the concept to Nike, which turned him down. Stock down more than 50% since last year. At Davos this year, said shoe-making segment had been hit by the economic slowdown, but Geox had not felt drastic drop in demand; last year sold 23 million pairs of shoes. Before starting shoe business, ran family's prestigious Villa Sandi winery. Has stated, "I am not an engineer, but a winemaker."

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Texas billionaire Ross Perot Sr. Father and son real estate outfit Hillwood cashed in on sale of natural gas interests under land on Texas' Barnett Shale to Quicksilver Resources in August. Hillwood retains the rights to develop on the land. Chairman of Perot Systems developing 40 million square feet of residential, office, retail and hotel buildings off the coast of Abu Dhabi; in September company successfully implemented electronic patient records in three area hospitals. Sold pro basketball's Dallas Mavericks to Mark Cuban in 2000. Airman completed first-ever round-the-world helicopter flight in 1982.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of stud-farm owner, runs privately owned Serum Institute of India, one of world’s largest makers of children’s vaccines, which he started in a corner of his family’s stud farm in 1966. Serum exports to 140 countries with customers like Unicef and the Pan-American Health Organization. Poonawalla has acquired minority stakes in biotech outfit Orchid Chemicals and rival vaccinemaker Panacea Biotech. Son Adar heads operations and business development. Remains major figure on horse racing circuit. Collects custom-built limousines. Recently ordered a new Falcon 900EX business jet for $45 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cash is king: last August Quicksilver Resources snapped up assets of Barnett Shale natural gas field owned by Ross Perot's Hillwood and his Chief Oil & Gas for $1.3 billion; Rees-Jones personally pocketed $400 million. Sold portion of Barnett Shale assets sale to Devon Energy and Crosstex Energy in 2006 for $2.6 billion in cash. Redeploying proceeds into prospects in Pennsylvania, Utah, Montana. Dartmouth grad studied law at Southern Methodist U. In 1984 left career as Dallas bankruptcy attorney to pursue oil and gas investments. Formed Chief Oil & Gas a decade later. With wife Jan, Rees-Jones Foundation awarded $2 million grant to Texas Christian University; gave $10 million last fall to alma mater Dartmouth for scholarships to Texan students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dyslexic fisherman reportedly told by schoolteacher he'd never amount to anything. Stock in main holding, Aker ASA, maritime conglomerate that operates shipyards, offshore drilling, seafood and shipping tanked 50% over past year. Got start selling fish off a single boat in Seattle, Wash.; returned to Norway and built up fleet and reputation as a ruthless corporate raider. Lived large with giant yacht and Boeing jet but nearly drove his shipping empire into the ground by 2003; sold yacht, paid off debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trucking fortune running out of gas as manufacturing and consumer demand dropped; estimated net worth down 60% since August. Father, Al, founded freight company with one truck 1935, grew rapidly through acquisitions, expanding into interstate shipping. Donald became president of Schneider National 1976, complemented father's eighth-grade education with Wharton M.B.A. Pioneered use of satellite tracking technology, transportation logistics. Today company's fleet includes 14,000 tractors, 40,000 trailers. Sales: $3.4 billion. Continues to expand internationally: growth in China said to be helping offset freight shortcomings in U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded online gaming outfit Giant Interactive in 2005. Took it public in the U.S. in November 2007; it has since lost two-thirds of its market value. Got a bachelor's degree in mathematics from the academic cradle of China's software industry, Zhejiang University, and created a huge following for his Zhuhai Giant Hi-Tech Group in 1991, based on the popularity of a single videogame. Zhuhai Giant collapsed under the weight of massive debt incurred for a 70-story skyscraper that was never built. His recent return to games through an online services provider he founded, ZTgame, has given new life to his entrepreneurial reputation. Shi also has stakes in Minsheng Banking, of which he's a director, and Huaxia Bank. Diversifying into Chinese rice wine market.

name: Billionaires
bio: University of Illinois grad became salesman for Oracle; left Larry Ellison's software giant 1990 after Ellison wouldn't take Siebel's sales-tracking software to market. Started rival Siebel Systems; public 1996. Sold to Oracle for $5.9 billion 2005; netted an estimated $500 million in cash. Now chairman of holding company First Virtual Group; has interests in real estate, agribusiness, philanthropy and asset management. Siebel Foundation supports education, health, stem cell research, methamphetamine prevention; "Meth Project" now in five states, plans to expand to nine states by the end of 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded developer Tishman Speyer in 1978 with former father-in-law Robert Tishman; today firm remains a global real estate powerhouse. Owns stakes in New York landmarks Chrysler Building and Rockefeller Center. Settled rent dispute with Cipriani family, owners of famed Rainbow Room; family agreed to vacate restaurant space atop 30 Rockefeller Center in August. Bought Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartment and retail complexes in Manhattan for $5.4 billion from MetLife in 2006; reportedly burning through cash reserves as eviction of rent-stabilized tenants goes more slowly than planned. Won rights for Manhattan's coveted West Side rail yards project last March; deal collapsed 2 months later following rezoning disagreements with New York State's transit authority. Bought apartment landlord Archstone-Smith October 2007, acquiring national portfolio of 88,000 luxury rental units. Family business: wife, Katherine, runs emerging markets division, plans to develop $2 billion town in India. Son and daughter also work for firm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Daito Trust Construction, a property developer specializing in rental apartments. Sale to private investors, including bidder billionaire Akira Mori canceled after financial crisis locked up credit markets. Company stock price rose after issuing $2 bonus dividend last year but has since declined.

name: Billionaires
bio: Biggest builder of apartments in Australia, as founder of Meriton Apartments; has built about 55,000 apartments in past 50 years, mainly in Sydney. He apparently has an extreme aversion to debt and banks; is also legendary for his run-ins  with design critics and local councils.  Born in China to Russian parents who fled their native country during the Bolshevik Revolution. Learned about real estate development as a child visiting his father, a builder, at work sites in Tianjin, China; immigrated to Australia at age 28. Drove a taxi and owned a milk run before being the first to spot the trend toward the inner-city high-rise apartments that dominate Sydney's skyline. Owns three Bentleys; on alternate days his license plates read HOT1 and HOT2 (for his initials) and OSCAR1 (his middle name).

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained physicist, he and four former IBM colleagues founded German software company SAP in 1972. Retired from SAP in 1998.  Stepped down from its supervisory board in May 2007. Devotes his time to his Klaus Tschira Foundation, dedicated to scientific research and cultural projects such as a communications and computer camp for blind and vision-impaired youth. Donated another $900 million worth of SAP shares to foundation in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property baron increased stake in U.K. Coal in November, driving speculation that he is planning a bid for the company; rumors surfaced in December his Peel Holdings making play to buy 1,000 acres on the Kent coast-both welcome moves in an otherwise stagnant real estate market. Took company private in 2004; a year later led the group's $1.3 billion takeover of Mersey Docks & Harbour Co. in a bid to revitalize the Liverpool waterfront. In 2006 Deutsche Bank's property arm paid $600 million for 49% stake. Group's other holdings include investment properties, airports and ports. Added a stake in Pinewood Shepperton film studio, where James Bond movies, among others, are filmed. Owns Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino kingpin continues to struggle as gamblers stay away from Las Vegas. In July told analysts on a conference call: "If there's less traffic, then you make less money. Period." Opened $2.3 billion Encore casino next to his Wynn Las Vegas resort 6 months later. Wynn Resorts stock down 84% in the past 12 months, pushing fortune down more than $2.4 billion. Announced wide-reaching plan to cut costs in February; cut staff hours, bonuses to avoid layoffs. U. of Pennsylvania grad started out at Frontier Hotel. Bought Golden Nugget, built Mirage and Bellagio megaresorts. Sold Mirage Resorts to Kirk Kerkorian for $6.6 billion 2000; opened Wynn Macau in China in 2006.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Resorts', 'uri': 'companies/wynn-resorts', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former leader of a collective, he and children own $2.9 billion (sales) Xiyang Group, one of China's largest suppliers of magnetite products, used in making steel. Also makes steel, fertilizer, and has stake in Chinese professional basketball team. Member of business delegation that accompanied China Premier Wen Jiabao to Moscow for economic conference last October.

name: Billionaires
bio: Not the best time to own real estate or media--and Zuckerman has gobs of both.  Manhattan mogul's fortune down $1.3 billion since September. With partners, bought Manhattan's GM Building from debt-strapped Harry Macklowe for $2.8 billion 2008; highest price ever paid for a building. "It is the best single purchase that I've made since I've been in the business." Also snared Two Grand Central Tower, 540 Madison Ave., 125 West 55th St. for an additional $1.1 billion through publicly traded Boston Properties; stock down 70% since September. Owner of New York Daily News lost to Dolan family on highly contested bid for Tribune's Newsday last year. Also owns U.S. News & World Report; magazine scaled back to biweekly circulation. Son of Montreal tobacco-and-candy seller studied law at Harvard and McGill U. after earning Wharton M.B.A. Cofounded Boston Properties in 1970 with Edward Linde; public 1997. Has donated hundreds of millions of dollars to cancer research; charitable trust lost $30 million to Bernard Madoff's Ponzi scheme.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Boston Properties', 'uri': 'companies/boston-properties', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: World War II veteran founded diet drink outfit Slim-Fast in 1976; created weight-loss craze with slimming the likes of Tommy Lasorda and Kathy Lee Gifford with "a shake for breakfast, a shake for lunch, and a sensible dinner." Expanded to extra snacks. Sold to Unilever in 2000; made $2.3 billion before taxes. Built wellness center for Mayo Clinic employees. Pro-Isreal Democrat donor gave big bucks to Clinton Foundation.
organization: S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns more than 50% of Caltagirone SpA, an industrial holding company. Stakes in construction finance firm Caltagirone and cement maker Cementir down more than 50% since last year; bank and media assets also suffering. Buying shares in down market: in insurer Generali, building-materials manufacturer Italcementi, and bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena. His personal financial holding company, ICAL, bought 2 buildings in Rome from Goldman Sachs fund for a reported $225 million. Dubbed Franco the Taciturn by media for his quiet ways.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tycoon&#39s holdings defying ailing economy. Reason: owns gobs of office space located in prized New York City neighborhood, Times Square. Son of a sewing supplies salesman inherited $34 when father passed away; paid for Brooklyn Law School by singing in synagogues. Considered career as vocalist, chose entertainment law instead. Star client: Sammy Davis Jr. Built practice by figuring out way to maximize tax benefits for oil partnerships. Jimmy Carter adviser helped broker Camp David Accords between Egypt and Israel in 1978. Bought first buildingÑOne Times SquareÑon the night Carter lost reelection to Reagan in 1980. Borrowed, reinvested rental income into 12 surrounding buildings. Today owns 3 skyscrapers, 1.5 million square feet of commercial space in Times Square. Tenants include Liz Claiborne, Office Depot, Jones Apparel. Hosts The Leon Charney Report, nationally syndicated political talk show.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Daniel D'Aniello and David Rubenstein, leads leveraged buyout outfit Carlyle Group. Firm rattled by collapse of hedge fund and mortgage bond fund operations. Hedge fund Carlyle-Blue Wave Partners launched in April 2007; lost 17% in first 8 months, shut down last August. Amsterdam-listed Carlyle Capital defaulted on $16.6 billion of loans last year as housing market soured. Founded Carlyle 1987; used politically connected advisers to buy defense-oriented companies, turn them around, sell for profit. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money; rehabbing image since. Today firm manages around $85 billion across 66 funds.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Assets reportedly in temporary conservatorship as family members, including her daughter, believe that the heiress is no longer capable of managing her finances; waging court battle to place her assets under the control of twin brother, George Hearst Jr., chairman of family company Hearst Corp. Cooke's lawyers contend that she is free to manage her money as she chooses. Granddaughter of publishing legend, William Randolph Hearst. Hearst Corp. empire includes newspaper (Houston Chronicle) and magazine (Cosmopolitan, Esquire) divisions, cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E). Also TV, radio stations. Company may close or sell Northern California's largest paper, San Francisco Chronicle, which reportedly lost $50 million last year. Also put Seattle Post-Intelligencer up for sale in January after years of losses; paper will fold if a buyer isn't found. Longtime chief exec Victor F. Ganzi resigned suddenly last June amid reports of clashes with Hearst family over direction of the company; replacement Frank Bennack Jr. has since appointed several new executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: With William Conway and David Rubenstein, leads leveraged buyout outfit Carlyle Group. Firm rattled by collapse of hedge fund and mortgage bond fund operations. Hedge fund Carlyle-Blue Wave Partners launched in April 2007; lost 17% in first 8 months, shut down last August. Amsterdam-listed Carlyle Capital defaulted on $16.6 billion of loans last year as housing market soured. Founded Carlyle 1987; used politically connected advisers to buy defense-oriented companies, turn them around, sell for profit. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money; rehabbing image since. Today firm manages around $85 billion across 66 funds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media mogul's splashy $100 million launch of OK! magazine in the U.S. is facing tough times. Fired managing director Kent Brownridge and editor-in-chief Susan Toepfer; major bungle in their first few weeks at helm when misspelled name of singer Ashlee Simpson as Ashley on cover. They had also stopped the practice of paying for star pictures (since reinstated). Media watchers predict magazine will fold by the summer. But Paul Ashford, one of Desmond's longest serving lieutenants says, "Rumors of our closure have been greatly exaggerated." Last year's OK! launches in Germany and Spain faring better. Despite downturn, U.K. newspaper group still pulling in profits; enough to purchase corporate jet. High school dropout started his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974; built stable of trade titles including at one time more than 40 adult entertainment publications, which he sold in 2004. Launched celebrity magazine OK! in Britain in 1993. Bought British newspaper group Express in 2000. For fun and charity, plays drums with his band RD Crusaders, whose other musicians include folks from The Who and Led Zeppelin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime ally of fellow billionaire Silvio Berlusconi; cofounded financial services group Mediolanum SpA with Berlusconi's Fininvest Group in 1982. Still runs the group, whose companies provide investment advice, banking services, life insurance and real estate loans; Italy's second-largest such group by market capitalization. Stock fell 25% since last February, one of the better performers in a market that fell 45% in the same period. Son Massimo, 41, is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns $4 billion (sales) Benesse, Japan's largest correspondence school, which runs globally recognized Berlitz language schools. Other divisions provide elder and child care services, student loans; also has a publishing arm that prints child care books for new moms and lifestyle magazines. Sales for first 9 months of this fiscal year, which ends in March, were up 9%. Company sponsors art museum on picturesque Naoshima Island.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saudi-born son of slain prime minister Rafiq Hariri is following in his footsteps; now Lebanon's parliamentary majority leader and head of the Future Movement, a moderate, nonsectarian, political bloc founded by his late father. Also runs construction, telecom and real estate conglomerate, Saudi Oger, which he inherited with the rest of the family 4 years ago. In January 2008 bought brother Bahaa's stake; now owns 50%. Business may take backseat as political season heats up. Highly anticipated legislative elections in June will pit Hariri against Hezbollah around the same time The Hague begins an international tribunal trying those charged in father's assassination.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune down $700 million as media industry suffers advertising meltdown. Hearst Corp may close or sell Northern California's largest paper, San Francisco Chronicle, which reportedly lost $50 million last year. Also put Seattle Post-Intelligencer up for sale in January after years of losses; paper will fold if a buyer isn't found. Grandson of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William's father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who "won" failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation's largest newspaper chain via sensational "yellow" journalism. Infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspaper (Houston Chronicle) and magazine (Cosmopolitan, Esquire) divisions, cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E). Also TV, radio stations. Longtime chief exec Victor F. Ganzi resigned suddenly last June amid reports of clashes with Hearst family over direction of the company; replacement Frank Bennack Jr. has since appointed several new executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune down $700 million as media industry suffers advertising meltdown. Hearst Corp may close or sell Northern California's largest paper, San Francisco Chronicle, which reportedly lost $50 million last year. Also put Seattle Post-Intelligencer up for sale in January after years of losses; paper will fold if a buyer isn't found. Grandson of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William's father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who "won" failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation's largest newspaper chain via sensational "yellow" journalism. Infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspaper (Houston Chronicle) and magazine (Cosmopolitan, Esquire) divisions, cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E). Also TV, radio stations. Longtime chief exec Victor F. Ganzi resigned suddenly last June amid reports of clashes with Hearst family over direction of the company; replacement Frank Bennack Jr. has since appointed several new executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune down $700 million as media industry suffers advertising meltdown. Hearst Corp may close or sell Northern California's largest paper, San Francisco Chronicle, which reportedly lost $50 million last year. Also put Seattle Post-Intelligencer up for sale in January after years of losses; paper will fold if a buyer isn't found. Grandson of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William's father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who "won" failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation's largest newspaper chain via sensational "yellow" journalism. Infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspaper (Houston Chronicle) and magazine (Cosmopolitan, Esquire) divisions, cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E). Also TV, radio stations. Longtime chief exec Victor F. Ganzi resigned suddenly last June amid reports of clashes with Hearst family over direction of the company; replacement Frank Bennack Jr. has since appointed several new executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former billionaire Michael Heisley passed away in late April 2014 at age 77. He founded Heico Companies, a Chicago holding company that specialized in buying underperforming or bankrupt companies to turn them around. He started in 1979 by buying Conco, a maker of sewer and drain equipment, with $150,000 in profit from selling his home and $10 million in bank loans. Heico expanded and bought several struggling Rust Belt manufacturers. He bought the Vancouver Grizzlies NBA basketball team and moved them to Memphis. He sold the team to a group led by technology billionaire Robert Pera in 2012. The Grizzlies made the playoffs in 2011.  Heisley was last on the Forbes Billionaires list in 2012. He fell off the list the following year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Stanley Eugene (d. 1992), founded one of the first commercial U.S. airlines; it went under. Built radio station 1923, TV station 25 years later. Son "Stub" took charge 1981; pioneered direct-satellite TV with U.S. Satellite Broadcasting. Took public 1996; sold in 1999 for $1.3 billion to Hughes/DirecTV. DirecTV shares down 30% since August. Latest venture: Reelz Channel, movie information and trivia channel debuted 2006, available in over 40 million homes.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Emperor of Little Caesars pizza empire started off fielding ground balls in the Detroit Tigers farm system. Injury ended baseball career; opened first slice shop 1959. Modeled franchise on Ray Kroc's McDonald's: cheap ingredients, fast service, drive-up windows. Famous for "Pizza Pizza" 2-for-1 promotions. Trouble late 1990s; refurbished stores, ditched frozen cheese. Estimated annual sales: $1.6 billion. Detroit native bought Tigers 1992. Also owns pro hockey's Detroit Red Wings; team won Stanley Cup in June (fourth championship since 1997). Wife, Marian, owns Detroit's MotorCity Casino Hotel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather founded retail outfit Shoe Corporation of America in 1905. Tom attended Harvard, worked at First National Bank of Boston. Founded private equity shop Thomas H. Lee Co. 1974. Bought Snapple for $140 million in 1992; sold to Quaker Oats for $2 billion 1994. Left Thomas H. Lee Co. 2006, founded Lee Equity Partners; owns stakes in Dunkin' Donuts, Warner Music. Bought teen apparel outfit Deb Shops 2007. Manages fund of hedge funds Blue Star; fund was reportedly down nearly 40% last year through mid-December, but up 7% annually since 2000. Art connoisseur sits on boards of Whitney, Museum of Modern Art, Lincoln Center, NYU Medical Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family nest egg down as art and real estate markets have fallen at least 25% in the past 6 months. Wharton grad joined family cosmetics company in 1958; pushed operation into pharmaceutical. Made fortune building - and flipping - a variety of businesses. Developed Permalens soft contact lens; sold optics outfit to Cooper Labs for $60 million in 1971. Founded Vision Cable in 1972, built subscriber base to 230,000; sold to Newhouse brothers for $220 million in 1982. Then flipped cell phone outfit Metro Mobile to Bell Atlantic for $2.5 billion in 1991. Today is chief executive of gas and pipeline outfit Southern Union; shares down 50% since September.

name: Billionaires
bio: With 2 brothers, opened ice cream shop in 1940 with $1,200; grew into United Dairy Farmers chain. UDF now run by brother Robert; operates nearly 200 stores in the Midwest. Moved into finance with S&L investments in 1959 and insurance in 1971. Today, with sons, owns $800 million stake in American Financial Group; shares down 54% since September. Investor in National City Corp.; bank bought out by PNC with government bailout money in December. Owns 20% stake in baseball's Cincinnati Reds; team traded star Ken Griffey, Jr. in the off-season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Tencent, China's most popular provider of online chat services. Revenues up 85% in first half 2008 thanks to boost in Internet advertising ahead of Olympics and popularity of such online games as Dungeon, QQ Dancer and Cross Fire. Member of the city congress in Shenzhen, where Tencent is headquartered. Holds B.A. in computer field. Heads of rival Internet outfits, Baidu.com's Robin Li and Alibaba's Jack Ma, both failed to make the billionaires cut this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Learned lumber from father, Joe Hardy, who founded 84 Lumber in 1956 and passed company to his daughter 36 years later. Ceded do-it-yourself market to Home Depot, Lowe's; focused on selling to contractors, developers. Slow economy "hammering" business: sales down 25% to $2.9 billion in past year. Recently borrowed $590 million to stay afloat. Hopes to "emerge from housing slump debt-free" by eliminating unprofitable stores, reducing overhead.

name: Billionaires
bio: Entrepreneur came from nothing. Grew up in Portland, Ore. during Depression; sold magazines, lemonade for change. Studied physics at UCLA. Founded aerospace companies Spectrolab in 1956 and Heliotek 4 years later; both sold to Textron (now owned by General Motors). Continued to invest in biomed firms. Helped fund MiniMed (insulin pumps), Advanced Bionics (cochlear implants), Pacesetter Systems (rechargeable pacemakers). Sold MiniMed to Medtronic for $3.7 billion in 2001. Recently reacquired Advanced Bionics after selling to Boston Scientific 2004; massive legal squabble finally over. Has invested $566 million in MannKind, company developing inhaled insulin. Also has stakes in Stellar Microelectronics and Bioness; latter now merging with Advanced Technology Acquisition Corp. In February his bankrupt Eclipse Aviation forced to cancel public asset auction due to a lack of qualified bidders. Donated $100 million to Purdue U. in 2007 to create Alfred Mann Institute for Biomedical Development; focusing on early breast cancer detection, healing tendon and ligament tears.

name: Billionaires
bio: Good thing he took the cash: traded his shares in Clear Channel Communications for $36 a share when company went private last July; $17.9 billion all-cash deal with private equity outfits Thomas H. Lee Partners, Bain Capital. Auto artisan dropped out of law school to sell cars. Founded Clear Channel Communications with partner Lowry Mays 1972; today radio juggernaut owns 717 radio stations, listening base more than 93 million. Also massive concert promotion operation. Other holdings are down: oil, real estate, more car dealerships.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked in warehouse of family grocery distribution center 1959; McLane Company grew into international holding company spanning 18 divisions, including food service, software and novelty gifts. Became chairman and chief exec; sold company to friend and tennis partner Sam Walton for 10.4 million shares of Wal-Mart stock and $50 million cash 1991. Diversified fortune includes logistics and information technology outfit McLane Group. Houston Astros owner says baseball will be the first sport to feel recession effects. Active deacon teaches Sunday school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Warren Buffett's right-hand man has lost $100 million in past year; Berkshire Hathaway stock has dipped 22% since December highs. Omaha-bred lawyer's son spent childhood raising hamsters, perusing medical journals, captaining school rifle team. Worked for Buffett & Son, high-end grocery store run by Warren's grandfather. Math & physics major at U. of Michigan dropped out to join Air Force. Law degree from Harvard. Kicked off investing career after meeting Warren Buffett at a 1959 party. Became vice chairman of Berkshire. Donated over $20 million in Berkshire shares to California schools last fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate tycoon is $200 million poorer this year as the commercial real estate market buckles. Lost more in the market; suing UBS and others for $500 million, alleging the banks broke promise to invest his cash in only conservative securities. Pleaded guilty to tax felony in 2007 for stashing more than $350 million in Europe; paid $52 million in fines, sentenced to 2 years' probation and 120 hours community service. Today Olen Properties owns more than 6.4 million square feet of office space, nearly 12,000 residential units in Las Vegas, Arizona, Florida. Daughter Natalia runs marketing. Opening restaurant in honor of son Andrei, who passed away in a 2005 car accident. Natalia insisting on green food. Olenicoff: "I'll to have to find an organic vodka."

name: Billionaires
bio: Candy maker is credited with inventing more than 200 sweets including Gummi Bears,  Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies. Said he gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. Makes these candies for Haribo, his family's $2 billion (sales) candy company that he owns with his brother Paul. Siblings rebuilt the company after World War II and still run it together; Hans oversees daily operations while Paul is in charge of production. Bachelor with no children. His nephew, Paul's son, Hans-Jurgen left in 2005 after reported falling-out with his uncle Hans. Paul's other two sons, Hans-Guido and Hans-Arndt, work at Haribo.

name: Billionaires
bio: With William Conway and Daniel D'Aniello, leads leveraged buyout outfit Carlyle Group. Firm rattled by collapse of hedge fund and mortgage bond fund operations. Hedge fund Carlyle-Blue Wave Partners launched in April 2007; lost 17% in first 8 months, shut down last August. Amsterdam-listed Carlyle Capital defaulted on $16.6 billion of loans last year as housing market soured. Founded Carlyle 1987; used politically connected advisers to buy defense-oriented companies, turn them around, sell for profit. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money; rehabbing image since. Today firm manages around $85 billion across 66 funds.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former economics student traded shrimp as a teenager, then switched to palm oil. Bought his first plantation in 1994. Later cofounded agribusiness Wilmar International with nephew of Malaysia&#39s richest man, Robert Kuok. Helped merge  Wilmar with the senior Kuok&#39s plantation and agribusiness group in June 2007, turning Wilmar into one of the world&#39s largest palm oil producers and largest cooking oil producers in Asia. Wilmar’s joint chief operating officer, still holds 10% of company; shares peaked in May 2008, now down more than half.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, John, was a Cambridge-educated humanities professor at San Jose U. who left academia to start for-profit University of Phoenix 1970s. Became Apollo Group; went public 1994. Today enrolls more than 380,000 students online or in classroom. Peter serves as vice chairman. Benefiting from recession as the unemployed workers look to retool their job skills. Stock up 22% in the past 12 months. Selling out: has sold over 2 million shares for around $150 million before taxes since July. Company has faced numerous lawsuits in recent years; fined $10 million for allegedly violated Higher Education Act by paying its recruiters based on number of students they enrolled. Peter sponsored an unsuccessful California ballot initiative in November to require use of more renewable energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chemical engineer from China mopped floors to pay for school. Now owns the Philippines' largest cigarette maker, Fortune Tobacco; Philippine Airlines; Asia Brewery; mining operations; banks; property developments in Hong Kong. Cigarettes and alcohol continue to do well during the downturn, but his property company, Eton, has been hit by lower property values and rents in Hong Kong and other parts of Asia. Being prosecuted by the Presidential Commission on Good Governance, which claims that much of Tan's wealth belonged to former president Ferdinand Marcos and should be returned to the country. Hobbies include flying helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kentucky farm boy inspired to fly planes after hearing radio broadcast of Charles Lindbergh's 1927 transatlantic flight. Opened hamburger stand to raise money for lessons. Dropped out of U. of Kentucky to pursue flying career; spent 26 years as PanAm pilot. Started FlightSafety pilot training school in 1951. Public in 1968; bought out by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $1.5 billion in stock and cash 1996. Personal fortune down $500 million in past six months as Berkshire shares fell 40%. Nonagenarian fights blindness through Orbis International; nonprofit group operates flying eye-surgical center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Early backer of Google: his initial $100,000 investment is now worth over $1 billion.  A cofounder of Sun Microsystems; an inventor of Cisco Systems's switching business. Cofounded and ran Kealia, a computer design system that he sold to Sun in 2004.  Left Sun Microsystems in 1995, returning in 2004 as senior vice president and chief architect.  Resigned from Sun last October to become  chairman and chief development officer of Arista networks, a tech outfit that will compete against network equipment maker Cisco Systems with an ultra-fast network switch that will reportedly cost one-tenth the price of Cisco's similar products. Project reunites him with Canadian billionaire, David Cheriton, co-founder and chief scientist of the venture. The pair's previous project, Granite Systems, sold to Cisco in 1996.  Also has stake in chip-designing-software maker Magma Design Automation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second-generation Greek-American born in Detroit, raised in Pasadena, Calif. Studied business and economics at Michigan State. Sold and leased land at busy intersections to oil companies to set up gas stations 1962. Today privately held Arnel & Affiliates owns, manages 5,500 apartments and 2 million square feet of commercial space. Founded private equity firm Westar Capital 1987; recently sold cooler-maker Igloo. Republican; former U.S. ambassador to Spain.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Arnel & Affiliates', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Backed billionaire Lakshmi Mittal in his successful 2006 bid to merge steel groups Arcelor and Mittal Steel.Now holds 3% of ArcelorMittal, world's largest steel company, who's stock is at a four year low.  Very press shy, reportedly never goes out in public without a bodyguard to safeguard him and his family from kidnapping and assassination attempts by Basque separatists. Owns cattle ranch Ganaderias Aguadulce in south of Spain, where he raises bulls for bullfighting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Value of real estate tycoon's Mission West Properties down 50% since May. Tried to flip firm in 2007; refused to bend on $1.8 billion asking price, pulled portfolio from the market when potential buyers could no longer get financing. Former vending machine repairman worked night shifts to pay his way through U. of New Mexico. Bought real estate investment trust Mission West in 1997; now manages 8 million square feet across 100 properties. Counts Microsoft, Apple among Silicon Valley office tenants. Focusing on outside investments: cancer research, technology startups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth generation of family to run $7 billion (revenues) Globus & Co., one of Germany's largest food retailers. Also operate 83 hardware stores and nine electrical appliance stores. Great great grandfather, Franz Bruch, opened first store in 1828. Thomas Bruch took over from his father in 1979.  With Bruch's three sons working at firm, continued family stewardship seems assured.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunge in commodity and fertilizer prices eating away at Cargill family's fortune. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, started Cargill as a grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took reins 1909. Family owns 88% of company, employees the rest. Today sales exceed $120 billion. Net profits in 2008: nearly $4 billion, up 69% from previous year as global demand for commodities soared. Company controls food from stable to table; manufactures animal feed, meat, crops. Also involved in commodities trading, risk management. Owns majority of publicly traded fertilizer firm Mosaic; stock down more than 60% since August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunge in commodity and fertilizer prices eating away at Cargill family's fortune. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, started Cargill as a grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took reins 1909. Family owns 88% of company, employees the rest. Today sales exceed $120 billion. Net profits in 2008: nearly $4 billion, up 69% from previous year as global demand for commodities soared. Company controls food from stable to table; manufactures animal feed, meat, crops. Also involved in commodities trading, risk management. Owns majority of publicly traded fertilizer firm Mosaic; stock down more than 60% since August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive and chairman of Charoen Pokphand Group, one of world&#39s largest producers of animal feed and livestock with operations throughout Asia, including Indonesia, Vietnam, Turkey; recently invested in Russia. He and his other 3 brothers, Jaran, Montri and  Sumet, each own 13% of group. Dhanin also invests extensively in China’s agriculture, food, retailing and property development. In December 2008 China named him as foreign business leader who has contributed the most to China&#39s economic development over the past 30 years. Keen to support and develop cockfighting as a humane sport with aim of preserving native genetic stocks and and encouraging a community activity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korea&#39s richest politician is son of late Hyundai founder Chung Ju-Young  and brother of billionaire Chung Mong-Koo, chairman of Hyundai Motor. Was chairman of Hyundai Heavy Industries in the 1980s. Left that role in 1988 when he was elected to the national assembly, but still gets bulk of his fortune from stake in the manufacturing group, best known for its shipbuilding division. Ran unsuccessfully for president in 2002 but remains an elected lawmaker. Caught up in scandal last year; he apparently touched a female reporter&#39s cheek and then had to publicly apologize for “unintentional” sexual harassment. Said to have close ties to current president of Korea, a former Hyundai executive. Owns $70,000 worth of folding screens and Korean art.

name: Billionaires
bio: A count who has a firm lock on his wealth. Major shareholder of Investments AB Latour, which holds stakes in Assa Abloy, world's largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of largest publicly traded security companies; and Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas farm boy remains a billionaire despite large stake in faltering Citigroup. Bank's shares down more than 90% in past 12 months. Ford's stake only lost 10%; claims he hedged his shares with $80 million in put options several years ago and has completely sold out his position. Now hunting for bargains in beaten-down banking sector. Bought first bank in 1975 for $1.2 million; with partners, sold for $100 million. With Ronald Perelman, sold Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion 2002.
title: Managing Member
employment: {'name': 'Ford Financial Fund', 'title': 'Managing Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Payroll pioneer has lost $400 million since September; Paychex shares down 40% in past six months. Used $3,000 and a credit card to form Paychex in 1971; provided payroll services to small businesses. Expanded through joint ventures and franchising; went public 1983. No longer runs day-to-day operations. Political junkie mounted 3 failed New York State gubernatorial campaigns with his Independence Party; last attempt cost $90 million of his own money. Last summer founded political action committee Responsible New York; reform group pledged $5 million to state legislature candidates from Republican and Democratic parties, working on setting up permanent Albany office. Donates to Golisano Children's Hospital, Veterans Outreach Center and Rochester Institute of Technology. Owner of pro hockey's Buffalo Sabres; continues to deny rumors he's looking to sell.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buyout specialist emigrated with family from Israel 1968, grew up in Flint, Mich. Founded what is now Gores Group buyout firm 1987 after selling Executive Business Systems, a software and hardware outfit he founded servicing small companies. Today owns 14 companies, manages 2 private equity funds. Prefers to buy divisions of technology firms, merge them to create new companies. Brother Tom runs competing Platinum Equity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shorted subprime, became a billionaire. Starting in 2006, friend of hedge fund master John Paulson began bet against crashing housing markets buying credit default swaps on subprime mortgage-backed bonds. Eventually sold out stakes for $800 million. Worked telemarketing gig selling circus tickets while studying at Johns Hopkins U.; saved up $100,000 by eating at Pizza Hut buffet, living out of his car. Invested in Boston real estate while earning Harvard M.B.A. Moved to L.A., bought and developed apartment buildings. Best man at his wedding: Mike Tyson.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former engineering professor has lost $600 million since last fall. Founded Linkabit 1968; company developed technology that is now the basis for most of the telecommunications industry. Founded Qualcomm 1985, creator of CDMA digital wireless technology. Shares down 40% from August highs; annual sales exceed $11 billion. Firm was sued by Broadcom for patent infringement 2007; paid $19.6 million in damages. Also settled several long-running lawsuits over mobile patent licenses with Nokia last July; former rivals now working together on new smart phone. Stepped down as chief exec 2005, remains chairman. Son Paul now runs company. Donates to San Diego symphony, art museum and university; gave to Barack Obama's presidential campaign.
title: Cofounder & Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Louis, started selling popcorn and peanuts in 1915; grew into massive sports concession business. Jeremy took over after father's death 1968; transformed Delaware North into global player in food and hospitality. Sales: $2.2 billion. Provides hospitality services to London's Wembley and Emirates stadiums; recently won rights to develop and run first legal 'racino' in New York City at the Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens. Awarded food service contracts at Minnesota Twins' new ballpark and new Meadowlands Stadium and Red Bull Arena in New Jersey. Owns pro hockey's Boston Bruins, TD Banknorth Garden, stake in lucrative New England Sports Network. Regional channel supplies Red Sox games to Boston and beyond. With wife donated single largest gift in University at Buffalo's history to fund the Jacobs Institute: focused on neurological, heart and vascular research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Football king's fortune down less than 10% as value of Dallas Cowboys holds up despite the recession. Bought America's Team in 1989 for $150 million; team worth $1.2 billion today. Cowboys finished their 37th and final season at Texas Stadium last year; moving into new 80,000 seat stadium with retractable roof this fall. Recently teamed up with New York Yankees and Goldman Sachs to form stadium services company Legends Hospitality Management. Led university of Arkansas Razorbacks to Cotton Bowl title in 1964. Joined father's insurance company. Ventured into energy; found natural gas in first 13 wells dug 1970s. Also owns poultry processor, cattle ranch; increasing gas exploration.
title: President and General Manager
employment: {'name': 'Dallas Cowboys', 'title': 'President and General Manager', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune going down the drain as home building and renovations grind to a halt. Estimated net worth down more than 60% since last summer. Third-generation head of Kohler Co. oversees maker of faucets, tile, plumbing, cabinets, generators, engines, toilets. Estimated sales in 2007: $5.23 billion. Real estate portfolio includes golf courses, stables, spas, hotels; prestigious Old Course Hotel at St. Andrews, Scotland. Grandfather started company in 1873 making farming tools and cemetery accessories.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kohler Co.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunge in commodity and fertilizer prices eating away at Cargill family's fortune. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, started Cargill as a grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took reins 1909. Family owns 88% of company, employees the rest. Today sales exceed $120 billion. Net profits in 2008: nearly $4 billion, up 69% from previous year as global demand for commodities soared. Company controls food from stable to table; manufactures animal feed, meat, crops. Also involved in commodities trading, risk management. Owns majority of publicly traded fertilizer firm Mosaic; stock down more than 60% since August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmer's son earned bulk of fortune making auto parts for such carmakers as Ford and Toyota. Today Lu's Wanxiang Group has diversified into agriculture, infrastructure, finance and real estate. Son and heir apparent Lu Weiding handles company's mergers and acquisitions. Wanxiang America, run by his son-in-law Pin Ni picked up several of the country's struggling auto parts business in recent years. Group is constructing office tower in the center of Shanghai's powerful Lujiazui financial district.

name: Billionaires
bio: McCaw has lost $1 billion in recent months thanks to escalating troubles between Sprint and Clearwire. Last May Clearwire announced $14.5 billion merger with Sprint; investors now backing out after CLWR stock fell 82% in the past year. Rollout of first national high-powered WiMax network said to be in jeopardy. With brothers, sold to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. Invested in Nextel satellite network; lost $5 billion during 2000 telecom crash. Now chairman of Clearwire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Temple U. grad studied medicine at Hahnemann (now part of Drexel U.). Made first fortune as a surgeon inventing spinal implants. Settled nasty intellectual property lawsuit with medical device maker Medtronic in 2005. Payoff: $1.4 billion. Set up 2 foundations funded by investment gains: one to support scientific research, the other to save unloved pets. Has planted 3.5 million trees in Costa Rica since 1999; now expanding reforestation program to Panama. On the prowl: "I'm single and good-looking."

name: Billionaires
bio: Johannesburg mining magnate is South Africa's first black billionaire. Born in the sprawling black township of Soweto and then trained as a lawyer, became first black partner at Bowman Gilfillan law firm in Johannesburg, before starting a contracting business doing mine scut work. Bought low-producing gold mine shafts in 1994, turned them profitable using lean, mean management style. Since then built $875 million (sales) mining conglomerate, African Rainbow Minerals (ARM), with interests in a wide swath of minerals: platinum, nickel, chrome, iron, manganese and coal. Benefited from South Africa's Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) laws, which mandate that companies be at least 26% black-owned in order to get a government mining license. Also holds a 5.5% stake in Sanlam, a publicly traded financial services company outside Cape Town.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recently made millions betting that Citigroup and Wachovia would falter. Money man learned finance as a $200-per-week research assistant under Max Heine (d. 1988). Sold Heine Securities to Franklin Resources for $670 million 1996; stayed on for 5 years to fulfill contract. Now runs low-key investment outfit MFP Investors. Nearly all of the money believed to be his. Largest holdings: ConocoPhillips (energy), Conseco (insurance), Rowan Companies (drilling services). Trimmed stake in out-of-favor retailer Sears Holdings late last year.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Retired money man bullish on credit card companies Visa and Mastercard despite worries about overstretched consumers. Since 2000 has lorded over the ultimate fund of funds: invested in 30 hedge funds, many run by Tiger Management proteges. Last year his "Tiger Cubs" are believed to have lost an average of 25% net of fees after returning roughly 50% in 2007. Born in North Carolina, first job at Kidder, Peabody. Appointed to run firm's money management operation 1974. Founded hedge fund Tiger; assets grew to $22 billion in 1998. Averaged 31.5% annual return before fees. Then the tech bubble burst; suffered severe losses, investors fled. Parceled out cash to former employees; group includes celebrated managers Steve Mandel, Lee Ainslie. Also owns vineyards, golf courses in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Personally lost $500 million in past 6 months as investments in steel, textiles and auto parts have taken a tumble. Made fortune buying up distressed companies, still looking for a bargain: acquired 68% stake in Florida bank First Bank & Trust in January; invested $80 million in low-cost Indian airline SpiceJet last year. Paid $2.7 billion last year for stakes in bond insurer Assured Guaranty, mortgage banks Option One and American Home Mortgage. Joined Rothschild 1976; as bankruptcy specialist cleaned up messes left by Drexel Burnham junk bond financings. Founded W.L. Ross & Co. in 2000. Assets under management: $8 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Attended Northwestern on football scholarship; sold insurance for 5 years after graduating. Founded Pat Ryan & Associates insurance firm 1964; sold policies directly through car dealerships. Salesmen became well known for clean-cut image. Merged with Combined International in 1982; renamed Aon Corp. 5 years later. Now world's largest reinsurance broker. Shares down 10% since August. Retired as executive chairman. Minority owner of pro football's Chicago Bears. Made unsuccessful bid for baseball's Chicago Cubs last July. Co-chair of Obama's Presidential Inaugural Committee wants to bring Olympics to Chicago in summer 2016.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ryan Specialty Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Resigned as chairman of Broadcom last May. Pleaded guilty a month later for lying to the SEC; admitted he played a role in alleged Broadcom stock-option backdating. Received 5 years probation, $12.2 million fines. In September a federal judge rejected plea deal saying punishment too light; Samueli appealing. Investigation part of wider options-backdating probe into Broadcom, chip outfit Samueli founded with Henry Nicholas. Company forced to write down $2.2 billion, restate 2006 earnings. Shares down more than 30% since August. Met partner Henry Nicholas at TRW. Designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas' spare bedroom. Founded Broadcom in 1991; took public 7 years later.
title: Chief Technology Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Broadcom', 'uri': 'companies/broadcom', 'title': 'Chief Technology Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada&#39s cheese mogul is seeing his day in court — again and again and again. Filed lawsuit against Canadian media for associating him with the mob; including allegation that he was wanted by Italian police. Then filed legal challenge to country&#39s Federal Court against new cheese standards Canadian government instituted in December. In January Saputo was fined for advertising snacks to children under 13. The legal bills haven&#39t kept his cheese giant, Saputo, from shopping. Latest purchase: Neilson Dairy, the dairy division of Weston Foods, from fellow Canadian billionaire Galen Weston. Born in Sicily, started Saputo in Montreal in 1954 with parents. Delivered mozzarella by bicycle in the early days. Snapped up U.S. and Canadian dairies in the 1980s as pizza&#39s growing popularity boosted demand for his products. Still serves as chairman; son Lino Jr. is chief.

name: Billionaires
bio: Global recession hampering FedEx chief's fortune; stock down 53% since September, erasing more than $500 million from personal balance sheet. Yale grad envisioned integrated network of planes and trucks in senior thesis; launched Federal Express 1973. Today firm ships to 220 countries with more than 144,000 employees, 677 aircraft. Sales: $38 billion. Cut base salary 20% from $1.5 million to $1.2 million in January as part of a company cost reduction program. Owns stake in pro football's Washington Redskins; son Cannon a quarterback at University of Miami.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Austrian citizen settled in Hong Kong almost 40 years ago and married daughter of shipping tycoon Yue-Kong Pao. Now chairs BW Group, whose fleet of 141 oil tankers and gas carriers is one of world's largest maritime groups; includes publicly traded companies BW Gas and BW Offshore and privately held BW Maritime and BW Fleet. Group recently upped its stake in BW Gas from 62% to 76%.  Obtained $3 billion loan to aid in restructuring debt. Recipient of China's Friendship Ambassador award for his contributions to China-Austria ties. Southern Methodist University law school alumnus, supports a graduate scholarship program for Chinese lawyers studying at SMU's Dedman School of Law. Oxford and Harvard-educated eldest son, Andreas Sohmen-Pao, is managing director of BW Shipping Managers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical device heir's fortune fell nearly 40% in the past year after shares of Stryker dropped more than 50%. Grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) surgeon who created mobile hospital bed; started medical supplier Stryker Corp. Son Lee died in plane crash 1976. John Brown took reins; public in 1979. Now makes joint replacements, surgical tools, medical software. Third generation now controls 30% of medical device maker. Jon's foundation gives to progressive movements, support of great apes. Donated $1 million to fight California gay marriage ban.

name: Billionaires
bio: His much publicized renovation of New York's storied Plaza Hotel, which he purchased for $675 million in 2005, ran into snags this year as two lawsuits brought by two separate buyers claimed that the penthouses they purchased were not up to snuff; Tshuva's company says it has fulfilled its obligations. Plans to build a Plaza-themed megacasino in Vegas also turned sour: Tshuva's plot on the Strip is now worth half the $1.25 billion he and partner Nochi Dankner paid for it in 2007. Shares of his publicly traded Delek Group, which operates 232 gas stations and has interests in insurance, car dealerships and cable television in Israel, are down by half since last year. One potential upside: owns a minority stake in a recently discovered natural gas field off Israel's northern coast, which he believes could turn Israel into a gas exporter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Partnered with college buddy Mark Cuban to launch Broadcast.com during early years of dot-com boom. Broadcasted live sporting events, concerts over the Internet. Public 1998, sold to Yahoo a year later for $5.7 billion; made 300 employees millionaires, Wagner a billionaire. Broadcast.com no longer operating. Co-owns 2929 Entertainment, Magnolia Pictures, Landmark Theatres, HDNet. With Cuban, produced Robert De Niro flick "What Just Happened?"

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang's BYD Co. began selling its first electric and hybrid plug-in cars in China in December, with plans to introduce them to Europe and the U.S. by 2011. Shares are up 26% since last September, when Warren Buffett's MidAmerican Energy Holdings agreed to invest $230 million for a 10% stake. Former professor left his post at a government-affiliated research institute in Beijing in 1995 to found BYD Co., initially a rechargeable battery manufacturer. In 2003 BYD acquired a state-owned, midsize automaker in Xian. Now chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded textile company with nephew Olgun (now a billionaire dropoff), turning it into Turkey's largest exporter. Now his Zorlu holding company is active in consumer electronics, financial services and energy industries. Once bankrupt, his private-label TV maker and distributor Vestel today commands a large share of the European market. Making big energy play: expects to obtain $1 billion loan to build the largest of 4 Israeli power stations; building wind farm in Pakistan. High school dropout shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shoemaker's son used proceeds from Florida real estate investments to buy Miami TV station for $3.4 million in 1962. Eventually added 2 competing Boston stations. Nabbed a third Boston broadcasting unit in 2006; purchased CW Television-affiliated WLVI from Tribune Co. for $114 million. Also owns gobs of real estate in Florida, Indiana via Sunbeam Development.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: After father died when he was 8, raised by sports-loving mother. Mowed lawns, babysat, pumped gas in high school. Founded Aerotek in basement at age 23 with $3,500; staffed aerospace industry. Now owns majority stake in Allegis Group, nations largest staffing firm; places workers in aviation, mining, banking.  revenues: $5.6 billion. NFL's quiet owner lords over Baltimore Ravens. Rolled the dice last year with coach John Harbaugh, who had no head-coaching experience. "I've made a living on guys with thin resumes." Team was on cusp of Super Bowl berth this year.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Home Depot cofounder has watched the company he launched in the late 1970s lose 30% of its value in the last 12 months. Current market cap: $32 billion. Hardware outfit shuttering its high-end EXPO business, cutting 7,000 jobs. Do-it-yourself improvement icon co-founded Home Depot 1978 after short venture with Handy Dan. Handed out dollar bills with partner Bernard Marcus in parking lot to lure customers. Retired 1991. Pro football's Atlanta Falcons are most valuable asset today; team rebounded from loss of head coach Bobby Petrino and Michael Vick dogfighting scandal to make 2008 playoffs. Favorite T-shirt reads: "There is no finish line."
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Newcomer to World's Billionaires list owns spectacular art collection including pieces by Picasso, Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol, David Smith. Second son of eastern European immigrants born and raised in Philadelphia. First job: traveling liquor salesman. Built vitamin retailer Keystone Discount Stores. Merged with Philadelphia Pharmaceuticals 1967, cashed out for $1 million a year later, moved to Florida. Bought Cadillac dealership in Tampa 1972; today owns 16 dealerships in Miami, Palm Beach and Denver. Former owner of pro football's Philadelphia Eagles lost money in Madoff Ponzi scheme.

name: Billionaires
bio: Money manager's fortune dwindling after horrid bets on Washington Mutual and Countrywide Financial. Assets now fleeing: down 56% to $53 billion since early 2007. Global Equity Fund down 44% in 2008. Investment guru born in Pittsburgh, majored in economics at Bucknell. Graduate studies at San Diego State. Borrowed investment philosophy from Benjamin Graham; identifies companies whose stocks are trading below intrinsic value. Founded Brandes Investment Partners in 1974.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Alexander Machkevich (both also billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; stock of London-listed Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation down 54% over the past year. In July the trio's investment company, International Mineral Resources, took a 49% stake of Chinese carbon and stainless steel producer Jiuquan Iron & Steel. The Uzbekistan native lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals in Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief of Clark Enterprises builds the stadiums sports fans cheer in: Camden Yards and M&T Bank Stadium (Baltimore); FedEx Field, Verizon Center and Nationals Park (Washington, D.C.); Miller Park (Milwaukee); Petco Park (San Diego). Company also builds museums, theaters, airport terminals, jails. Sales: $4 billion. Real estate arm owns millions of square feet of office space in Washington, D.C. area, plus 15,000 residential units. U. of Maryland home to A. James Clark School of Engineering.

name: Billionaires
