bio: Father worked as business adviser to General Douglas MacArthur in Japan after WWII; saw opportunity in region. Founded logistics company William E. Connor & Associates in Tokyo 1949. "Chip": Stanford grad got M.B.A. from U. of Southern California, law degree from U.C. Santa Clara. Took over in 1980s; moved headquarters to Hong Kong. Firm now employs 1,400; 35 offices in 20 countries. Operates supply chain linking production to salesroom; helps clients cut out middleman. Specializes in apparel and home goods. Clients: Saks, Neiman Marcus, Nordstrom. Fortune down 40% in past year as cash strapped consumers keep their wallets closed, crushing retailers worldwide.

name: Billionaires
bio: Venture capital kingpin at firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has labored nearly 3 decades in Silicon Valley. Studied electrical engineering at Rice U., then Harvard M.B.A. Funded tech blockbusters: Sun Microsystems, Amazon, Intuit, Netscape. Also had a hand in some duds: AtHome, Handspring. Kleiner Perkins' $11.8 million investment in Google made him truly rich. Today on boards of privately held Zazzle, Purkinje, Good Technology, Spatial Photonics, Miasole. KP recently announced $500 million Green Growth Fund to battle climate crisis, $100 million fund for iPhone applications. Passionate believer in clean energy recently named as member of President Obama's Economic Recovery Advisory Board; told lawmakers investing green technology can help drive economic recovery. Brought on former Vice President Al Gore as a partner 2007.
title: Partner
employment: {'name': 'Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers', 'title': 'Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Why didn&#39t he take the money? Yahoo chieftain saw his stock languish for years, then pop 45% after Microsoft tried to snatch company up for $44.6 billion to take on Google in search. Balked at hostile takeover attempt; shareholder activist Carl Icahn led proxy battle to replace board, oust Yang as chief executive. Settled weeks later; Icahn and 2 friends now on expanded board. Met partner Jerry Yang in grad school at Stanford, turned Internet directory project into Web portal Yahoo. Left Ph.D. track 1995, took public a year later. Brought in professionals: Tim Koogle in 1995, former Warner Bros. boss Terry Semel 2001. Agreed to ad partnership with Google in June following Microsoft debacle; deal to deliver Google ads alongside Yahoo&#39s search results fell through months later.
title: Chief Yahoo (director)

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris founded music-and-jeans store Gap in San Francisco 1969; public 1976. Handed control of company--and nearly half their stock--to sons John, Robert and William in 2004; shares down 40% since August. Retailer recently pummeled as consumers shut wallets; reported 14% decline in December comparable-store sales over the same period a year earlier. Owns majority stake in pro baseball's Oakland A's.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: The recession continues to batter Gage and her sister Marilyn Carlson Nelson; combined fortune down $800 million in 6 months. Their Carlson Companies is heavily invested in hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's), travel agencies, all industries taking a hit as consumers reign in spending. Inherited family empire from father, Curtis, who founded Gold Bond Stamp 1938. Renamed grocery store promotion outfit as Carlson Companies 1973. Runs family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief executive of Banamex bank made almost $2 billion in 2001, when he sold it to Citigroup. Today owns more than 14 million Citigroup shares, recently worth $50 million, down from $375 million last year. Stepping down from Citigroup board in April but will remain chairman of Banamex. The bank will reportedly continue to reimburse Hernandez for airplane use and other services. Owns luxury resorts on the Yucatan Peninsula.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her five children, Gunter, Joachim, Michael, Wolfgang, and Daniela, inherited a fortune from her late husband, coffee magnate Max Herz. Personally owns 15% of consumer good group, Maxingvest AG; originally called Tchibo Holding, the group was run by her late husband, then by her son Gunter but nasty family feud led Gunter and Daniela to cash out in 2003. Sons Michael  and Wolfgang now control the holding.  Son Joachim  died last May after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake. Joachim, who was childless, left his share of the fortune to a charitable foundation in his name.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; stock of London-listed Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation down 54% over the past year. In July the trio's investment company, International Mineral Resources, took a 49% stake of Chinese carbon and stainless steel producer Jiuquan Iron & Steel. Native of Kyrgyzstan moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. Devout Muslim with 6 sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Berlin, Jarislowsky moved to Canada in 1949 after earning his M.B.A. at Harvard. Six years later founded Jarislowsky Fraser, asset manager that today manages $54 billion on behalf of institutional clients and high net worth individuals. Outspoken critic of excessive pay and "greedy executives," as well as government's mismanagement of current financial crisis. In addition to eclectic art collection that includes jade, Chinese furniture and Eskimo artifacts, owns private island in British Columbia with 16 miles of shoreline. Last December was promoted by Canada's Governor General to Companion, highest rank of the 3-tiered Order of Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in early 1990s; bank value has fallen 75% since last year as credit crisis brings Ukraine to brink of collapse. Last year sold iron ore and coke interests to Lanebrook Ltd., the major shareholder of Russian miner and steelmaker Evraz Group; received cash and shares in Evraz; those shares down 86% over past year. Focusing on oil and gas interests. Reportedly came to agreement with Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko: his former employee Valentyn Franchuk was appointed as deputy head of the state oil and gas company Naftohaz Ukrayiny; Tymoshenko will receive support from his One Plus One TV channel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Banking magnate started finance firm in 1985 with tractor tycoon Anand Mahindra, who still retains minority stake; converted it into a bank called Kotak Mahindra Bank in 2003.  In 1996, partnered Goldman Sachs in domestic securities and investment banking venture; bought them out in 2006. Today his Kotak Mahindra group is a financial conglomerate with interests in investment banking, mutual funds, life insurance and private equity. Shares of his Kotak Mahindra Bank sank 67% this past year, amid retail banking slowdown. Cricket fan and accomplished sitar player

name: Billionaires
bio: Auto dealer's son started used computer sales operation after a $3, three-line ad in the Chicago Tribune for his old IBM was met with high demand. Turned $300 profit on second sale. Founded Computer Discount Warehouse 1984; company became one of world's most profitable resellers of tech products. Retired 2001; company bought by private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in 2007. Donated more than $350 million in CDW shares to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairs Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon. Helped Natura founder (and fellow Brazilian billionaire) Luiz Seabra build Natura into multinational company, with consultants selling makeup and creams across Brazil and 7 other Latin American countries; it recently expanded to Venezuela and Colombia. Revenues for 2008 expected to be up 15% to $1.6 billion; the company listed its shares in Brazil in 2004. Personally promotes biodiversity and pushed a product line that uses renewable ingredients from the Brazilian rain forest. He is also an active board member of nonprofit groups, and has worked with the World Wildlife Fund of Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Math major at Chinese University of Hong Kong cofounded developer R&F Properties in China with Chinese billionaire Zhang Li. Shares in his Guangzhou R&F Properties have lost more than two-thirds. Group still opened hotels in 2008, including Ritz-Carlton and Grand Hyatt in Guangzhou and a Renaissance in Beijing. Li recently paid $6.5 million to buy one of R&F's apartments in the new Ritz-Carlton. Also holds stakes in brokerage firm Haitong Securities, KWG Property Holding. Reportedly paid $200,000 to buy a white truffle at auction in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Shui On Group is taking its hits: Shui On Construction announced January profit warning, while Shui On Land is delaying projects in western China's Yunan Province. Son of the late Lo Ying-shek, a prominent Hong Kong developer, struck out alone on the mainland. Became known as "Mr. Shanghai" for his promotion of China's international business hub. Wed former Miss Hong Kong Loletta Chu in November and transferred some of his shares to her name.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; stock of London-listed Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation down 54% over the past year. In July trio's investment company, International Mineral Resources, took a 49% stake of Chinese carbon and stainless steel producer Jiuquan Iron & Steel. Native of Kyrgyzstan studied literature; later moved to Moscow to start a trading business with Chodiev and Ibragimov. Early on obtained Israeli citizenship and has been very active in Jewish causes; authored Dialogue of Civilizations: The Next Stage, which was released last fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Protege of hedge fund legend Julian Robertson shaken amid market turmoil. Funds at his investment firm Lone Pine Capital fell between 26% and 44% in 2008. Personal fortune down $800 million. Rough year follows a stellar one: Lone Pine returned 57% in 2007. Today manages $13 billion across three funds. Consulting stint at Mars and Co., then Goldman Sachs. Became consumer analyst at Robertson's Tiger Management. Founded Lone Pine 1997; named hedge fund after tree in Dartmouth college lore that survived lightning strike. On board of Teach for America.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Derives fortune from 77% stake in Sun TV Network, country’s biggest regional broadcaster, with 20 channels. Also owns 45 FM radio stations, newspapers, magazines. Recently launched Sun Pictures, film production outfit. His Sun Direct, a direct-to-home satellite TV service provider, was launched 2007 in partnership with Malaysia’s Astro; competes with outfits of two fellow billionaires, Anil Ambani’s Big TV and Subhash Chandra’s Dish TV. One of Maran’s biggest rivals is Kalaignar, a broadcaster sponsored by his granduncle, M.Karunanidhi, chief minister of the southern state of Tamil Nadu, with whom he recently made amends after a bitter public falling-out in 2007. Brother Dayanidhi used to be telecom minister before family wars erupted, forcing him to resign.

name: Billionaires
bio: Home Depot cofounder has watched the company he launched in the late 1970s lose 30% of its value in the last 12 months. Current market cap: $32 billion. Hardware outfit shuttering its high-end EXPO business, cutting 7,000 jobs. Started do-it-yourselfers' paradise with partner Arthur Blank after getting fired from now defunct Handy Dan; took public 3 years later. Hung up tool belt in 2002 to focus on philanthropy. Donated $250 million to build the Georgia Aquarium 2001; Marcus Autism Center opened in Atlanta 2008. Took heat for October 2008 conference call where he said retailers not supporting GOP candidates "should be shot."
title: Co-founder, ex chairman of the board
employment: {'name': 'Home Depot', 'uri': 'companies/home-depot', 'title': 'Co-founder, ex chairman of the board', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold Cogen Technologies to Enron for $1.5 billion in cash and stock at peak of tech bubble; avoided exposure to free-falling market, Enron bankruptcy by selling stock right after deal closed. Used cash to become hometown hero; brought football back to Houston in 2002 NFL expansion. Stake in Houston Texans worth $618 million today. Team's home commands the priciest naming rights in U.S. sports: Reliant Energy paid $300 million in 2000 to call stadium Reliant Park for 30 years. Horseman sold Kentucky's Stonerside Stables to Dubai's Sheik Mohammed last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: The recession continues battering Nelson and her sister Barbara Carlson Gage; combined fortune down $800 million in six months. Their Carlson Companies is heavily invested in hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's), travel agencies, all industries taking a hit as consumers reign in spending. Inherited family empire from father, Curtis, who founded Gold Bond Stamp 1938. Renamed grocery store promotion outfit as Carlson Companies 1973. Stepped down as chief executive in 2008.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Billionaire bad boy has lost a third of his fortune as Broadcom stock dropped more than 30% in the past 6 months. Lost more paying stiff lawyer bills fees for various legal issues. Fighting ugly battle with ex wife over trust. She alleges in suit he threatened to "whack" her; hired men in gorilla masks to stalk her. Nicholas denies allegations. Indicted in U.S. District Court in June on charges of distributing ecstasy, cocaine and methamphetamine. In a separate indictment charged with backdating $2.2 billion worth of Broadcom stock options. Nicholas has pleaded not guilty to all charges; released on $3.3 million bail. Despite legal problems, funded the passing of California victim's rights law, Proposition 9. Met partner Henry Samueli while designing microchips at TRW. Launched Broadcom 1991 out of Nicholas' spare bedroom; designed high-speed telecom chips. Public 1998. Quit as chief exec in 2003 to "spend time with family." Options trial scheduled for February 2010, drug case later.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: Politician's son used a majority stake in African Petroleum to get himself appointed its chief executive last year. Now he plans to merge it with his private firm, Zenon, to create the continent's largest oil company. Deal has stalled in the face of government concerns about a monopoly, with his assets temporarily frozen last year. Nigerian regulators lifted the ban in January. Conflict abounds in Otedola's life: he claims his friend and fellow billionaire, Aliko Dangote, broke a gentleman's agreement when he thwarted Zenon's bid to buy Chevron's local subsidiary in September. In retaliation, starting buying shares in Dangote's publicly traded sugar company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile tycoon, helped turn family’s modest property firm into leading real estate developer in Mumbai. Split from siblings in 1996 to run his own real estate group, K. Raheja Corp., whose portfolio includes offices, malls, IT parks, hotels and special economic zones. Inked partnership with logistics firm ProLogis to build warehouses and a franchise agreement with Australian firm Servcorp to provide serviced offices. AIM-listed property fund Ishaan down 75%. Sons Ravi and Neel work with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of publicly traded Swiss luxury group Richemont, which owns Cartier, Dunhill and other premium brands. Stock down 70% since last February. His South African holding company, Remgro, is listing its stake in British American Tobacco on the Johannesberg exchange. But unbundling of the BAT stake will create pressure to find investments to replace the asset, say analysts. His private South African investment outfit, VenFin, finalized a much-anticipated deal to acquire British rugby club Saracens. With family relatives, owns two of South Africa's best-known vineyards, Rupert & Rothschild and L'Ormarins; also owns one of the country's most exclusive golf clubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Charles Schusterman (d. 2000), who started in oil and gas business 1961. Founded Samson Resources a decade later; grew into one of world's largest privately held energy companies. Daughter Stacy today runs Samson Investment; spent $4 billion in past 3 years on drilling and development. Operates more than 4,000 oil and gas wells; owns interests in another 11,000. Majority of revenues come from natural gas. Charles & Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation contributes to various Jewish causes; more than $100 million in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairs Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon, which he founded in 1969. Its “consultants” sell Natura&#39s cosmetics across Brazil and 7 other Latin American countries; it recently expanded to Venezuela and Colombia. Revenues for 2008 expected to be up 15% to $1.6 billion; the company listed its shares in Brazil in 2004. Fellow billionaire Guilherme Peirao Leal also serves as chairman. Media-shy Seabra reported to live in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chennai, India-born entrepreneur started at Netscape 1994. Created shopping site Junglee; sold to Amazon in 1998. Founded Sherpalo 2000, went on to back Yodlee, Zazzle.com (custom T-shirts, mugs, posters, stickers). Early investor, board member of Google still owns 1.3 million shares worth $450 million; stock down 30% in last 6 months. Today backs Indian, U.S. outfits: Mevio, 24/7 Customer. Sold online classifieds site StumbleUpon.com to Ebay last year; sits on board of similar Indian site Naukri.com. Says that the days of easy money are gone.
title: Managing Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical device heir's fortune fell nearly 40% in the past year after shares of Stryker dropped more than 50%. Grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) surgeon who created mobile hospital bed; started medical supplier Stryker Corp. Son Lee died in plane crash 1976. John Brown took reins; public in 1979. Now makes joint replacements, surgical tools, medical software. Third generation now controls 30% of medical device maker. Pat founder of Bohemian Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former junk bond guru at Goldman Sachs was down 17% in first quarter of 2008. Feared prolonged economic slowdown; directed money managers at his Appaloosa Management hedge fund to move billions of dollars out of equities and into cash between June and October of last year. Pittsburgh native "never got an A in high school." Attended Carnegie Mellon business school (renamed Tepper School of Business following $55 million donation). Left Goldman after failing to make partner; founded Appaloosa 1992. Fund up 150% in 2003; assets under management down 20% since 2007 to $5.5 billion.
title: President and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Appaloosa Management', 'title': 'President and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister in law Joan Tisch, controls family fortune built by their late husbands, famed investors Preston and Laurence Tisch. Duo started with small New Jersey hotel 1946. Acquired Loews Theatres 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. holding company includes diverse assortment of investments: oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk), insurance (CNA). Spun off cigarette maker Lorillard (Newport, Kent) to Carolina Group in 2007; last year sold Bulova watch group to Citizen for $250 million. Loews stock hammered by recenssion; shares down 56% in the past 12 months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger in 1985. Sold 80% of company to a British investor group for $800 million in 2002. Sold rest to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in July 2004 for estimated $360 million. Now retired.

name: Billionaires
bio: Industrialist is the main owner of copper producer UGMK-Holding and Transmashholding, Russia’s largest maker of locomotives and rail equipment. Transmahholding is forming a strategic partnership with French transport giant, Alstom Transport; according to a memorandum signed in October, the agreement provides for technical cooperation between the two firms and the possibility for Alstom to buy a 25% plus one share in TMH equity, pending due diligence. In addition, the two companies are creating a joint-venture to make double-deck coaches, mostly for Russian Railways.  Born in Bukhara, Uzbekistan, lived in Tashkent, then graduated from local university with degree in oriental studies. Put Arabic-language skills to use in various Soviet military organizations in Libya and Iraq. First moves as a businessman were with Trans-World Group, once the largest metals-trading operation in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: His mid- to high-end property developer, Guangzhou R&F Properties, has been beaten down on brokerage-firm downgrades and concerns about property-market bust. Company announced it would adjust prices on some projects to boost waning demand. Planned offering of its A shares has been delayed. Set up real estate firm with Hong Kong partner Li Sze Lim, also a billionaire, in 1994 after starting his career as a hotel industry executive. Zhang is its cochairman and president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leased a faltering iron and steel plant from government a decade ago. Bought 100% of it a year later and renamed it Jianlong Iron & Steel. Still runs group, which also has interests in mining, equipment manufacturing, shipbuilding. A subsidiary bought 10% stake in Australian mining firm IMX Resources in 2008. Steelmaking partners include fellow billionaire Guo Guangchang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wildcatter racked up a fortune in the petroleum business; more famous for his deep roots in pro-football. Today "Bud" helms NFL's $869 million Tennessee Titans franchise. Oklahoma native earned engineering degree from Kansas U, served in the Pacific during WWII. Established oil and gas supplier Adams Resources and Energy 1947, public 1974. Stock is down 40% over past 12 months. Purchased football's Houston Oilers with an initial investment of $25k, helped buddy Lamar Hunt establish the American Football League 1959. 38 years later, transported beleaguered team to the Volunteer State, eventually rechristening them the Titans. 1999 AFC Champs lost to the Rams in Super Bowl XXXIV. Sports nut also owned stake in the American Basketball Association's Houston Mavericks; Arena Football's now-defunct Nashville Kats. Part Cherokee, owns collection of Native American artifacts, Western art.

name: Billionaires
bio: With 3 billionaire brothers, Sulaiman, Saleh and Abdullah, built small desert money-changing business into world's largest Islamic Bank, Al Rajhi Bank. His stake down by nearly half over past year despite fact that sharia-compliant bank's ban on interest-earning loans helped shield it from credit crunch fallout. Via holding company he shares with his 6 sons, owns Saudi's third-largest steel producer, a plastic factory, a gypsum factory and a local mineral water brand. Group is rumored to go public on Saudi exchange in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-husband of billionaire heiress Esther Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Cortina, who married Esther's sister Alicia, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages fell apart in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. Sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004. Cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Alcorer reportedly enjoys hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime chairman of Kuwait's Gulf Bank resigned last October after the bank suffered $800 million in losses due to defaults on derivative trades. Kuwait's sovereign wealth fund was forced to take a 16% stake, earning the bank the dubious distinction of being the first local company to require a bailout. Brother Kutayba, also a billionaire, now chairs the bank. Remains involved at family trading group Alghanim Industries, a group of 30 retailing, manufacturing, advertising and shipping businesses. Father Yusuf founded group in 1932 and later became first person to introduce American cars to the country, through a deal with General Motors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Assumed chairmanship of Kuwait's Gulf Bank after disgraced brother Bassam resigned last October in aftermath of $800 million in losses due to defaults on derivative trades; the country's second-largest bank was the first Gulf institution to need a bailout since the credit crisis hit. Also heads family's trading conglomerate Alghanim Industries; a group of 30 retailing, manufacturing, advertising and shipping businesses. Father Yusuf founded group in 1932 and later became first person to introduce American cars to the country through a deal with General Motors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his sporting goods retailer Sports Direct International public in February 2007. Company, which has 465 stores and owns brands like Lillywhites and Lonsdale, lost half its value since last year amid the economic downturn. Talk of merger with JJB Sports; Sports Direct has a 22% stake in rival sportswear company. In May 2007 purchased popular soccer club Newcastle United. Tried to sell last September but took it off the market in December after no takers appeared.

name: Billionaires
bio: Value of private equity maven's Apollo Management has plummeted since selling a 9% stake to Abu Dhabi in November 2007. Firm once valued at $6.8 billion now worth less than $500 million. Worked with Michael Milken at Drexel Burnham Lambert 1980s; founded Apollo 1990 when Drexel collapsed. Annual returns through 2007: 30% net of fees. Two years ago, took Apollo quasi-public on private Goldman Sachs exchange. Acquired Linens 'n Things with partners in late 2005, company filed for bankruptcy last May. In January Apollo and affiliates agreed to pay $1 billion to settle dispute with Jon Huntsman over scuttled merger agreement between Huntsman Corp. and Apollo-owned chemical maker Hexion. Recently finished raising 7th private equity fund. Amount committed: $14.8 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Ihor Kolomoyskyy controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in early 1990s; bank value has fallen 75% since last year as credit crisis brings Ukraine to brink of collapse. Last year sold iron ore and coke interests to Lanebrook Ltd., the major shareholder of Russian miner and steelmaker Evraz Group; received cash and shares in Evraz; those shares down 86% over past year. Via his private company, Palmary Enterprises, won control over Australia's manganese ore miner Consolidated Minerals. Last fall launched a raid on Australia's OM Holdings, regarded as world's last independent supplier of high-grade manganese, sparking concerns he may try to corner supply of an important industrial mineral; company reinforced its takeover protection in response.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker became head of Banco Santander in 1986. Built it into Santander Central Hispano, one of the worldês leading banks; despite sector doldrums posted $12.2 billion in net profits in 2008. But his expertise couldn&#39t shield the bank from Madoff&#39s ponzi scheme:  Santander&#39s clients incurred $3 billion in exposure to the scam when one of Banco Santander&#39s  funds, Optimal Strategic U.S. Equity, commissioned Madoff to handle some investments.  Santander has offered to indemnify individual investors burned by the Madoff scam for their initial investment - but apparently not management fees or supposed investment gains. A class action complaint alleging negligence has been brought against the bank in Federal court in Miami. Daughter and heir apparent, Ana Botin, runs Banesto, bank&#39s retail branch. Botin&#39s great-grandfather discovered the famous Altamira caves in northern Spain in 1879. Emilio enjoys golf, hunting and fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile former banker derives chunk of his fortune from 2000 sale of Banco Bozano, Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano. In 2006 reportedly sold stakes in coffee plantation and Rio de Janeiro shopping center to new Brazilian investment fund. Owns a 10% stake in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer, the world's third-largest maker of airplanes. Bozano has invested in Azul, the new discount Brazilian airline launched by JetBlue founder and former chief executive David Neeleman. Owns race horses and is said to have a home in Greenwich, Conn.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rice trader turned media baron, his Essel Group owns television broadcaster Zee Entertainment, which has 500 million viewers in 167 countries; also owns Veria TV in the U.S., a wellness channel. Son Punit named Zee’s chief executive last August. Subhash’s brothers run Zee News and Dish TV. Other businesses include cable networks, online gaming, amusement parks, packaging, multiplexes. Co-owns DNA, a daily newspaper that competes with The Times of India. Launched his own cricket league. Practises Vippassana, a meditation technique; chairs the Global Vipassana Foundation which recently built a 325-foot-high stone pagoda in suburban Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford professor introduced students Sergey Brin and Larry Page, now billionaires, to venture capitalists Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Rewarded with a chunk of Google stock, which is down a third since last year. Reunited in late 2008 with past business partner Andreas Bechtolsheim, a German billionaire, in new outfit Arista Networks, a low-cost switchmaker aimed at competing with Cisco Systems; is founder and chief scientist of the venture. The pair's previous project, Granite Systems, sold to Cisco in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-husband of billionaire heiress Alicia Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Alcocer, who married Alicia's sister Esther, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages fell apart in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. Sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004.  Cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Said to like boating, collecting art and hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once China's richest man, Ding is the founder of China's No. 2 online game company, Netease. Its flagship game, Fantasy Westward Journey, is among nation's top 10 downloads. Signed 3-year contract with U.S. game developer, Blizzard Entertainment, to distribute StarCraft II and Battle.net to Chinese mainland. Netease's U.S.-listed shares were up 9% in past year, outperforming Nasdaq, where it trades, on double-digit profit growth. Ding is one of a rare group of billionaires who actually added to their net worth in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed the Hangzhou Jinjiang Group in 1993. The low-profile executive has led the company into power, textiles, waste management and paper industries. Announced $80 million waste-to-power project in December 2008 to be built in Wuhan in central China. Dou's business partners include the International Finance Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment guru bullish in near-term: "I like stocks for 2009 precisely because they did so badly in 2008." Father, Philip (d. 2004), was a well-known investor; made early fortune buying, holding growth stocks. Ken studied forestry, economics at Humboldt State U. Worked for dad before going solo 1973. Pioneered use of price/sales ratio in investment analysis. Writes regular column for Forbes. Fisher Investments currently manages $30 billion, down from $45 billion in August. Reads history books for fun; funds studies on coastal redwood trees. Owns $100 million in West Coast real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property developer has fared decently over past year thanks to conservative approach and distrust of debt. His two major assets are a 50% stake in Chadstone, Australia's biggest shopping mall, and a 17% stake in the listed property trust that owns the other half. Polish immigrant parents founded Sussan women's clothing chain. Gandel joined that business in the 1950s and eventually ran it. Sold Sussan to his brother-in-law, soon after buying Chadstone in 1983. With his wife, collects Japanese art. Recently donated $1 million to fight devastating bushfires in Victoria.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout joined the Marines in WWII, learned television repair on GI Bill. Used $1,500 in 1956 to create cable upstart in Liberty, N.Y.; soon grew into 5-channel system. Sold to Time Warner 4 decades later, netted $900 million. Invests proceeds through Granite Associates: hedge funds, private equity, real estate, Time Warner stock. Investments down an estimated 30% in last six months. Donates to environmental, educational, medical causes. Woodstock museum opened doors last June.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trinity U. graduate married Linda Pace, daughter of Pace Salsa founder David Pace. Cut vegetables on assembly line before finding niche in sales; became president 1977. Teamed with wife to buy company; bought her half for $95 million after divorce in 1991. Sold company to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion in 1996. Runs private equity group Silver Ventures.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Silver Ventures', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked at 5-and-10 in high school. Started arts and crafts retail chain Hobby Lobby with $600 loan. Projected 2009 sales: $2 billion. Fighting the recession: says frugal consumers opting for art projects over long vacations keeps Hobby Lobby ahead of competition. Poor preacher's son big supporter of Christian foundations, causes. Hobby Lobby closed Sundays. Has delivered over 350 million copies of Gospel to children in 100 countries through Book of Hope ministry. Son, Mart, founded Christian education, office supply chain Mardel.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his main holding company, Fosun International, public in August 2007; at the time said it was sixth-most-oversubscribed offering in Hong Kong stock exchange history; reportedly attracted such investors as legendary Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing. Chairman and chief executive cofounded Fosun in 1992 with fellow Fudan University grads; soon moved into pharmaceuticals, real estate. Other interests now include iron, steel, retail. Fosun International subsidiary Fosun Media became main shareholder in Nasdaq-listed Focus Media this year. Recently announced plans to publish Forbes China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Azerbaijan native took Turkish citizenship in 2006. Onetime ship cook repaired old Soviet ship. Now his Palmali Group has a fleet of 127 vessels that transport fuel. Expanding food operations in Azerbaijan. Military school and Soviet internal intelligence academy grad averages 4 hours of sleep nightly. Awarded medal from Russian defense ministry in September. Animal lover keeps dogs and monkeys in his botanic-garden-like Istanbul office; has built shelters for homeless animals in Russia and Azerbaijan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family fortune down more than a third as shares of BP plunged 35% in the past 6 months. Met husband John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995) in grade school. John parlayed $6,000 in craps winnings into construction giant: power plants, water systems, airports, South American pipeline. Bought coal reserves in eastern Kentucky, Tennessee in 1960s; sold to Amoco for stock during energy crisis in 1970s. Traveled the world, golfed, hunted quail. Son Raymond runs family money.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri, who left behind a $16.7 billion estate in 2005. Now based in Riyadh, helps oversee family's investments in telecom, media and real estate while older brother Saad carries on political legacy as Lebanon's parliamentary majority leader. Georgetown-educated engineer got start in ranks of global fixed-satellite-provider Intelsat. Now chairs U.S. identity-software management firm Epok, which sells to federal and state customers. Also serves on board of South African mobile phone operator Cell C.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of the late Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri inherited stake in his father's massive construction, telecom and real estate empire Saudi Oger after his death in 2005; investments value declining as markets slump. Serves on board of family's Future TV, a satellite and terrestrial television network covering the Middle East. Reported bachelor also spends time in Paris, home to mother, Nazek, who fell off this year's billionaire's list; runs a fledgling furniture design studio.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy global futures trader becomes a billionaire thanks to pro baseball's Red Sox. The club's majority owner built his fortune with hedge fund J.W. Henry and Associates; now worth just $11 million. Illinois native purchased baseball's Florida Marlins from Wayne Huizenga (see) 1999; sold three years later in deal with Expos' Jeffrey Loria. With partners Tom Werner and Larry Lucchino, bought Red Sox for $700 million 2002. Two years later led team to first championship in 86 years. Today his New England Ventures owns Sox, Fenway Park, 80% share of lucrative New England Sports Network. Auto racing buff owns 50% of NASCAR's Rousch Fenway Racing. Sox season tickets in danger of not selling out for first time since 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start selling eyeglasses, has investments in gem trader Xinu Zhongbao, conglomerate Zhejiang Xinhu Venture Investment and Harbin High-Tech Group. Unlisted investments in minerals may be injected into a listed company. In spare time low-profile executive runs club for Chinese chess.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago native's fortune comes courtesy of the gridiron. Father Robert (d. 1997) purchased the Baltimore Colts in 1972 for $15 million; 12 years later shocked local fans with "The Move," smuggling the franchise to Indianapolis after years of head-butting with city government. Jim graduated from Southern Methodist U., worked his way up from Colts' ticket counter to General Manager in two years. Father's 1997 death ignited legal battle with stepmother for team control; Jim emerged as the NFL's youngest owner at 37.  Earned first Super Bowl ring with Colts' 2006 victory over the Chicago Bears; team worth $1 billion today. Rock 'n' Roll aficionado has a home recording studio, guitar memorabilia. Bought original manuscript of Jack Kerouac's "On the Road" for $2.4 million 2001.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Green-tech advocate studied engineering at Indian Institute of Technology. Failed at attempt to start soy milk company catering to Indians without refrigerators. Earned biomedical master's at Carnegie Mellon, then Stanford M.B.A. Cofounded electric design automation company Daisy Systems in 1980. Two years later joined Andy von Bechtolsheim, Billy Joy, Scott Nealy to form Sun Microsystems. Served as chief executive for short time before turning to finance full-time 1996. Joined fellow Sun investor John Doerr (see) at venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins; started own firm 2004. Khosla Ventures funds 'science experiments': solar panels, clean tech; Calpers reportedly looking to anchor new $1 billion Khosla fund.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Morocco, attended Clark U., then New York Law School. Ran bankruptcy operations at Cowen & Co.; approached by Robert Bass, agreed to manage small sum of money. With sister Sonia Gardner founded distressed debt brokerage Amroc Investments 1989; 6 years later siblings founded hedge fund Avenue Capital. Sold 15% stake to Morgan Stanley for $275 million in 2006. Firm's assets have fallen 20% to $17 billion since the fall.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of telecom PCCW, Hong Kong's leading phone company, made offer to take it private in November. Later sweetened offer after first bid was rebuffed, a move that helped win support from top U.S. shareholder advisory firms. Shareholders voted in favor of the $2.2 billion buyout offer on Feb. 4, but deal was delayed after allegations of vote-rigging surfaced. A judge has since given stock market regulators more time to investigate; a ruling is expected in early April 2009.  Li owns Hong Kong Economic Journal through nonbeneficial trust. Has cash to do deals after Landmark Marunouchi Building, in which he had 55% stake, sold for $1.7 billion, highest price for single piece of Tokyo real estate, in 2007. Youngest son of revered Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing borrowed $125 million from his father in 1991 to launch satellite outfit StarTV. Later sold to Rupert Murdoch for $950 million; used proceeds to start Pacific Century Group and buy PCCW.

name: Billionaires
bio: U. of Chicago grad founded investment research company Morningstar in his Chicago apartment with $80,000 in savings 1984; quarterly publication became analysis giant famous for its starred mutual fund ratings. Public 2005; shares down 55% since August. Recently expanded product line. Added fund data business from Standard & Poor's 2007, then acquired U.K. data, media and investor-relations Web site outfit Hemscott from Ipreo Holdings last January. Mansueto bought financial magazines Fast Company and Inc. from Gruner & Jahr for $35 million. Ad pages for Fast Company are reportedly up 24% from 2007, bucking the downward slide in the magazine industry.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: "Tex" first exposed to oil business at age 10 by wildcatter father W.A. (Monty) Moncrief Sr.; witnessed dad's discovery of 6-billion-barrel oilfield in East Texas. Studied petroleum engineering at U. of Texas; served in Navy during WWII. Worked with father at Moncrief Oil. In 1972 acquired one-third of Wyoming's Madden Deep natural gas field; remains company's biggest asset. Owns ranches on 20,000 undeveloped acres on Barnett Shale; halting development until big players like Chesapeake and XTO Energy improve techniques. Continues drilling throughout the West. Fortune down almost 50% in last six months as values of oil and gas assets dwindle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cisco stock down 40% since August; fortune off $500 million. U. of Wisconsin grad started career at Honeywell, joined networking firm Cisco as president and chief executive in 1988. Took the company public 2 years later. Increased sales from $5 million to more than $1 billion in 6 years. Stock soared dramatically during the tech bubble. Firm briefly the world's largest; market cap was $555 billion in 2000 but dwindled to $70 billion by the end of 2002 as the bubble burst. Market cap today: $86 billion. Became chairman emeritus 2006. With wife, Tashia, has donated $50 million to alma mater, pledged to give up to $175 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Nidec, a maker of micromotors used in DVDs, hard drives; camera shutters, robots, game-machine consoles. Hit by global downturn, net profits for latest business year expected to drop 32% to $289 million despite slashing costs and inventories. Has sponsored a skating team since 1953; 45 of the skaters have gone to the Olympics, including one who won gold at the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano.

name: Billionaires
bio: South African-born Neilson made his name as an investment guru by sidestepping the 1987 global equities market crash at BT Australia, the Australian arm of Bankers Trust where he worked as a fund manager. He left BT in 1993 to start his own boutique funds management group, Platinum Asset Management, with George Soros as a client and founding shareholder. Listed 25% of Platinum on the stock market in May 2007.  Cashed out nearly $500 million. Still holds 57% stake. He and his wife, Judith, are opening up an art gallery in Sydney to showcase Chinese contemporary art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former textile trader runs property group Kowloon Development, which announced $475 million in investment losses in October; stock has tanked. Began career as a textiles trader in Hong Kong. Expanded to Macau to obtain export quotas and branched into property investments. Big chunk of fortune comes from 2006 transaction, in which he sold personal property in Macau back to Kowloon. Wife and son are involved in business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton dropout had first score with Triangle Industries' acquisition of National Can 1985; sold company for $4.2 billion 1988. Bought Snapple from Quaker Oats for $300 million; sold company 3 years later to Cadbury Schweppes for $1.5 billion. Develops insights into brands by browsing supermarkets, frequenting fast-food chains. Two years ago, stepped down as chief of holding company Triarc (renamed Wendy's/Arby's Group after merger with Wendy's last fall), stayed on as non-executive chairman. Today controls 22% of Wendy's/Arby's via investment firm Trian. Raised $1 billion for "blank check" company in January 2008; poised to make acquisition.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Served as national finance chair for President Obama's run last year; led record-breaking fund-raising campaign. Now one of the President's advisers; named to Economic Recovery Advisory Board. Also helped run the Presidential Inaugural Committee. Member of Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited chairmanship of Turkey's Dogus Holding conglomerate. Media and auto profits squeezed as result of financial crisis; partner Volkswagen delaying investment in Turkey. In December 2007 raised stake to 30.5% in its major holding, Garanti Bank, in part with a $580 million loan; the bank's stock has fallen almost 50% over the past year. At this year's Davos warned world might be headed for social crises; supports cutting deal with International Monetary Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to T. Mellon & Sons banking fortune is enduring a nasty public divorce from his second wife, Ritchie. Salacious divorce documents became public after a clerk at the county court accidentally published the sealed documents online. Docs exposed the value of various personal trusts, as well as some odd behavior. Example: Ritchie took Scaife's favorite dog, Beauregard, after the couple separated. Scaife placed a sign on his front lawn reading: "Wife and dog missing. Reward for dog." Staunch conservative, owns Pittsburgh Tribune-Review newspaper, as well as Pennsylvania radio stations. Supports right-wing policy via Heritage Foundation. Strange twist: gave to $250,000 to former President Clinton's charitable foundations; donors were disclosed in December as Hillary was being vetted for new gig as Secretary of State.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned his first rubles in late 1980s helping foreign tourists find rooms in Moscow hotels. In 1990 worked as a consultant for Italian confectionary Ferrero Rocher; then started selling Italian vermouth, winning an exclusive contract with Martini & Rossi. In 1998 created the first ever upmarket brand of Russian vodka, Russian Standard. In 1999, with help of McKinsey & Co., set up Russian Standard Bank, pioneering consumer credit market; became market leader three years later. Bank's pre-tax profit fell 50% in 2008 to $245 million, but vodka business is thriving: introduced two new Russian vodka brands last year and now distributes to 60 countries. Company operates Miss Russia pageant.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs board of his family's Yildiz Holding. Completed $850 million purchase of Godiva from Campbell Soup Co. last year; expanding into new products and markets in 2009. Owns candy and sweets factories in Uzbekistan, Ukraine and Saudi Arabia. Cut teeth working at his father's Ulker Food Co. and at Continental Baking Co. in the U.S. before joining Yildiz. Enjoys sailing, hunting and travel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemical engineer grandfather John T. Dorrance developed method of canning condensed soup that used half as much water, reduced costs by a third. Result: Campbell Soup Co. Today world's biggest soupmaker. Sales: $8 billion in 2008. Earnings slumped in latest quarter as consumers wait longer to restock their cabinets. Stock down 28% in past six months. Publicly traded firm also controls Pace (salsa), Pepperidge Farm (Goldfish, crackers), Prego (spaghetti sauce).

name: Billionaires
bio: Considered the brains behind NYSE-listed telecom Turkcell; his idea for the mobile phone company was funded by billionaire Mehmet Karamehmet. Sat on Turkcell board from 1993 until May 2005; sold partial stake last year. Bought one of Turkey's largest hotels in Izmir, the Grand Efes for $121 million in October 2005; newly renovated facilities opened in 2008. Started Turkish search engine Hakia 2006. Rents out his 120-foot yacht, Jasmin, docked at Antibes, France, for $90,000 per week in the low season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Viessmann Werke GmbH, $1.8 billion (sales) maker of boilers and heating equipment. Grandfather founded group more than 90 years ago. Ran company since 1993 then last summer moved over to supervisory board to concentrate on company strategy. Company supports the  Viessman Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers; also sponsors cold weather sports like skiing and sledding as well as Formula One racing. President of the Kassel Chamber of Commerce, treasurer of Marburg University. Has a professional pilot's license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemical engineer grandfather John T. Dorrance developed method of canning condensed soup that used half as much water, reduced costs by a third. Result: Campbell Soup Co. Today world's biggest soupmaker. Sales: $8 billion in 2008. Earnings slumped in latest quarter as consumers wait longer to restock their cabinets. Stock down 28% in past six months. Publicly traded firm also controls Pace (salsa), Pepperidge Farm (Goldfish, crackers), Prego (spaghetti sauce).
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: "Meg" took first step in running for California governor; recently formed exploratory committee. Former eBay chief fueled her political dreams serving as National Co-Chair of John McCain's campaign last fall; also advised Mitt Romney. Left boards eBay, Procter and Gamble and DreamWorks in January to focus on her campaign. Will run as a Republican in 2010, but has only been registered as one since 2007; previously "decline to state." Settled rights to domain name Meg2010.com in January, previously held by cyber-squatters. Promises to create 2 million private-sector jobs by 2015. Harvard M.B.A. held posts at Hasbro, Keds, Procter & Gamble, FTD, Disney, Bain & Co. before landing job as eBay's chief auctioneer post in 1998. Steered company through Internet boom, then bust; stepped down as chief exec last March. Stock down 60% since.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been a rough year and a half: embattled Yahoo co-founder stepped down as chief executive in January after company named Carol Bartz to replace him, fueling speculation that merger talks between Microsoft and Yahoo might resume. Many believed he botched Microsoft $44.6 billion offer, balking at takeover attempt despite the 62% premium Microsoft was reportedly willing to pay for Yahoo shares. Settled proxy contest with shareholder activist Carl Icahn for control of the company; Icahn and 2 friends now on expanded board. Met partner David Filo in grad school at Stanford, turned Internet directory project into Web portal Yahoo. Left Ph.D. track 1995, took public a year later. Brought in 'professionals': Tim Koogle in 1995, former Warner Bros. boss Terry Semel 2001. Agreed to ad partnership with Google last June following Microsoft debacle; deal to deliver Google ads alongside Yahoo's search results fell through months later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older brother of appliance billionaire Zhang Jindong, makes his own mark in real estate. His Suning Universal (not to be confused with brother's Suning Appliance) is listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Business focused in Nanjing, the capital of Jiangsu province. Son Zhang Kangli shares wealth and sits on board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took control of Grupo Televisa when his father died in 1997. Company operates radio, satellite, Internet and publishing businesses, and in recent years has diversified into off-track betting and a discount airline. In January 2009 it settled a lawsuit with Univision, the top U.S. Spanish-language broadcaster that Azcarraga Jean tried and failed to buy in 2007. Televisa had sued Univision for breach of contract, accusing the company of underpaying for the lucrative telenovelas. Also tangled with the Suprema Corte de Justicia de la Nacion, which struck down provisions in a 2006 radio and television law designed to protect Televisa from new competition. In response, group is shoring up its efforts outside Mexico, exporting telenovelas to additional countries. In 2007 signed a deal with the Chinese government to make Chinese versions of its soap operas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and former chairman of Astroc Mediterraneo S.A. Made his debut as a billionaire in 2007 worth $7.7 billion. Lost $6.4 billion within a year amid rumors of inflated earnings and a cooling property market in Spain. The company, now called Afirma Grupo Inmobiliario, dropped another 85% in the past year. Banuelos still makes ranks, barely, thanks to stock sales, including one in December. Apparently trying his luck again in Latin America, notably Brazil, where he has recently acquired a stake in real estate company Abyara. Runs a private foundation promoting Spain's cultural heritage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tough year for "long-term" value-oriented investor: his Baron Asset Fund was down 41% in 2008. Borrowed $1,600 to invest in nursing home operator Manor Care 1969; company acquired by the Carlyle Group for $4.9 billion last year. Founded Baron Capital 1982. Today manages $12 billion, down a third from the fall. Hosts popular annual investors conference; last year's event was headlined by Jerry Seinfeld, drew 4,000 guests. Past conferences have featured performances by Elton John, Sheryl Crow, Bette Midler, and Cher. Paid $100 million for a 40-acre estate in the Hamptons in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate and private equity kingpin scathed by exposure to casinos, high-end hotels; fortune down $1.3 billion since last March. Attended U. of Southern California. Studied law at U. of San Diego, became international finance attorney. Worked on real estate side of Robert Bass' investment firm. Founded Colony Capital 1991. Made first fortune buying up bad real estate loans from struggling S&Ls. Today firm manages $31 billion. Invests in businesses with underlying real estate assets: Station Casinos, Costa Smeralda (hotel) in Sardinia. Last May bought $23.5 million mortgage of Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch from Fortress Investment Group, brought financially troubled pop star to negotiation table.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to run Verlagsgruppe Bauer, mass-media company founded by his grandfather 1875. The $2.6 billion (sales) group publishes everything from TV guides to special interest publications like Auto Zeitung (cars) and Kochen & Geniessen (cooking), to magazines like Neue Post and Das Neue Blatt. U.S. titles include First for Women, Woman's World and InTouch. Sells in 14 countries including Mexico, Russia and China. Is now one of Britain's largest radio producers after acquiring various divisions from British media company Emap.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iceland's lone billionaire had a chilling year. The government seized Landsbanki, the bank in which he and his father, Bjorgolfur Gudmundsson, were the biggest individual shareholders, rendering their holding worthless. It was enough to wipe out the fortune of Thor's father, who was also the bank's chairman. Luckily Thor had other assets outside of Iceland. Sold his shares in Finnish telecom operator Elisa for $330 million. Accumulated stake in Amer Sports, which owns Wilson, Solomon brands. Diluted holding in Polish telecom Play to 25% from 35%. Stake in Icelandic investment bank Straumur nearly worthless. Rumored to be selling his most valuable holding, Actavis, the generics firm he took over in an $8 billion leveraged buyout in July 2007. Got his start in Russia, where he cofounded Bravo brewery and created popular Botchkarov beer brand. Sold to Heineken February 2002. Lives in London with longtime girlfriend, who is a movie producer, and their son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rough year for cofounder of private equity colossus TPG (formerly Texas Pacific Group). Net worth down $2.3 billion in past 12 months as lack of liquidity and stalling economy wreak havoc on private equity firms. TPG provided $1.3 billion cash infusion to Washington Mutual bank for discounted shares in early 2008; bank was seized by the government months later, wiping out shareholders. Met James Coulter while working for Robert Bass. Pair left to pursue first deal together: propped up Continental Airlines with $66 million investment, stake worth $700 million 5 years later. Started Texas Pacific Group in 1992. Bonderman founded Fort Worth office, Coulter settled in San Francisco. Thrive on dizzyingly complex deals. Winners: Burger King, J. Crew, Petco. Manage $60 billion with affiliates today.

name: Billionaires
bio: Textile entrepreneur owns Gap Textile, one of the world's top 10 denim producers, which sells products to Diesel, Levi Strauss, Armani, Gap and other Western brands. Last April made big media push with $1.1 billion purchase of Turkey's second-largest media company, Sabah and ATV. His company publishes Forbes Turkey, under license from Forbes Media LLC. Plans to expand energy and telecommunications businesses may be constrained by tightening markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beekeeper's son from small North Island town now heads all-in-one billion-dollar investment firm, venture fund and think tank, Legatum. Made first fortune when he and brother Richard, also a billionaire, invested proceeds from selling parents' department store in Hong Kong real estate. Together founded investment firm Sovereign Global in Monaco, focusing on transitioning industries in Russia, Latin America and eastern Europe. After racking up success investing in transitioning economies like Latin America and eastern Europe, brothers amicably split to go solo. Based in Dubai, Legatum continues investment approach of predecessor with special emphasis on socially sustainable enterprises, such as microfinance. Heavily invested in India. Founded Legatum Centre for Development & Entrepreneurship at MIT, which sponsors students from developing countries who aspire to launch businesses back home.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beekeeper&#39s son now one of Asia’s biggest philanthropists and most innovative investors. Made first fortune when he and brother Christopher, also a billionaire, invested proceeds from selling parents&#39 retailing business in Hong Kong real estate. Together founded investment firm Sovereign Global, focusing on transitioning economies in Russia, Latin America, Asia and eastern Europe. Brothers amicably parted ways in 2006; Richard founded Orient Global in Singapore, continuing his focus on value investments in emerging markets with emphasis on social returns. Recently set up $100 million fund aimed at improving education in the developing world, beginning with India. Lent artist mother a reported $4 million to open Manhattan gallery for her paintings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Fuyao Group, which makes glass used in automobiles. Customers include Audi, Ford, Fiat, Nissan.  Announced in February that he would donate 70% of his family's shares in Fuyao to charity, making him one of China's most generous businessmen when the fund is actually set up. The focus of this giving will be education, disaster relief and poverty. Government officials lauded Cao's act as a new model for business leaders.

name: Billionaires
bio: Just barely a billionaire; has lost $300 million since September. Former Procter & Gamble product manager developed Quicken personal finance software to combat wife's complaints about balancing her checkbook. Cofounded Intuit with Tom Proulx 1983; public a decade later. Today products include TurboTax, Property Manager, QuickBooks, Medical Expense Manager. Stock down 30% from September highs. Active philanthropist funds business school program at wife's alma mater, U. of Wisconsin; Intuit Tax Freedom Project donates free tax prep to 18 million low-income people annually.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plumber's son attended Hunter College, became a Xerox quality control engineer in 1965. Carpooled to business school at Columbia U. with investor Mario Gabelli. Took job at Goldman Sachs in investment research, eventually ran asset management division. Created hedge fund firm Omega Advisors in 1991. Today Omega manages $3 billion in assets, down from $5 billion last year. Said to have returned 14% net of fees annually. On board of Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Hanging on to billionaire status despite his stake in outsourcing outfit Syntel losing 45% of its value since September. Born in Kenya, moved to India at age 11. Studied engineering at Indian Institute of Technology, moved to U.S. in 1976 for programming job at Tata Consultancy Services. Founded Syntel with wife, Neerja Sethi, while earning M.B.A. from U. of Michigan. Took company public 1997. Today firm outsources client's information technology and business process operations overseas, mostly to Asia. Sales: $410 million. Adding capacity in India. Cardplayer represented India in bridge world championship 1995.
title: Chairman and Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Sharp-tongued titan's InterActiveCorp split into 5 companies last August: HSN, Ticketmaster, Interval Leisure Group, Tree.com and IAC now traded separately. Stocks have fallen vastly since. Ticketmaster and Live Nation announced merger plans in February; will create world's largest ticketing and artist entertainment firm, prompting outrage from artists and concertgoers concerned about price hikes. Investors wonder what Diller will do with IAC's war chest of $1.9 billion; reportedly biding his time, waiting for prices to drop. Wealthy developer's son dropped out of UCLA for mailroom job at William Morris Agency. Later became executive at ABC, Paramount; created then-unheard-of Fox Broadcasting Co. in 1980s for Rupert Murdoch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of York Capital hedge fund bruised by market turmoil: firm's funds down an average of 23% in 2008. Assets under management: $10 billion. Worked first at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, then at Kellner DiLeo. Market crash of 1987 wiped out life savings, instilled mistrust of investing on margin. Like John Paulson, shorted subprime credit two years ago. Leverage-free returns have averaged 15% a year since 1990.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Highbridge Capital hedge fund and private equity outfit smarting from tumultuous 2008: flagship "Multi-Strategy" fund down 24%, computer-based "Statistical Opportunities" fund up 22.1%. With grade-school buddy Henry Swieca launched Highbridge in 1992. Sold 55% stake to JPMorgan in 2004 for more than $1.3 billion; duo still controls investment decisions. Assets down 44% from peak in July 2007 to $20 billion today. Married doctor who is a former Miss Sweden; couple funded breast cancer center at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded back-office software giant PeopleSoft in 1987; took public 1992. Stepped down from day-to-day operations in 1999, continued as chairman until selling to Oracle's Larry Ellison for $11 billion in 2005. Cornell grad set up $10 million fund for ex-employees unable to find new jobs. Early investor in background check firm HireRight. Now hoping to create new fortune with enterprise software startup Workday. Animal-loving philanthropist a trustee of Maddie's Fund (named after his late miniature schnauzer) to help make America a "no-kill zone" for unwanted pets.
title: Chairman and co-CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: In February, the mastermind behind superfashionable Dyson vacuum wrote to the Guardian newspaper, "Let engineers make Britain great again." Dyson donated $10 million to London's Royal College of Art after his ambitious plan to launch a design and innovation school at the site of a flood plain in Bath collapsed when the government rejected the school's proposal. Went to art school to study design and engineering. Ran through 5,127 prototypes until he perfected G-Force, an upright vacuum that uses spinning technology to maintain constant suction. Introduced his vacuum in U.K. in 1993, and it was an immediate hit. Guards technology zealously. In January won a patent-infringement case against Samsung Electronics. Stated: "We may not be a commercial giant like Samsung, but we will vigorously defend all the technology we have worked hard to develop and protect."

name: Billionaires
bio: Maritime lover got sea legs as a kid; rebuilt small boat and sailed around Lake Washington. Later crafted sailboats in his Seattle garage before founding Bayliner Marine Corp. in 1955. Doubled revenue every 3 years; sold to Brunswick for $425 million 1986. Invested proceeds in stocks, bonds, real estate. Spends days flying helicopters, skiing, cruising in new 164-foot yacht, Evviva. Donated $5.4 million to Arizona State University for student entrepreneurs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Israeli conglomerate Federmann Enterprises started by late father and uncle. Chairs boards of its 2 biggest publicly traded holdings: defense elctronics maker Elbit Systems and luxury hotel operator Dan Hotels Corp. The hotel group began as a boarding house on the Tel Aviv seafront; now expanding into India. Also deputy chairman of the board of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem and a board member of Weizmann Institute of Science.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris founded music-and-jeans store Gap in San Francisco 1969; public 1976. Handed control of company--and nearly half their stock--to sons John, Robert and William in 2004; shares down 40% since August. Gap pummeled as consumers shut wallets; reported 14% decline in December comparable-store sales over the same period a year earlier. Board member; stepped down as interim chief executive August 2007.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Buyout titan grew up wealthy in Greenwich, Conn.; played hockey at Yale. Law school at Columbia. With brother, founded private equity firm Forstmann Little 1978. Critic of junk bonds made hundreds of millions buying, growing, flipping Gulfstream Aerospace and General Instruments. In 2004 bought talent agency IMG for $750 million. Company's clients include golfer Tiger Woods, model Gisele Bundchen. Owns 24 Hour Fitness. Linked to Top Chef cohost Padma Lakshmi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of country's largest private logistics company, got start selling soft drinks out of the back of a single truck in 1957. Today company Linfox boasts truck fleet of 5,000, 20 million square feet of warehousing, 2 airports and 1,000 armored vehicles. Former pro in Australian Rules Football League, also has large industrial and personal property holdings including Grand Prix racetrack on Victoria's Phillip Island. Avid car fan, owns 130 rare classic cars (among them, a V12 Enzo Ferrari and 1937 Mercedes once owned by the German ambassador to London) all displayed at his Queensland museum. Sold down stake in Bank of Queensland late this year, reportedly to free up cash to grow Linfox deeper into Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil tycoon has braved war and corruption to build an empire on the cheap. Started as an oil trader in the 1970s; made friends with West African potentates like Nigeria’s Sani Abacha and later moved crude for Saddam Hussein. Today his Addax Petroleum produces 130,000 bbl. per day from Nigeria and Sao Tome. Hired Nigerian navy to protect offshore assets after militant attack last year left one dead. Acquired more oilfields in northern Iraq. His collection of Egyptian antiquities among best in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mexico's most wanted man, "El Chapo", or Shorty, heads the Sinaloa cartel, one of the biggest suppliers of Cocaine to the U.S. In 1993 was arrested in Mexico on homicide and drug charges. Escaped from federal prison in 2001, reportedly through the laundry, and quickly regained control of his drug trafficking organization, which he still controls today. In 2008 Mexican and Colombian traffickers laundered between $18 billion and $39 billion in proceeds from wholesale shipments to the U.S. Shorty, an alleged tunnels expert, is believed to have directed anywhere from a third to half of that during the past 8 years. Apparently started out working with Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, "El Padrino", or the Godfather, head of the most powerful drug trafficking group in Mexico at that time. U.S. government is offering a $5 million reward for his capture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemical engineer grandfather John T. Dorrance developed method of canning condensed soup that used half as much water, reduced costs by a third. Result: Campbell Soup Co. Today world's biggest soupmaker. Sales: $8 billion in 2008. Earnings slumped in latest quarter as consumers wait longer to restock their cabinets. Stock down 28% in past six months. Publicly traded firm also controls Pace (salsa), Pepperidge Farm (Goldfish, crackers), Prego (spaghetti sauce).

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean immigrant celebrated 50th anniversary of the founding of his privately held Maruhan, Japan's largest operator of pachinko parlors, in June 2008. Classical music fan had party with 2,000 guests featuring a performance by the Tokyo Philharmonic Orchestra. Opened hotel casino in Macau and commercial bank in Cambodia last year. Has Mister Donut and Seattle coffee chain, Zoka, franchises. Art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime head of Banamex made a fortune when company was sold to Citigroup in 2001; then trading around $45 a share, Citi stock has plummeted to a recent $1 a share. In 2008 bought majority stake in sporting goods retailer and gym Grupo Marti. An active philanthropist who's serving as president of 2 Banamex-affiliated foundations. A baseball fanatic, Harp also owns the Red Devils, a minor league team in Mexico City. Cousin of Mexico's richest man, Carlos Slim Helu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Century Golden Resources Group, with business in real estate, hotels, and minerals. His Beijing Century Golden Resources Shopping Mall attracted Gome, the appliance chain headed by former billionaire Wong Kwong Yu, as a new tenant last year. Owns stake in Bank of Beijing. Donated $40 million last year, making him the most generous individual domestic donor to Mainland causes last year, according to a government-connected research body. Philanthropy last year was centered around Yunnan Province. Among the causes he supported there: relief for the elderly, education support and financial assistance to farmers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his fortune as an original investor in Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. He has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998; now focuses on venture capital and philanthropy in Israel. As principal of Aurum Ventures, has invested in a dozen emerging life-science and tech companies like Atlantium, which specializes in water disinfection; and N-Trig, which makes a multitouch screen for computers. Lives on Israel's Mediterranean coast and spends most of his time on a 100-foot yacht. Cofounder of Coral World International, a string of aquariums in locations such as the Bahamas and Australia; still owns a 50% stake. Son, Benjamin, is a marine biologist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iranian-born academic and former art dealer&#39s primary passion—and source of wealth—is likely the largest private collection of Islamic art, including more than 20,000 objects spanning 1,400 years. Artifacts include ceramics, textiles, metalwork, glass and Qu&#39ranic manuscripts. Interest in Islamic art increasing: Sotheby&#39s and Christie&#39s both set records at semiannual Islamic art auctions last year; Qatar debuted I.M. Pei-designed Museum of Islamic Art in a blaze of fireworks in November. Real estate holdings in and around London down.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in a small town near Moscow. In 1995 joined Alisher Usmanov&#39s (also a billionaire) metals group, for a time serving as chief executive of one of his companies. In April 2006 sold out to Usmanov. In 2007 used some of the capital to buy National Standard Bank and NovorossCement, Russia&#39s third-largest cement producer. NovorossCement delisted last year and is now a private company, held by Kvetnoi. Is also apparently largest shareholder in Moscow’s Vnukovo Airport and main shareholder in a number of the airport service companies, including an airplane-repair factory.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plunging oil prices and slump in refining industry have sliced $300 million from the personal balance sheet of this intensely private tycoon in the past year. Ole Miss grad founded Ergon in Jackson, Miss. 1954; turned company into refining and chemicals giant. Today owns refineries in Arkansas, Mississippi, West Virginia. Subsidiary develops communications, security equipment. Other companies include fuel distributor Lampton Love and an asphalt business. Also owns an ethanol factory in a joint venture with Bunge; plant will make 54 million gallons of ethanol a year in Mississippi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korea's richest woman heads retailer Shinsegae, once part of Samsung Group, founded by her late father, Lee Byung Chull. Still quotes her father's management aphorisms to her employees. Shinsegae has grand plans to expand into China and become one of the top 10 retailers in the world within 4 years. Upped her stake in Shinsegae by 150,000 shares last fall; now holds a 17% stake. Her powerful family has been caught up in a scandal in which they  allegedly bought valuable art with Samsung money. Brother Lee Kun-Hee, also a billionaire, stepped down as Samsung chairman last year amid charges of corruption.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out growing vegetables, selling rice. Began developing property in his late twenties. Now publisher of Liberty Times, Taiwan's No. 1 daily and champion of island's democratic reforms and international relations. Also has holding in Union Bank of Taiwan. Former Taiwan legislator was a national policy adviser to 2 past presidents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father got start making watering cans in summer and hot water bottles in winter. Eventually founded Loh KG in 1961. Friedhelm, his second-born son, took over 13 years later. Company, now known as the Friedhelm Loh Group, manufactures  safes,  post boxes, intercom systems and switch boxes that protect electrical and electronic circuits. Has $2.7 billion in sales, with more than 11,000 employees in 74 plants worldwide. Known for his religious beliefs, has established the Christian Media Foundation, publishers of Christian literature. Avid collector of antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deputy chairman and a shareholder of $1.4 billion (sales) Coloplast, a Danish health care company that makes medical devices in the fields of ostomy and urology such as colostomy bags and catheters. Also makes dressings for wounds. Stock off only 4% in past year. His late father, Aage Louis-Hansen, founded the company in 1957; took it public in 1983.

name: Billionaires
bio: Football tycoon narrowly missed another Super Bowl berth; his Philadelphia Eagles were edged by Arizona in January's NFC Championship game. Born into well-to-do Boston family; grandfather Philip Smith (d. 1961) built family fortune through movie theatre operator General Cinema, investments. Jeffrey taught social policy at Boston U.; abandoned academia for bright lights of Hollywood. Founded Chestnut Hill Productions 1985; produced string of so-so films including "I Love You To Death" and "Foxfire," one of the first flicks to feature Angelina Jolie. Bought Eagles in 1994 from billionaire Norman Braman for $195 million. Estimated value today: $936 million. Serves on NFL's Finance, Broadcast, Super Bowl Advisory Committees. Helped cement deal to build $512 million, 68,500-seat Lincoln Financial Field 2001. Also serves as a director of the Autism Research Foundation and the Nancy Lurie Marks Family Foundation.

name: Billionaires
