bio: Investments in booming oil storage, energy insurance businesses tempering losses from economic slowdown. Raised in the Bronx. Studied economics at City College of New York; then Wharton M.B.A. Learned investing at Oppenheimer from Wall Street legend Leon Levy. Cofounded private equity outfit First Reserve; launched first buyout fund 1992. Invested $10 million in drilling equipment producer National Oilwell 1996; reaped $240 million selling stake over 6 years. Plowed First Reserve proceeds into several coal companies in 2004. Assets under management up 20% to $20 billion since last summer. Enjoys bird-watching.

name: Billionaires
bio: After sale of jointly-owned pipe producer TMK in fall of 2006, began divvying up assets with partner, billionaire Sergei Popov. Now aggressively defending his fertilizer business. After dip in sales of his Eurochem, reportedly lobbied Russian president, Dmitry Medvedev, to repeal export tax on fertilizers; In February, tax abolished. Buying into potash producer, Germany's K+S, to ensure supply; trying to get its own potash mine operational by 2014. Despite the downturn, debuted his new $350 million yacht, A, named after his wife's first initial, in the Mediterranean last year. Started out with chain of currency-exchange booths; founded MDM Bank in 1993. Met Popov and pair began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal producer, which they still jointy control.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Akira Mori, also a billionaire, inherited real estate fortune from late father. Siblings who have vastly different approaches to property development went their separate ways in 1999; Minoru is known for grandiose projects such as the Shanghai World Financial Center, China's tallest building, which opened in 2008. Last year raised capital to help fund new development.  New plans include a 47-story tower in Japan's capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Transportation tycoon owns Ambassador Bridge; conduit for one-fourth of commerce between U.S. and Canada. The bridge could be getting competition; Michigan and Canada are planning on building their own span nearby. Detroit native grew up poor, worked in gas station as a teenager. Crunched numbers for father's Central Cartage trucking outfit 1950s; took full control in 1970s. Matty bought Warren Buffett's 25% stake in Ambassador Bridge 1979, quickly snapped up controlling stake with family. Sued by sisters 1992 for $50 million, citing company mismanagement; settled 7 years later, bought their stake. Other investments include Universal Truckload Services, PAM Transportation, CenTra. Said to ignite ire amongst Teamsters, locals with controversial business practices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stepped down as chairman of U.K. food retailer Morrisons in March 2008 after 55 years at the group; had been chairman since 1956, when took over from his father, who founded the retailer in 1899. During his tenure transformed it from small market stall into a $13 billion (market cap) company. Suffered criticism from some shareholders for his management style. Fortune is almost entirely tied up in Morrisons stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brewmaster of Turkey created one of the country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. Controls Anadolu Group conglomerate with fellow billionaire Kamil Yazici. Beer and soft drink growth slowing; brewer Anadolu Efes stock down by a quarter over the past year. Group also holds 50% stake in Coca-Cola Turkey. Auto sales hit as well: makes Isuzus in Turkish plants and imports Lada and Kia cars made in Russia and Korea, which are then distributed in Ukraine and central Asian countries. Ex-basketball player has a 3,000-piece pen collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chile's credit card pioneer now trying to storm the nation's top political office. Ran as right-leaning candidate in Chile's 2005 presidential election; lost but is preparing for a second attempt this year. Earned a doctorate in economics at Harvard before returning to Chile. Founded credit giant Bancard. Later amassed 27% stake in Chile's national airline, LAN. Recently pledged to unload the bulk of his shares ahead of presidential contest.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago's richest family is getting poorer as people stay home instead of at the Pritzkers' Hyatt Hotels. Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (370 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up in full swing. Sold undisclosed stake in Hyatt to the Walton family's private equity firm, Madrone Capital, and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion August 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; will sell remainder by 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media tycoon barely holding on to billionaire status. Sold $233 million worth of stock in October to appease holding company National Amusements' creditors. Last month reached deal with creditors: will repay $140 million up front; remaining $1.46 billion is due by December 2010. Will likely sell movie theaters to make debt payments. Still largest individual shareholder of Viacom (Paramount Pictures, MTV Networks) and CBS (CBS, CW, CBS Radio); gloomy ad and movie markets weighing on shares: CBS down 80%, Viacom down 60% since last March. Boston-born Harvard grad inherited theater business from father; operation became National Amusements in 1954. Firm bought controlling stake in Viacom 1987. Oversaw merger of Viacom and CBS 2000; companies split up again five years later. Majority stake in Midway Games worth $800 million 3 years ago, sold to private investor in November for $100,000. Prostate cancer survivor donated $105 million to 3 U.S. medical centers 2007.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Conair founder barely a billionaire; estimated fortune down $400 million in 6 months. College dropout established hair dryer outfit with parents in 1959. Turned $100 investment and hot-air roller invention into cash cow through rapid growth, iconic pistol-shape blow dryer design. Product line now includes razors, mirrors, fabric steamers, massagers, Interplak Oral Care.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fertilizer kingpin makes first appearance on the World's Billionaires list, but his fortune is down nearly 40% since August as the commodities bubble bursts. First job selling jewelry. Became fertilizer salesman for IBE Trade 1987; president and owner 1996. Today company controls 12% of world's ammonia supply, 6% of ammonium nitrate. Clients include Cargill, ConAgra, Koch Nitrogen. Offices in Budapest, Moscow, Kiev, Odessa; factories in Russia and Ukraine. Brooklynite owns 14 buildings in New York, looking to expand his real estate holdings. Gives to education, health; on board of Brooklyn's Brookdale University Hospital, NYC Board of Correction. President of Zvi Dov Roth Academy of Yeshiva Rambam. Enjoys tennis, spas.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's richest author. Harry Potter author named highest earning celebrity last year by Forbes, for taking home $300 million. Her 7 books in the series about a teenage wizard and his school chums has sold 400 million copies worldwide. A box office blockbuster, the 5 Harry Potter films released so far have grossed more than any other motion picture franchise in history. Sixth film scheduled for release this summer. Sales of Potter-related products, of which she gets a cut, has been reported to be in excess of $15 billion. Says she won't write any more Harry Potter books but released wizard fairytale book, Tales of Beedle the Bard, in December 2008; proceeds from that book will go to a children's charity. Her personal story is nearly as magical as the fiction she writes: single mother living on welfare in a coldwater flat in Edinburgh, Scotland, Rowling completed her first story of the teenage wizard in 1997. A year later Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone was published in the U.S. and became a children's literary sensation.
title: Author

name: Billionaires
bio: Socialite and philanthropist splits her time between London and New York and has homes in Geneva and Monaco. Counts among her friends the U.K.’s Prince Charles and his wife Camilla. Reportedly briefly listed for $740 million Villa Leopolda, an estate she owns on the French Riviera; now apparently off market. Inherited her fortune from late husband Edmond Safra, a billionaire banker who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-key fashionista sister of billionaire Ferit Sahenk and heir to Dogus Holding fortune built by father, Ayhan. Has handled retail partnerships with luxury brands Tods and Armani; once hot lux sector now slowing. Also holds title of president at family's active charitable foundation, the sponsor of well-known 3-day annual international mountain-bike festival in Turkey's Cappadocia region.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited stake in family's Sainsbury's, one of the U.K.'s largest grocers; in recent years group has expanded into insurance, banking and travel businesses. Stepped down from management in 1998 to enter politics; Minister for Science & Innovation for 8 years, resigned in 2006. Has given away hundreds of millions through his Gatsby Charitable Foundation, which supports education, medical research and the arts.  In December, gave $740,000 to U.K. Labour Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swedish badminton prodigy attended college outside Stockholm; spent two years in Paris covering European equities for Atlantic Finance. Then earned MBA at Columbia. Joined Bear Stearns in 1988, colleague of famed investment banker Ace Greenberg. Highlight of early career: worked on billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's bid for Chrysler. Founded hedge fund Sandell Asset Management 1998. Focus: "event-driven" investing. Last year investments sank 30%. Currently manages $4 billion, down from $7.5 billion in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns half of German publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck; brother Stefan von Holtzbrinck owns the rest. Other brother, Dieter, sold his share to siblings in 2006.  Heads its book publishing unit, S. Fischer Verlag, which dates back to 1886; Group was the original publisher of Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka and Hermann Hesse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of financial news and data juggernaut Bloomberg LP debuts on the World's Billionaires list after partner, New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, bought back 20% stake in the firm from Merrill Lynch for $4.5 billion this summer--valuing the company at $22 billion. Secunda owns a 4% stake. Studied math at SUNY Binghamton; took job in systems research at Salomon Brothers. Traded bonds at Morgan Stanley; joined Michael Bloomberg and others to launch financial information services firm Innovative Market Systems 1982. Later renamed Bloomberg LP. Pitched Merrill Lynch on prototype that could crunch financial data, provide information on government bonds 1983; sold Merrill a 30% stake for $30 million. Today Secunda oversees all Bloomberg financial products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minority partner in Russian oil magnate Roman Abramovich's Millhouse LLC; firm founded 2001 to manage assets owned by Abramovich and his partners. Duo founded oil-trading outfit Runicom early 1990s. Took control of oil firm Sibneft 1995; sold stake to Russian state-owned gas monopoly Gazprom for $13.1 billion a decade later. Agreed to buy 41% of Evraz, Russia's largest steelmaker, in 2006. Took drugmaker Pharmstandard public May 2007. Other investments: Russian meat processor, Moscow real estate. Abramovich gave Shvidler his yacht 2006; Le Grand Bleu (The Big Blue) came complete with 65-man crew, helicopter, aquarium, speedboat.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dealmaker founded marketing outfit Snyder Communications. Bought Washington Redskins for $800 million 1999. Team now worth $1.5 billion; second most valuable team in the league behind Jerry Jones' Dallas Cowboys. Purchased Dick Clark Productions in 2007 for $175 million. Net worth down more than 20% since last March as recession racks restaurant and entertainment portfolio; shares of his Six Flags amusement parks down nearly 90% in past 12 months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Poland's sole billionaire returns to ranks after a one-year hiatus with successful listing of his digital television platform Cyfrowy Polsat. Enthusiasm for the stock, which is up 23%, lifted his fortune in an otherwise dismal year; Poland's WIG index is down 51% and the 6 Polish billionaires from 2008 all dropped off the list. Controls Polsat, now one of the nation's biggest television stations. Deal to sell a 25% stake of Polsat TV to Germany's Axel Springer for $325 million and list shares failed when parties could not agree on price. Also owns shares in Invest Bank, pension fund PTE Polsat, pharmaceutical Bioton and TV producer ATM Grupa. Shares in Elektrim challenged in court. Began importing cars from the then East Germany in the 1980s; moved into media in 1992.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs conglomerate Rajawali Group. Its Express Group is Indonesia's second-largest taxi operator. Most valuable holding is stake in cementmaker Semen Gresik. Sold off interest in cell phone company, Excelcomindo Pratama, for more than $400 million in 2007. Signed agreement with Cambodian government to develop its national airline. Opened a St. Regis hotel in Bali in September. Owns vacation home in Beverly Hills in same enclave as Denzel Washington and Rod Stewart.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime baker broke ground on properties in the 1960s. Today A.G. Spanos Cos. is one of the country's largest apartment developers; firm worth a fraction of what it once was because of the massive housing slowdown in the U.S. Best asset: pro football's San Diego Chargers. Sons now manage team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media and industrial equipment are the twin hearts of the business interests of Stokes, who is also one of Australia's major art collectors and philanthropists. Most of his television, publishing and internet assets lie in Seven Network, a 50/50 joint venture with the private equity specialist, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Stokes' industrial equipment assets are wholly-owned via a franchise to sell and service Caterpillar earthmoving and construction gear in Australia and China. Already the biggest Cat dealer in Australia through his WestTrac. Self-made billionaire started out installing television aerials on suburban homes as a teenager. Stokes boosted his popularity at home by acquiring one of the few remaining Victoria Cross medals, the highest award in the Australian military, and then donating it to the Australian War Memorial.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded the Guanghui Group in 1989. Today, from headquarters in Urumqi in Xinjiang Province, Sun's companies employ 20,000 people and have operations in real estate, natural gas and logistics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Highbridge Capital hedge fund and private equity outfit smarting from tumultuous 2008: flagship "Multi-Strategy" fund down 24%, computer-based "Statistical Opportunities" fund up 22.1%. With grade-school buddy Glenn Dubin launched Highbridge in 1992. Sold 55% stake to JPMorgan in 2004 for more than $1.3 billion; duo still controls investment decisions. Assets down 44% from peak in July 2007 to $20 billion today. Swieca: on executive committee of pro-Israel lobby American Israel Public Affairs Committee.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded, runs China's largest women's footwear retailer, Belle International, which bought footwear retailer Mirabell International Holdings for $200 million last year. Also sells sportswear brands including Nike, Reebok, Li Ning. Owns Fila trademark in mainland, Hong Kong, Macau. Tang's partner is mainland tycoon Shen Baijiao. Serves as Chairman of the Federation of Hong Kong Footwear. Shares fortune with 38-year-old daughter, Tang Ming Wai, the group's executive director, who has a business degree from the University of Texas at Austin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of the mall maven's Taubman Centers REIT have dropped 70% in the past year, erasing $700 million from his net worth. University of Michigan dropout founded Taubman Centers 1950; today owns 23 malls in 10 states. Son Robert joined in 1976, chief executive since 1990. Purchased venerable auction house Sotheby's 1983; took private. Public again 1988. Spent 9 months in jail on price-fixing charges 2004; wrote memoir "Threshold Resistance" about experience. Still owns stake in Sotheby's; stock down nearly 80% in past 12 months. Value of large contemporary art collection down from blistering summer art market highs. Building $54 million movie studio Pontiac, Mi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bartender's son attended Southern Illinois U. with money raised from selling life insurance, housing projects. Pounced on booming telecom market; founded Excel Communications 1988. Took public 1996. Quickly sold 2 years later to Teleglobe near peak of tech bubble for $3.5 billion. Reinvested in stocks, bonds, horses. Net worth down 20% as private equity, hedge fund investments decline.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Dieter and half-sister Monika Schoeller, both billionaires, inherited publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, from their father George,  who founded it as a book club in 1948.  Since 2001, has run the $3.2 billion (sales) company; it owns German newspapers Die Zeit and Handelsblatt and publishing houses Henry Holt in New York and Macmillan in London.  In 2006 he and Monika bought out Dieter's one-third share; each now own 50% of the group. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining Holtzbrinck in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard graduate and cofounder of Royal Caribbean, which has seen stock price plunge more than four-fifths in past year. Luckily, pocketed at least $500 million in September when China Oilfield Services acquired all of Awilco Offshore, including his 40% stake, for $2.5 billion. Chairs the family investment company, with stakes in oil tankers, Russian hotels and Baltic shopping centers. Also owns private Norwegian real estate outfit Linstow.

name: Billionaires
bio: As a boy worked at his father's grocery store in Istanbul and learned how to trade. Founder of Anadolu Group, brewer and distributor of beer and soft drinks, and holder of a 50% stake in Coca-Cola Turkey. Brewer Anadolu Efes stock down by a quarter over the past year; auto and consumer finance interests also suffering. Partner of fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan. Has helped open thousands of summer sports camps throughout Turkey to generate interest in basketball.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Hong Kong-listed China Yurun, one of China's largest pork processors. China Yurun is one of only a handful of stocks headed by billionaires that actually appreciated in U.S. dollar value in the past year. Zhu also is a major shareholder in Nanjing Central Emporium, a Shanghai-listed department store, and Yurun Dihua, a real estate company. Co-founded Nanjing Yurun Meat Product, a predecessor business to China Yurun, with wife Wu Xueqin in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majority owner of steelmaker Mechel incurred wrath of Prime Minister Vladimir Putin last summer when Putin accused the company of price-fixing. Relations much improved. Company granted a $1.5 billion loan by state-controlled Vnesheconombank in January. Outlook glum; shares down 96% since last February, and 3.4% of his stake held as loan collateral by UBS investment bank. Now part of mega-merger talk under way among billionaires Alisher Usmanov, Oleg Deripaska, Vladimir Potanin,  Dmitry Rybolovlev, and Roman Abramovich, to combine assets and have government assist in restructuring debt. Also in the works: plans to buy West Virginia-based Bluestone Coal Corp for a combination of cash and shares.  In 2001 his coal mines and coal trading outfit Yuzhny Kuzbass bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Metallurgical Plant from U.S. billionaire and commodity trader Marc Rich's Glencore. Out of these assets he created steel and mining Mechel Group, which went public in 2004 on the NYSE.
